number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Summary: Basically, the game is good, but the features are just so out there and change too much. It left a bad taste in my mouth to be honest. It was fun, I'll give it that; but for 20 bucks, I expected it to have alot more content and actually extend the gameplay with higher levels. Instead, like stated, alot was changed, and alot was restricted. It doesn't feel fun to have restrictions on a coop game. This feels more like a F2P prototype for the first DD. Positives, negatives, and in the middle of the two:+ A few new maps, some from the community. + New currency system. This is one of the few good ideas they had to be honest.+ Gear is phsyical. Equip it and it shows. You can make it invisible if you want, you just need to buy the ridiculously cheap invisible armor from the tavern keeper.+ Ability to dye items. This is good since you can make the weapon fit with your overall look. + Physical dye. Work towards making your character unique!+ All classes and characters unlocked. Well that's nice. Another good idea.- No steam workshop for mods. Just microtransaction ideas for items people submit. Sad thing? No one submits anything. That's . . . Just sad. Why did they think people would help with this if they hate it so much?- No local multiplayer with a controler, and a rather dumbed down singleplayer thats nearly impossible.- Microtransactions for emotes and hats. I think this is a slap to the face since they wanted it to be like TF2 or any other social game we see with a vanity system.- Difficult to level. Extremely slow leveling speed.- Level 60 cap.- Gear is divided into levels of 8. Honestly, did they REALLY just think that was a feature that was a good idea? Now it's even HARDER to get past the easy maps. It's now nearly a REQUIREMENT to jump on a survival game built by a high level. God.- Skins are all unlocked at the beginning. All of them. Even ones that were unlocked by getting an achievment.- Pets given at the start include the cube everyone used as advanced currency before . . . Big slap to the face again. It stings that none of the starting pets can be upgraded or even be useful.- Very low enchantment/upgrade limit. 16 upgrades max?! That's insanely dumbed down, making it EVEN MORE IMPOSSIBLE for new players! Now they can't upgrade their low level gear with the gold they EARN.- No more minion units. ♥♥♥♥ing. Genius. I mean, theres no real reason we needed those, right?Except for building survival builds. And every other build. Yeah, good job Trendy, you ♥♥♥♥ed us over on that one. Now the summoner is useless as a builder; he used to be able to just decimate from using these minion units, now he's just basically a wimpy downgrade to any class.  = New system that involves the requirement to have played that map or unlocked it in order to play a server with it. Now the rant. Oh boy.:. . . Why did I think this game was good when I was playing it, is the question. I mean, I played it because it's DD and I can't afford every single DLC and content pack for the original. I hoped this was going to be the same or at least like it, but it turned out I'm not the only one upset that it's entirely different. Oh no, it turns out, everyone agrees. It's sad to see that 'Mixed' score on DDE, then look at DD1+DD2, and see 'Very Positive' on both. Just utterly sad; the people who remade DD were probably entirely different devs than the people who made it. Otherwise, the qaulity check is long overdue and Trendy needs to try to seriously reconsider the 'rebalanced' idea. In a game about coop set in a rpg, is rebalancing things really needed? Furthermore, are tower defense games supposed to be neccesarily 'balanced'? Doesn't it take away the fun to survive onslaught after onslaught of orcs, goblins, and ogres with your friends as you both become stronger? Yes. Trendy, remove the balancing. If anything, we need to bring back the DD1 core experience back if we want this community to survive. It's a good game, don't get me wrong, but unless it's reverted to its golden days of DD1 in terms of experience, it's going to be dead like DRM games usually are.

number of helpful: 30 of 57 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												After playing some time, i can say, that this game is NOT garbage. Like many people said, this is more or less a GOTY edition, but also their way to intruduce people to their own gaming hub for the upcoming DD2.Sound and Graphics are the same, nothing much changed. (To this point the Textures dont seem to load for some people, a bug i assume)Gameplay almost stayed the same, they added some mechanics, like Pet abilities, Egg hatching, seeing the armor you are wearing and colouring it. Not all of the new things but some.To play you will need a online connection, probably for their Anti Hacker/Cheater System. The matches are now hosted from their servers, in EU its a small delay but i guess (hope) they will find a way to reduce it.Private or "Solo" lobbies have been added this evening.~I heard there is a ingame Store now, is it P2W?~Even though i dont understand why they added it, but yes, there is a small selection of taunts you can buy for 1 Dollar each.But thats all it. You wont win the game because you can now show off a fancy dance.Now the most important question.Shall you buy it?If you dont mind starting from the beginning and were a fan of the original DD you should buy it. Alot of people already play it so its easy to find other players. to play with.Also if you are a huge fan of Tower Defence, RPG with the possibility of Co-Op, this game is the right choice.But if you like b***** around because you can now spend a dollar for a taunt, and you consider this P2W or cashgrabbing, then you shall play something different.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Game appears to be unsupported a mere 8 months after release. Still numerous bugs in the game, everything from visual bugs, to enemies spawning in locations or getting stuck where they cannot be killed and you have to restart the entire level, to not being able to progress in the game at all due to levels that are required to be completed not loading. It does not bode well for this developer that they drop support for a game less than a year after release because they are working on a sequel, making me hesitant to purchase anything else from them. Couple that with the fact that this game requires an internet connection, has an additional Playverse overlay that forces you to create yet another login/password to memorize and be concerned about having it compromised when they are inevitably hacked, and that all of your characters are stored on their servers (with no option to import them locally) makes this a big no-no purchase.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												If you already own Dungeon Defenders 1, the price point for this game is exceedingly reasonable.  Basically consider it a full reset, with new maps and several new features.  Do you have to start over?  Yeah, because of the new server-central architecture.  But hey, the early levels were the fun levels anyway.I got it when it was on sale (and the pre-owner discount stacked) so I paid $6 and am more than happy.If you don't own Dungeon Defenders already, then this is the game you want instead.  Dungeon Defenders is an epic combination of Tower Defense and Hack-and-Slash RPG and there are no other games in this genre that even come close.  Sure, there's Sanctum, but its mechanics and defense building are so much less interesting, its weapons have less kick, there's fewer options, and oh yeah.  The enemies have 100% immunity armor.  Good luck sniping the weakspot!

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Now. As a player of the original Dungeon Defenders, I looked forward to this. Now, unlike everyone else.. ranting and raving about how Crap this is. Let me start off with the good stuff.1: You don't have to pay to unlock all the characters. They are all there ready for you.2: The UI for your Character Sheet is much better. It allows you to easily swap over gear3: The bonus of your armour ACTUALLY changes when you put it on. For EG: I picked up a crown and I saw the crown on my charaters head.4: The abillity to create a character and name it without having to go out of the game and back to the menu to name it, colour it, and all that.5: The open tavern. Alot don't like the idea as Whining, Rude people, Noobs and such. The open tavern is a place where people can meet up, stuff like that instead of having a game on a menu to pick from. and not knowing who you might be playing with. At least with the open tavern, you can get a rough idea.6: The abillities. Nothing makes Dungeon Defenders like the placement of towers and useage of abillities. That is still all there, but with a little more. There are now ingame items which can be used to assist gameplay. Of course these can be bought from the tavernkeeper, or you can find them randomly drop from Goblins, Orcs, Dark Elves and the such or from chests. 7: The Character Model. The Character sheet now has a model of your character. It allows for 360* rotation to view all angles of your character.8: Cross-Platform. Got a friend who is waiting for a new PC? Well why not buy them a copy of Dungeon Defenders Eternity on a different platform and let them play with you.9: Same classic music... it even sounds clearer10: The map selection is easier to traverse11: The portraits of the parents look better12: When dying, you have 6 colour slots instead of 3 making for more customization13: (Just Played Multiplayer) The drops are individual and so are the chests. no longer shared manaNow that I belive I have done all the Pros, its time for the cons.1: Lack of instant customization. Sure you can pick a skin to use on a hero, but to customize it more, you need to buy Dye from the tavern keep. Oh If you make a mistake, buy a bucket of white wash and start again with buying more dye.2: Limited Skins. Heroes have custom skins, but they are limited.3: One Server. From what I can tell, there is one server.4: The Cash Shop. Yep, the annoying Cash shop to get more stuff. Usually associated with Pay 2 Win games. Though in Dungeon Defenders Eternity, it is thankfully only for cosmetics.5: While an open tavern is good, It also does have its cons. With an open tavern, The abillity to move around is hard. The lack of space to find friends, or even preview your character are hindered.6: Online. Now, I know you might rage at this, saying online is a con? well, It is and it isnt. The con of the online is that if your not connected to the internet, you can't play.7: Currency. You no longer use Mana crystals. You use gold coins to buy stuff which you find randomly in chests and from enemy drops and buy sellling old gear. (Not to sure about after completing a wave or a map as my game wasn't completely downloaded when I stated to play)8: Wait time. You join a game wether its private or public and you have to wait.9: It doesn't use Steam UI for invites10: You can't customise your Crystal11: The Defence Units are shared among all players, including those playing summonerThere are more pros and cons, but as of this time of what I have played, This is all I can give. I am bound to do another Review after more playtime.Now, Some people might like the original Dungeon Defenders and hate this, or vice versa or like both. It doesn't matter as everyone is different. So I am not going to say YES buy this or NO don't buy this. I will let you decide if you want to buy it or not. I wouldn't based your decision on the reviews, but on videos on gameplay, demos or trying it at a friends place. But as a gamer and lover of Dungeon Defenders (note Dungeon Defenders was one of the first games I bought on steam when it first came out many years ago near christmas) I would recommend this if you want to just have fun without the worry of paying for more characters, maps, skins etc.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												I would like to add some counterweight to the terrible review this has recieved.DD1 is a fantastic game with well designed and fun content that will keep you engaged for hours. This is simply an extension of that game and it has essentially been rebuilt from the ground up in a manner that could provide a better and more secure environment.Originally Eternity did not release with single player mode enabled however this has been changed. They were appologetic about the decision and admitted that it was a mistake. Here's a part of that blog:"Single player and private sessions now availableBlog - July 22, 2014 - By Brad Logston, Senior Producer of the Dungeon Defenders FranchiseHey Defenders. We have just enabled Single Player and Private Sessions to Dungeon Defenders Eternity tonight.Turning off Single Player/Private match in our initial release of Eternity was related to our fear that the server costs would be exponential, and cause us to lose significant money. We realize that jeopardizing the loyalty of fans far outweighs the risk of profit – and it was a mistake."A I already own the original, I've only had to pay £4, which is nothing really. If you do not and pay the full amount then you're about to experience the best of a fantastic game with none of the issues that existed before (such as people hacking their characters to get hacked op stats and bad internet games hosted on other peoples machines). It's no longer an issue because the information is stored on dedicated servers (which they could not afford before due to being a new company)If you read many of the negative comments they all seem to be displeased about things that have allready been resolved or things that are kind of inconsiquential.

												First off. There are some legitimate complaints in the negative reviews. There are quite a few bugs, and some features in the description aren't available yet. Many of the complaints in the negative reviews, which were mostly made in the first 2 hours of launch, have been addressed.My personal experience has had a minimum of lag or instability, I haven't run into many problems, and those I did did not ruin the fun. For the price you really can't go wrong. you could go see a movie or two and get a fraction of the entertainment.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Ok this review is for you if you:A) Loved the first gameB) Ran it sort of ok on your PC that was just about up to the jobC) Read all the early reviews and thought...........I better not risk itLike you I was excited about the release of a rebalanced/updated version but having red the reviews slating every aspect of the game and complaining about how it runs (I saw a guy with a great graphics card and 16G of ram saying it ran slow) I decided to give it a miss.Unfortunately for me, my daughter is a massive fan of the original and pestered me to give it a try and I'm glad I did.My Laptop (Not a swear word) is only i5 with intel hd graphics and 3G ram. I could run Dungeon Defenders fine (Lower settings) at about 30 fps. Dungeon defenders etternity both looks and runs better (At similar lower settings) so thats one worry down.The changes to the game are mostly good. The game plays well and there is more loot than ever before. The multiplayer both sets up and plays better and each player has there own individual chests and loot pick ups (So no loot ninjaing. Although that was fun at times) which makes for a better multiplayer experience. The shared tavern is not a terrible addition as many claim, it is a little annoying fighting your way to the bar but its a small grumble. I don't like the new menu systems for items (Its very small sometimes even when displayed through my massive TV) and having all your costumes as items gets in the way. I like the new hatching and leveling up of pets and visibility of armor etc. Consumables seem a bit pointless but it might be I need to use them a bit more to get the point. But these points aside this IS the game you know and love in a new updated version for you to grind through. If you made a little 'whoop' when you saw this on steam but then changed your mind, change it back. Its all good. All the chracters costumes and levels you want plus extras and the new permadeath hardcore mode is awesome.PS Dont fear the microtransactions......so far its pointless not play to win. Remember you DON'T need that emote!

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Right now, this game is a prime example of how not to do online DRM / matchmaking.In the pursuit to eliminate cheaters, Trendy in their infinite wisdom re-released this updated versions of the game with their new Playverse backend, requiring everyone to connect to a Public Online Tavern Area.Here lies the problem with this game at the moment: If the tavern does not load due to server issues there is no way to play the game at all. Even if you want to play solo .. you still have to connect to this public tavern area to be able to start a mission.For several days since launch people have had this issue, and no reliable fixes in sight.If you can log in the game is fun and performs very well indeed. If you already have the original Dungeon Defenders .. do yourself a favour and stick with that until they sort out these ridiculous connection issues.Can't recommend this game till they fix this game breaking issue.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Dungeon Defenders: Eternity, a sort of hold over title released by TrendyENT to test out their playverse system and to tide Dungeon Defender fans over until the awaited sequal releases, is quite the game.Eternity holds true to the core game in that you grind through numerous dungeons... Kill tons of enemies and bosses... and farm for even better loot to upgrade and destroy "The Old Ones" with. That said, the game has been changed around plenty enough to give a new feel to even the most veteran of defenders.Added to Eternity are a plethora of new systems and tweaks that really give the game that fresh coat of paint it deserves. Eternity starts you off with all 12 of the games classes right off of the bat, as well as all of the maps from the core game, and the download packs(holiday maps aside) rolled into one. On top of that it starts you off with several costumes unlocked, with some being put behind achievement walls giving you something extra to work towards just as you had to with the first game. Aside from the characters and maps, TrendyENT added in a much welcomed dodge mechanic that allows you to jump out of harms way in an instant, so long as you have the energy for it. Both hero and monster damage has been reworked, the overall games balancing has been given some loving, and the overall display has been given a fresh look. The game also features new maps not seen in the core game or in any of it's downloadable packs, as well as a new looting and crafting system. Gone is the mana bank and coins have taken their place. Coins can be used to upgrade weapons, buy items/consumables that you can use in battle, and even to purchase colored dyes which can be used to recolor practically every inch of your character in numerous ways. The pet system was also given an overhaul, as you now collect pets by gathering eggs mid-battle and hatching them. You'll never know what pet species you'll get until it hatches!My only real gripe with the game so far is it's launcher. The launcher itself is horrible... It can take quite a while to download a patch, or the core game resources, which most will find to be annoying. Aside from that the game feels, looks, and plays like Dungeon Defenders, but better. I've spent roughly 15 hours at this point actually playing the game, and it's a purchase I most certainly do not regret!!I highly recommend this game for anyone who enjoys Action RPGs, Loot grinding games(similar to diablo and borderlands), Tower Defense games, Co-op titles, and fantasy styled games. It's a lot of fun, and even more so when you play with friends. With plenty of maps, challenges, and classes (With more maps coming soon for free), there is always a ton to do in Etheria.Happy Defending, and see you in the Playverse!8.8/10

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												I don't understand all the hate this is getting. This game's base mechanics are so similar to the origional that it's extremely difficult for me to even think this was ported TO mobile. Besides, it seems you need gamepad attachments for your phone or something, so why even play it on a phone or anything if you're just gonna slap on some gamepad bits... This is a game that's available on mobile, but doesn't CATER to mobile. Stop calling it a "cheap port from mobile", because that's totally not what it is.Anyway, my friends and I were a bit skeptical at first because of all the horrible reviews here, but after we bought the game, well, you can see how we liked it from the eighty hours I've clocked in. It's a good game with a few balancing issues still, but they've shown alot of real effort towards balancing progression, stats, gear, and all that fun stuff. It's alot better than it was in DD1.Why's everyone complaining about summoner? Him having his own personal DU pool was just absurd from a game design perspective. He's no longer OP and uses regular DU like everybody else. I mean sure, he can't attack, but that's kinda the reason his soldiers can move. RTS-em-up, yaknow?They added amulets (which act as standalone spells) which are pretty nice. They even made new assets and everything for them, it's great. They also help give the player more power to do stuff and aid in balancing out the game. Sure, some have trolling potential, but just get together some friends and play yourselves then.Public tavern/hub world. I was cool with it, it's not gonna kill me to holler at a few people for friks and giggles, and helps the tavern not be creepily empty like it was all the time in DD1.If you liked DD1, you'll like this. Also, the "cash shop"? Just a bunch of emoticons as of the time of this review, they're not even worth buying and don't affect the game at all. Dunno if it'll be expanded upon, but right now nothin really freemium or microtransaction-y has happened.It has always-online servers, and you can only play online. Don't get the complaints about this; this is how MMOs work. Yeah, this isn't an open-world MMO persay, but you could call it an MMO. Plus, when Trendy's servers DO bite the big one, they'll hopefully pass the torch to dedicated servers or something. If they don't, well, SOMEONE's gonna do something about it since this game is online-drivin (at the moment of this review). I don't think they'd just shut the game down and lose all the potential customers. Matchmaking for the game derps now and then, but even big companies have server problems, so should we REALLY bash an INDIE company over such a trivial issue?No splitscreen yet, the game's being "developed" in a way, as in it's still receiving updates (which is something you should expect from an online MMO-esque game). Splitscreen was initially removed due to exploits involving it from what I've gathered. I keep calling it "MMO-esque" and the like because, while the public taverns are where you see the bulk of players, each actual game map supports 1-4 players, barring some huge maps which allow 1-6 players if I recall correctly. If you can't deal with trolls or the incompetence of the players in public servers, just get some friends and host private matches.Content is streamed in, instead of downloaded all at once. Honestly, I prefer it this way. It means I don't have to wait an hour for the game to download if I want to play right away. On the other side the content has to download when you get to it, but I'm cool with that. Core game mechanics are loaded right away, so you won't be bumbling around in a disjointed mess or anything.Again, this game has a few balancing issues still, but givin the nature of everything I feel that most of them will be ironed out at some point. The game's still a hell of a lot of fun, and it'd be a shame not to give it a try. Don't listen to those clowns who only clocked in under an hour, or barely over an hour, of playtime. Listen to a real Dungeon Defender....Besides, if you've owned DD1, discounts stack. I got this for six bucks. That's like, a happy meal at mcdonalds or something. It won't bite back, trust me.(Oh yeah, by the way, this game has all the relevant DLC of DD1 pre-installed. Knock yourself out, buddy.)

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												I have spent, as of writing this review, about 1 hour in game. I have 6 hours on record, but about 3 of them were downloading, since the Steam download is essentially just the launcher.What were the other 2 hours? Well, in all honesty, I've spent 2 hours collectively trying to connect to their servers. I got a single map in today. While trying to return to the tavern, a familiar "you have been forcibly removed from the game" message appeared. I don't even know what that means, but I'm guessing it's a way of saying the connection timed out designed to make the player feel ♥♥♥♥♥♥. When somebody's forcibly removed, you imagine some obnoxious guy getting kicked out of a store or club by security, not somebody that's having issues connecting to a server. That aside, I haven't been able to connect to a game since today. It's been like this since I got it. I get to play a little, then I'm forcibly removed from the game. Of course, if this were like the original Dungeon Defenders, I could just play single player if I wanted and still play the game at least, but nope, not an option. Between that, the addition of microtransactions in a B2P game, and the inclusion of a second type of log-in after Steam make me kind of wish I could just get my money back and leave this mess behind, and hope that when DD2 comes out, they make some improvements on this system they have.All the complaining out of the way, there are some really great things here. The addition of 4 slots for consumables like potions or, which I prefer, amulets, are an amazing addition. The amulets give you little magical abilities at the cost of mana, like AoE lightning, of a fireball, or healing. The consumables have a variety of effects, ranging from potions of mana that give you additional mana, to holy hand grenades which just deal explosive damage. Before my last forceful removal from the game, I'd picked up a couple of pet eggs, which made the removal even more painful. They were drops after completing a level, and apparently you hatch pets in this game by putting them in one of your 4 amulet/consumable slots and getting exp. That was exciting to me, and I couldn't wait to see what I got.Also, to their credit and to defend the second log-in, they seem to have included TwitchTV streaming. Or, at least, I saw an option that had a sign-in for it and a "start stream" button. That's cool, now there might be a good number of DD streamers to help bolster the community.Overall, as the game is, it needs some work. Maybe buff the servers, or let there be an offline mode, even if it's completely separate from the online in terms of characters and loot and stuff. I'd probably recommend it if I could play it steadily, and since I can play larger games without connection issues, I don't think the problem is entirely on my end. I am prepared to edit my review, though, with future updates and any improvements they make, because this game has potential, and there are a lot of things I'd love to see from this game in DD2.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Ok i'm on the fence on this one.... In some ways DD Eternity is BETTER then the original game, it's not another Unreal Engine start up, it's on it's own dedicated engine.. Despite what people say while it's multiplatform it looks BETTER then the original Dungeon Defenders.. HOWEVER....  The actual discription and other items for this game are deceptive. I will list everything that is DECEPTIVE about the game below.1. There is NOTHING here to tell you that you MUST be ONLINE to play this, the original Dungeon Defenders let you play OFFLINE and LOCAL network.2. There is NOTHING here to tell you that your going to be STREAMING 99.99% of the ASSETS on the FLY, that's right you get a 40mb dl then you have to STREAM the rest of the game, this is MAJORLY wrong.3. This is meant to be a fully paid for game.. yet it has a 'Cosmetic' Cash Store in it.. Which it SHOULD NOT have at all.. if you pay for a game you pay for the game, not part of the game.4. Trendy Have been deceptive in how they handled the release, how they put up information, etc.. These guys have seriously LOST a lot of the respect the community had for them.. OVERNIGHT.Trendy Need to remember that not every one wants to be online while they play a game, there are a lot of defense personnel who game, who can NOT always be online, there are a lot of people in areas with POOR internet that can not always STREAM content, while you can understand the harder stance against Hacking and Cheating, Trendy have taken what people loved, the ability to CONTROL THEIR GAMING EXPERIANCE, and said you MUST PLAY OUR WAY ON OUR SERVERS or not at all.Bad move Trendy... I was gonna buy DD2, you just lost a customer unless you return it back to how Dungeon Defenders ORIGINALLY played.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												While the improvements for this game are many. The fact that you have to purchase this version makes it far less amazing than it actually is. Because what it actually is, is an update...not an actual completely new game. This is the same game as Dungeon Defenders, just with all the fixes and some new stuff they're testing out. I purchased Dungeon Defenders when the summer sale was happening. Which means I got everything for this game for like $20 or less (I can't really remember the price), which is a lot of DLCs and other content. This game is cheap still, at $6 for people who own DD, or $14 for people who don't. Still a good deal. But the fact that people who already own DD have to pay for this is just a money grab.It would have been more fair for people who already own the original DD to receive this version for free while everyone else had to pay $6. Still, if you want a solid game to play that's a mix of tower defense and action RPG, then this game is still really good, but if you already own DD, then don't waste your time unless you have money to throw away, because you're not actually getting anything of value out of this version.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Dungeon Defenders has always been a fun game, but it lacked in one area that this "Revamped" version failed to fix: Shared DU.  If you want to play multiplayer, this game forces you to make 3 of your 4 party members go dps.  Otherwise multiple builders just step on eachother's toes.  Summoner in the old game was the only thing that eased up on this, allowing two builders and two dps for a 4player game.  Although I feel the summoner being pushed to DU was slightly warrented, as it made games where you did not have someone to fulfill the Summoner role difficult, however it returned us back to the origional issue of a "Tower Defense" with four players fighting for rights to build towers.I await the day they change this, as to change my review to a thumbs up.  Comon, Trendy, you can do it!

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												On 2.0 things are starting to look more DDesque. Solo gameplay is avaliable, but, personally I do find there are still quite some design flaws - like summoners, who can use 2 pets have to rebind (using the action wheel) their 2nd pet skill, some collision shenanigans, the "collective tavern" spamming announcements of people joining/leaving, you STILL have to calculate wether a new piece of gear is better than the older because equiped set gears are still shown with their bonus applied, lack of tooltips on lots of stuff, sorting out sets is still a growing pain (instead of finding 4 matching pieces, now you need 7), resistances seem now to be more complicated, crafting is lackluster and the playverse isn't very user friendly.But not all changes were for worse - pet skills, amulets and dashes add some new layers of depth to the gameplay. If you can deal with the problems, it is now still not so much enjoyable, but surely playble. If the devs manage to keep improving the game, it has quite a lot of potential - and I do hope they do make this into a better dungeon defenders.pet peeve: summoners now use DUs instead of MUs D:<---------As of 1.0, it's pretty much a nuisance instead of a game.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												This game...I’m shocked as to how badly they screwed up a re-release of a classic tower defense game. If you're familiar with the original dungeon defender, then a lot of things will seem very familiar, if a little unintuitive at first.However if you’re new to this series, then I feel really bad – you are thrown into a public tavern without going through any tutorial (which the original had) and you automatically start out with the MONK, a class that according its description in the original game is designed for advanced players…but you wouldn’t know that because the developers had the genius idea of not including ANY tooltips in this re-release. Tooltips and simple descriptions of the classes were in the original version – they can’t be that hard to implement (unless there are limitations to this mobile port).This game needs a lot of work before I can recommend it, especially for newer players.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
UPDATE: Offline mode and Steam achievements have been added into the game. I have edited my review to reflect this.Dungeon Defenders Eternity is a revamped version of the original Dungeon Defenders. In this new one is a whole slew of new content (Check this guide for more info about that).Offline/SingleplayerThere's now offline mode in the game and the option to host a private tavern with your friends.MoneyThe only thing you can use your IRL money to buy is the cosmetic emotes and (upcoming) accessories that don't do anything useful other than making you look cool. All of the DLC from the original is for free in this game.PlayverseAt first, I didn't like the whole Playverse thing, but it's really not that bad. In Playverse, you can create groups in which everyone in that group will get sent a invite to join another group member in a match, and you can have multiple groups.MiscellaneousThe game doesn't have a tutorial, so good luck new players to DD figuring out what the ♥♥♥♥ to do. You can't customise your Eternia Crystal like in the original game, but it isn't that big of a deal. Survival mode has been changed to instead 25 waves, to one continuous wave that lasts a hour long. I used to only own 50 items in my box, then it went up to 800 once I did one successful match of survival.Pros:Revamped end-game and other fixed♥♥♥♥♥♥br>No more hackersTrading CardsRuns greatStill the good 'ole Dungeon DefendersCons:Doesn't use Steam to update the gameNo tutorialNo splitscreenNot Dungeon Defenders 2

number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												To put it simply, this is a disgusting mess.To be fair, all the new stuff is great. The new gear system, the modified progression, the consolidation and simplifying of all the DLC... all of that is really nice. The problem is the unholy layer of oily grime and garbage it's all buried underneath.The UI is beyond clunky. It actually feels like it's even working against the player at times. Doing even the simplest of tasks requires navigating menu upon menu, where the original game has everything right there waiting for you. And it's all just so slow.The new tavern system is atrocious. Gone forever are the charming personal taverns, decorated with trophies and awards. But the really important part is how you are now forced into a crowded, public tavern. It lags, it's loud, and all the while the chat is popping up over your menus you're trying to navigate. Be prepared to inspect multiple players instead of opening the forge or shop because the tavern is so overcrowded. What used to be a place of relaxation between missions is now just as chaotic as the missions themselves.Even the tavern itself is a mess: The Tavernkeep is still behind the counter for all your shopping needs... but the new crafting guy is on the balcony above him. This places every single useful aspect of the tavern as far away from each other as possible, leaving you to run around all over the place when all you want to do is get set up for the next mission. Also, for some reason some of the practice dummies have been removed. Want to test your new weapon? Well get in line, because so do the other dozen people in your tavern!Customization seems to be a mixed bag. Your character wears their gear now, which is neat, and you can even dye it with a wide selection of colors. (This is extra fun with the Jester/Fool, who like to just kinda slap the gear onto their bodies wherever they'd like.) However, you can no longer customize your crystal or your character's base colors on creation. They gave some, but they also took some.One of the big draws is the usable items, like the amulets. They're kinda neat, but really, I feel like they're unnecessary and just serve to dilute the diversity of the character classes a bit. Also, the pet eggs are weird. The game gives you a pet, but you must carry it in an item slot and watch it do nothing for a while until the game decides you may start using it. This is somehow considered fun and a positive addition to the game.Speaking of "fun," there's also a crafting system. Maybe this is a personal opinion, but I've never seen the appeal to these things. They jsut seem to be this weird fad game mechanic that everyone puts into their games nowadays. I've never heard of anyone saying "Wow, a crafting system! I am so excited for that!" Honestly I don't see the draw of the game giving me a weapon, but telling me I can't use it until I collect an arbitrary number of useless doodads.Finally, there's the biggest elephant in the room... the always online system. This is another one of those cases where, if you want to play your game, you're at the mercy of the servers. No offline play at all here, not even for single player. (There isn't even a single player mode. You just have to make a private room and not invite anyone in. But you still have to deal with the public tavern.) And someday, when the servers die forever, so too does your access to this game. While on the other hand, the original game is all on your computer, meaning you'll always have it.So, in short, this is a good... expansion? Remake? I don't even know what to call it. But whatever it is, it's good. It just needs a LOT of buffing and scrubbing before it's actually servicable. I'd STRONGLY recommend just playing the original version. The updates here are nice, but ultimately not worth the tradeoffs. Only get this if you've never played the game at all and don't have the cash to get caught up on all the DLC.

number of helpful: 17 of 32 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Always online. No split screen. Stay away. Don't get me wrong, if this was simply a bundle of the Dungeon Defenders series, it would be well more than worth it...but ALWAYS ONLINE. And many other bad changes.Okay, maybe you live in the mystical wonderland of internet where you get more than 1 provider, and one of them is actually reliable, so what's this new version all about?Slightly revised UI. I actually really dislike the fact that when you hit the inventory button, only a tiny bit of the screen is used to show the stats of the character, and you have to go through more than 1 window to look at your gear. The item box thing is a good bit more clunky, as you now have to choose your hero from there instead of when you're loading in, so, quite unneccesary.Supposedly more secure online play. I can't attest for or against this.4 more maps. Yeah, I got through one of the new maps before I got fed up with the horrible load times. Pretty on par with current maps.Did I mention there's no split screen? You can't play with friends unless they buy their own computer and this game. Kinda annoying, especially when the previous version had it in.BUGS. By god. So many bugs. Can't even log in half the time because of them. (and that's not an exaggeration, literally every other time I tried I got kicked out because of something like "AsAdmin doesn't like you" or some nonsense like that, even occasionally crashing) And when I do log in and queue for a game (no single player, wtf?) And in those precious few moments I am actually in the game, I am often stuck in the loading screen for 10-15 minutes, by which point I restart the game. I honestly don't know if it was the game or my connection, but...always online ftw.My computer far exceeds minimum requirements for this game, so not a problem with my hardware.Oh, and because of the communal tavern that everyone goes to, whenever someone logs in, it lags your connection, and for some reason, if you're comparing items, the stat screen goes away...and it will do that each and every time someone logs in, or gets out from a game...better be quick with those comparisons.Also, other players are a pain because they block your movement, crowd you out of the item box, and will attack the training dummies you are using to compare actual dps for your weapons.On the plus side: they made it so that you collect coins instead of mana to buy/upgrade items. I also kinda like the idea of the blueprints...but I only had 2 drop and they weren't that great, certainly not compared to what drops regularlyHowever, you can't buy items now for some reason, and some characters really can't solo if they don't have good items, so better hope your drops are better than mine when I tried and play the barbarianEvery person also spawns their own chests and items. This is relatively good. You don't have ninjas, or mana hogs. I thought at first this just makes it incredibly easy the more you have, but the numbers seem to scale up with the more people you have.I like the item seperation, don't know about the mana...it's convenient I guess.

number of helpful: 18 of 34 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												This was a massive let down. I bought it because I figgured "hey, for how much I played the original, I could get $6 worth out of it". I was wrong.One of the features listed is cross platform play. One of those platforms is Android. Basically this means you are playing an awkward phone version of Dungeon Defenders on your PC. The graphics took a noticable downgrade and everything feels a lot slower paced and clunkier. Not to mention the new interface manages to be even more awakward and unhelpful - I don't think I can see what a pet does without first equipping it and swapping into an entierly different menu.It's a shame too, because some of the new features ARE pretty interesting looking. Pets now have both passive and active abilities, and you can get amulets to give characters new active skills as well. But the overall performance hit, coupled up with being forced to play online in multiplayer (No solo play here. At all.) really ruins it.Second Edit : They patched in being able to host private games and play solo, but when you do you still seem to have to "wait for other players" for about half a minute before you can start the stage. The Tavern is still public though. They also let you download everything up front - and I did. Now I can say for sure that the graphics took a hit, they can't still be streaming in at this point.For a comparison, this is the original game : 


Dungeon Defenders 
A Screenshot of Dungeon Defenders
By: azamoth66




And this is DDE : 


Dungeon Defenders Eternity 
A Screenshot of Dungeon Defenders Eternity
By: azamoth66




Between the worse visuals and the slightly less responsive gameplay, I'd sooner recommend playing the original than I would recommend DDE.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Probably one of the best Tower Defense games on the market if not the best.Dungeon defenders Eternity is essentially a definitive version of the original dungeon defenders with most of the DLC included and new additions to boot. The game boasts redone combat mechanics, changing some of the different weapons to make them stronger or more balanced while still keeping every character useful at core. The main objective of this game is to defend the eternia crystals from the onslaught of hundreds to thousands of orcs. mages, goblins, ect. Each level feels fair for every class and keeps the original feel of the game even with the minor changes. The levels at an aesthetic level are beautiful and rich and the music is to die for.Honestly I cannot recommend this game more to anyone who is a fan of the original Dungeon Defenders.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Review as of Content Update 1:I feel this game has gotten a bad rap.  Yes, it is the original game rehashed, but that was made clear prior to release.  Yes, it has new features, but more or less it plays like the original.  As an owner of the base games of both, this is the one that I prefer.Graphics 7/10 - They choose a slightly different style for DDE and I personally liked the style of the original better.  The graphics don't seem as clear and crisp as the original.  They even have a warning about streaming textures....why can't I opt to download these?Sound 10/10 - This game has some ridiculously addictive music.  I've caught myself humming along with bits of it.  A family member who played it breifly said the same thing.  Some sound effects could use a little more oomph but that's about the only downside I could say.Gameplay 8/10 - I'd love to give this game a 10/10 here if not for one fact.  Load times.  Load times drag down the overall experience even when playing in a private lobby.  On the plus side, this game is FAR more accessable that it's predecesssor for finding gear for your characters.  Having the option of which stats that the game is comparing is a big deal for newbies especially.  The massive amounts of mana available on each map means your resources are not the limiting factor, it's more focused on your strategy.Developer Support 10/10 - Let's face it folks, this is the game they are supporting more at this date and time.  DDE has gotten a lot of bad reviews and most of the constructive criticisms have been addressed.  It has gone from what felt like a beta release to a full release over the last few months.  Their continued support and patches will make this into an even better title.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												Considering the popularity and quality of the first edition of Dungeon Defenders, I was surprised by the overwhelming number of negative reviews for what I'll call the *upgraded* Eternity edition. I should start by saying that my experience with the original was only about 2 hours playing the demo on Xbox 360. I was impressed but never got around to purchasing it. So I'm basically brand new to the franchise.My friends and I have been playing some Sacntum 2 recently (and loving it), so we decided to give DD Eternity a shot. We almost didn't purchase Eternity due to the large number of negative reviews, but after canvasing the complaints most of them could be categorized as follows:1) The UI is totally unintuitive (some say broken)2) There aren't enough new features added over the original to really consider this a new version3) It's online all the time4) No single player or private modesLet me address each of these:1) The UI is totally unintuitive - Yah this isn't the greatest UI in the world, but it does actually work. It just takes some getting used to. But it definitely isn't broken, just suffers a bit from poor design. I wouldn't make your buying decision on this characteristic alone.2) Not enough new features - I'm a totally new player to the franchise, so I can't speak to the evolution from the original to Eternity. But I can give my opinion on how I think the new version plays: It's fun as hell! There are quite a few classes to choose from each with their own flavor of play, tons and tons and tons of items, a variety of ways to build your characters, and the combat is smooth and easy to get used to after a few matches.3) It's online all the time - This is true. It really boils down to personal preference. You don't have to interact with any other players, you'll just see them in the Tavern (Dungeon Defenders equivalent of a Lobby). I'm not in the habit of playing with strangers, but the online only component doesn't really bother me. They have their own online platform they are developing called Playverse which is a bit convoluted when you are trying to get a group with your friends, but it still works. We've gotten used to other platforms where you essentially invite a friend with a single click, or accept an invitation with a single click. Playverse makes you have to do like three clicks the first time to accept a friend invite, after which the invites work much easier. 4) No single player or private modes - So this game came out about a month or so ago as of this writing. I have  a feeling that the game may have launched without single player/private modes, but has since been patched to allow it. Here's the bottom line: you can absolutely play single player or private mode with up to 4 of your friends. If it's just two of you in a private match it's totally fine - you won't get any strangers added to your game. I've played several matches solo and won handily, so the difficulty must scale with more players.Overall I would definitely recommend this game. It has a few rough edges, but these are things that can easily be improved with some patches going forward. The game is not broken as others are claiming. It plays beautifully and is a lot of fun to play either by yourself or with friends. After playing for a few hours now I felt obligated to come and write a positive review to offset the huge number of negative reviews.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												I'll give it a thumbs up. I owned Dungeon Defenders on Xbox, but never got the dlc seeing as the PC version looked a lot better. However, I didn't really ever have money I felt was worth putting towards getting it with all the DLC. This provides a really nice way to get all that at a cheaper price. The only major downsides are that it's online only (for this type of game, I'd really prefer the choice to go online or not), and that it's horribly lacking in explanation for new players. I already had an idea of what things were coming in, so it didn't affect me too much, but it was still annoying trying to refresh my memory on what the stat pictures were. Also, I actully liked the old system where mana was money. It was cool balancing greed and need.NOTES TO DEVELOPERS SHOULD THEY SEE:-Please for the love of god fix the issue where your cursor goes away on a menu page when someone walks behind it. When I'm comparing stats, I don't need the popup to disappear every 4 seconds.-GIVE ME MORE MANA FROM CHESTS IN SOLO. I understand you wanted to balance it around teams, since everyone gets their own chests. But 100 mana isn't enough for crap by yourself, making it neccessary to have a hero that can fight the waves, even if you want to build a pure tower character and watch the fight instead.EDIT: -They fixed the issue with the menus going away. This is fantastic. Thank you!-They give more mana when there are fewer players on the map now. Again, thank you!

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												After seeing a lot of the more negative reviews on here I was a bit wary about getting the game at all, but after giving it some time and patience I have to say it is nothing like as terrible as some have accused it of being. In fact it has brought me back to playing the previous version and enjoying both of them again.It does seem strange that in times when things change so fast people are so obstinate about anything being even slightly different; the reaction every time facebook makes a minimal change there is always some kind of uproar from the masses about how terrible it all it, the apocalypse is coming etc. The same seems to have happened here. There are certainly differences, and once you have got used to them the system actually works very well. Trendy have listened to all of the complaints and have made efforts to address them. There is now a single player mode that is easy to access, there are shortcuts in the item boxes for quick selling etc all of which are complaints that have been voiced over the last weeks (see below reviews)Loading time at the beginning if you have a slower connection is a bit of a pest, but once in everything is smooth, give it some time and have some patience it is worth it in the end.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												I read all of the bad reviews of Dungeon Defenders Eternity, then waited a few days and bought it anyway. We have two accounts at my house and have been playing two person games. Overall we are enjoying it very much but there is a lot of confusion. Some things that should be simple take an internet search to figure out. Because the game is new, there is not a lot of information on the internet. Simple things like inviting friends, creating a party, and hatching eggs are just different enough to cause problems. My biggest issue is initial load time. One computer may be ready to play almost immediately while the other wants to reload a lot of graphic files. So far it seems almost random one whether a computer want to reload graphic files. We have learned to start the game, then go gather our drinks and snacks while the graphics load, then come back to play the game. With a weekend of play we only had one instance where a party member was dropped as the dungeon was loading. No time warps as far as we can tell.Over all we had a lot of fun with the updated version of a favorite game. Everyone gets their own chests so building is faster and much more even. Experience is divided evenly among characters. No more worrying about the knight and mage towers giving most of the experience to those characters. I do wish that the inventory system was easier to use. There is still a lot of junk items to go through and sell. I need to experiment with the item filters in the Options menu and see if I can filter out the items without losing the income I get from selling them.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												This is identical to the base game with a few tweaks, and as far as I'm concerned it does the franchise perfect justice. All the things people are griping about have either been implemented, announced, or are just things people came up with for the sake of whining. No, currently there aren't achievements. Yes, it's because the playverse overlay is a WiP. Yes, they COULD have just stuck with steam, but no, thats not the end-all best option. The playverse overlay will be fine when it gets finished, and the negligible balance issues will be fixed in patches LIKE THEY ALWAYS ARE FOR EVERY GAME EVER. And no, there is no cash store in the game to pay2win. If you like, you can pay cash to get emotes for your characters. Purely aesthetic, not even remotely game-changing. If you like the original, then there's little to be upset with in Eternity. And all these guys crying about the 6 dollars they spent for basically an upgraded compilation of the original and all the dlc is just mind-boggling.

												I'm quite sad that this game has gotten so many bad reviews, its actually really good if you give it a try!The game is updated regulary, it's way more balanced compared to the first game where you could just take a LVL 1 character, hop on a nightmare crystalworld multiplayer game and boom you're LVL 70...In the first game it was easy to just upgrade gear into ridiculousness and instakill everything in your way.In this game most gear only go up to LVL 16 and as a LVL 45 apprentice i still have a weapon with +5 shots and 300Dmg.This game is a good challange, gear isnt so overpowered and the hero stats are more balanced too, where in the first game you had 300points on tower casting rate and it shoots out a line of projektiles and murder everything, In eternity you have 400Points and the towers are now good, but not nearly as op.The first game has it's pro's and cons, So do this.But i got this game because: ITS a new DD game! and that it includes all the DLC for way less money than if you buy it all for the original game.I can say that sure, you don't have to love it, or you think that it sucks compared to the original DD.But just like everything else, give it a GOOD FAIR CHANCE, and see it as a standalone, new game instead of a copy of the old one with "improvements"

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												I had a lot of hope for this game.  To date, I have 295 hours put into the original Dungeon Defenders.  It's one of my favorite games, so much so that I purchased a 4 pack for my friends during 2013 winter sale.  I saw Dungeon Defenders Eternity - revamped with new missions, unlockable loot for DD2 and on sale for $5.99.  I didn't hesitate...a poor choice on my part.  The game is now server based so that you are streaming from Trendy - security from cheaters, understandable.  But at this point the game is pretty much early access at best.  Long queue times, laggy servers.  I tried to play today and couldn't stay in for more than 5 minutes until a "your session has timed out....etc" error popped up.  At this point, until they fix the bugs the game is unplayable.It was $6, not a big deal to me.  I'd be more upset if I had shelled out the regular price of $19.99.  What really bothers me is if this is what is to come with DD2, I'm going to be really let down by Trendy.  Hopefully they can get their act together, fix the servers or completely rethink the way they have the "online only" play set up.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												While much of this game is the same as the first, there are a significant number of differences for me that make it worth getting, not the least of which is the level of Dev attention it is getting, which has fixed a number of starting problems, including many with the Summoner class (which stuck out for me as it is my class of choice).The inclusion of most of the DLC content (the holiday packs and such don't seem to have made it) is something that stands out for me, especially given the price. This also means most new players will likely go for the DDE over DD1 (dungeon defenders eternity/one). New levels have been made and more to come, including one in the campaign (so far, I have not made it too far as I have been enjoying the social aspect, and testing out the classes), pets now come from eggs that hatch simply by having them on your person and you never know what you will get.Also, gear now appears on your person in a physical way which is fun, especially when you get the full set of something. Mana is no longer the currency, coins are, which drop from creatures just like mana, and are used to upgrade your items. However you can no longer buy weapons or pets from the barkeep (as of yet). There IS an ingame cash shop, but the only thing in it is emotes for your characters at a dollar each. Dyes are also available now with the barkeep, as well as a new crafting system.For crafting, recipes drop from mobs, and materials seem to only drop from chests (though I could easily be wrong, i tend to get caught up in the action). You can choose to join your own private tavern, or a public one with other people milling about. There are even more new features that I could mention but I am sure you could find more complete lists out there.IN CONCLUSION:I find this game to be quite a bit more fun than the original right now given it is easier to join people of my own level, there is more details on the games I am joining, I can host private if I really want to and only invite my own friends, and it has stopped me being booted out for not having that one awesome piece of gear or whatever other reason people saw fit.The only downside I saw, no offline play, which I do hope comes later, but I understand why not if it doesn't.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Lots of negative reviews, so here is a positive one.  I have 100s of hours into the original DD and all of the DLC.  DD is one of my favorite Co-Op games.PROS:  DD Eternity is a nice refresh of the original.  I felt it had enough new stuff to offer to feel like a fairly fresh experience.  It's still the same game for the most part, but has a bit of a facelift.  There are a few new boards, tons of new gear, more gear sets, and special items that boost loot quality, stats and other things.  There is also a lot of new character cusomization.  I really like that all of the characters no longer look identical.  The biggest pro is they are continuing to update and add to the game, giving you more to look forward to.  Also, the issue with taverns not being private is fixed.  CONS:  IT's the same game. If you are looking for an ALL new experience, you won't get that here.  The game is very Internet-reliant.  if you have a poor connection, you will have issues.  The updates take a long time to download and apply.  The balance is a smidge off (The first few waves are easy, then oh-my-gosh!)   I'm not crazy about the Playverse interface, I much prefer Steam (though they are adding some Steam integration)  Most of the issues I have are minor quibbles.  If you enjoyed DD and haven't played in awhile, you will enjoy this game.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												Do you base a good review of a game on how many people are logged in to the game?Do you base a good review of a game on how similar it is to another game?Do you base a good review of a game on how often the developers update the game?Do you base a good review of a game on what they could of done with the game?Do you base a good review of a game on what others think of the game?Or do you base a good review of a game on what that game actually is?This game is fun, bottom line.  Even if nobody plays it anymore, it doesn't mean that it's not fun.  You can compare it with DD1.  And yeah, there are some similarities.  The maps, and the characters.  After all, it is the Definitive Version of the game.  But that's pretty much where the similarities stop.I'm like others when they say that they will defend this game till the end, because there's nothing wrong with it honestly.  This is the Definitive Version, and it is a little tougher than DD1.  You cannot just blow through it like an insane mad man like you could in DD1.I just want to point out a couple of really nice things they accomplished with making DDE.1)They made it more of a challenge.2)They made it cross-platform.3)They made it run on just about anything imaginable.4)They made it to where you cannot cheat (online of course) like you could in DD15)In some ways, they made it more fun.6)They made it to where you get all the DLCs that you have to pay for in DD1, in DDEI'd like to get all you naysayers out there, to really look at this game for what it is.  Not for how "DD1 is better than this" point of view.  I'll admit, DD1 does have some things that are better, like the private tavern, and the various level item drops.  But there are several things that DDE has that DD1 just didn't.And what I hope more people will do, is not trash one game because another that is like it is better, but instead, look at that game alone and figure why it is good, or why it is bad.  That may be a dying hope though, because most of you seem to be on the bandwagon and you may be riding it with too much pride. Heh

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Dungeon Defenders Eternity is basically a repackaging of the original Dungeon Defenders. They cleaned it up, balanced it, added visually appealing armor, heaps more armor sets(besides the leather, chain, plate and pristine that they used to have), and cleaned up the multiplayer to further prevent hacking or save editing. This game is worth the money, because it packages the best dlc and challenge maps together in one game so you don't have to download every dlc or shift through forums to find which are the best ones, all while offering itself to you for a lowered price. A lot of people complain about the game, but that is just them looking for some attention; People who complain about getting a more cleaned up version of a great game for 4 dollars.

content:

												TL;DR: Buy it if you haven't played Dungeon Defenders and you like ARPGs and Tower Defense.Although many people were disappointed with this game upon release, me included, this game is worth looking at. A lot of the disappointment had to do with promises that weren't quite delivered upon.Yet, upon revisiting this game, I find all the things that made the original Dungeon Defenders one of my favourite games of all time. Yet at a fraction of the cost. Sure it has problems, but this game is so diverse and puts in so many elements, of course it is going to be a mess. It is like Bethesda games: Open to play around with, tons of stuff to do, but similarly quite a few problems. If you want a game experience that is polished to the utmost and blanced, move on. If you don't mind a few uncomfortable edges and corners on a game that delivers tons of fun, jump right in.

												Dungeon Defenders Eternity may well be a remake of the original, but it's one hell of a good one. Ok, there are cons, no doubt about it, but when i play this game, i have just as much fun as i did on the original if not more! People say "but it's the same game, just better graphics?" or "Crap because you always have to be online." so what? you have internet else you wouldn't have steam? Besides, Trendy are fixing major issues with this game and any complaints given by the community. Trendy Entertainment are, in my opinion, working well with the community to find out what we like and what we don't like about the game and are changing these. I have played this game for many hours now and it really is fun, if you like RPG's/TD games, i would highly reccommend this.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												After playing this game for 1,5 months of chance I ust admit I've lost confidence in it. Let me summarize why: - intensive serverside lag issues to a degree that the server makes enemies do impossible moves, eventually causing you to loose matches.- So called balancing. Way to much of the abilities and defense units have are subpar towards the enemies. The few exceptions get nerfed so instead of a Tower/RPG hybrid they changed this game into a FPS clone.- Mistakes they made in the previous installment made again. In the previous game some loot was to powerfull so they made it far more difficult to obtain. Causing new players to never achieve the levels the first players got into. In this game they admitted some loot dropped that shouldn't have. They stopped the loot from appear and nerfed peoples loot to a degree that should have dropped with a boss who shouldn't be defeatable (people used a glitch to kill him cheap). But this gear still had stats you would find 1 in million in current drops. Now they added a new difficulty with monsters finetuned to those stats on gear. So people who played legitly have no chance of winning this causing another gap between players. It also confirms in this game only cheating gets you further in the game.- Very bad menu's. In the more difficult levels even one second not paying attention could cause you to loose the game. But any action in the menu's takes at least 5 seconds to animate. We don't live in the later 80's anymore where 256 colorsreens were high tech on a 286 model. Get your junk together and show me computers can calculate faster then humans can.- Poor fixing in "forgotten" content and disriminating people because of it: Some special gun gifted to you when you bought the game wasn't available in the first weeks. They fixed it so who buys the game now does get it. The only way for the players who bought the game earlier to get this gun is to create an account on their forums and PM the community managar there and hope he posts you a code to get the gun in game. No news post IN the game mentions this so any player who isn't active on the forum doesn't know about this and doesn't get the gun he should have gotten in the first place. If it was forum visiters only I'm ok with it but as newer players do get it now without touching the forums ever. It's downright discriminative.- Bad community. Those cheaters with their over the top gear are whining the game is to easy. And it seems the developers are listening to them.So after seein al that I can only see the game going down the never ending spiral of not letting any new player enjoy their game. as the excisting community is rotten I don't want to touch this piece of #### ever again. Can't wait for Dungeon Defenders 2 so I can give it negative points as well. As this team is not learning from their earlier mistakes,

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												dde is marketed as the "Definitive" DD experience. After having played thousands of hrs. of DD I had high hopes for dde. Sadly it is just too radical a departure from what captivated me in the original game. It is an action RPG tower defense game like the original that has the same char. with diff. abilities and balancing. Many of the mechanics and much of the gameplay style is changed for the sake of making the game play like what I'm assuming dd2 will be like instead of staying with the tried and true of what DD did right and fixing issues and refining what worked there. It is saved server side so it requires a constant internet connection as well and suffers from lag routinely due to this fact. Some like it due to the fact there is less a problem with hackers but for me it is not enough to make or keep me playing it I will stick to the original.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Even though it had a very shakey launch, DDE offers all the characters of DD1, new mechanics like amulets and pet skills, new maps and more at a much cheaper price then buying DD1 and all it's dlc. DDE has issues here and there and uses a 3rd party client called playverse (though it launches with the game and isn't really a problem just used for things like public pages for selling you items and better security vs the original DD). This game has issues sure. but I can still fully recommend it. DD1 was/is great game but had lots of hackers and most of the content was DLC locked. DDE offers a ton to do and great co-op. with monthly content updates (new maps, mecanics and more) and weekly patches (bug fixes and tweaks). The team and trendy is continueing to improve this game. Yes its worth it and unless you've got a stick up your bum and just want to hate on this because it's the in thing to do, Buy this!

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Game Review:Pros: Gameplay New system allows for a more rebalanced look at the classic dungeon defenders and grants old players that new player experience. While some feel that this is not true, I feel after playing DD1 for hours on end that this is in fact true. Keep in mind that the game does not allow you to transfer over a character from DD1, so you will have to start over at level 0. Each game you play presents the same thing you saw in DD1, chests, monsters, etc. However the chests are now for you only. What does this mean? Every player sees a chest and, lets just say that if another player tries to take it then they would just opened a chest that was for them specifically, you still have yours! Pretty cool... this means more mana than normal to start with, if you have enough players. Coins The game drops coins and mana now. Mana is used for upgrading towers and using special abilities like amulets, pets, and hero skills. Coins are used for upgrading armor and weapon pieces. This does provide a nice divide between the fighting environment and the tavern environment. Microtransactions Wait what? Why did I list this as a pro? Okay, so here's the deal. Trendy decided to setup any real money transactions that will allow people to buy emotes... and that's it. Good job on that one, I'm cool with this. If you need a little extra cash for emotes, I'll do that. Amulets New items have been added to help boost the gameplay. The amulets can do multiple types of abilities depending on which one of 4 you can bring into battle. Some of the abilities that you can choose are repair towers, weaken enemies, heal players, boost weapon damage, and so on. Blueprints Blueprints drop randomly throughout maps you play. You can use ingredients found in chests to then craft the item on the blueprint at the craftmaster found in the tavern. Some people say that this provides an overall better stats item, however, I did not notice this. But I will say you can save the blueprint and make multiple weapons or armor if you wish, which is cool if you want to have multiple pieces of the same armor because it has awesome tower stats! Inventory The new inventory system is much easier to use once you get through the challenges of learning how to manipulate the commands. For example "M" unlocks all items that are displayed, "A" sells all items that are displayed. I'm being specific in saying "that are displayed" because if they aren't displayed with your filter settings on, then you won't sell them on accident... huge bonus :) They also added folders just like the old game, however you have a bit more freedom with how many you can add. Oh yeah... did I mention 0/1000 slots? That's much better. DyesDyes are cool if you are into asthetics, however, I am not. But none-the-less this is an awesome feature for people who like to get off on detailed coloring of their armor pieces. The amount of detail that was added so you can completely customize the color scheme is, to me, a bit more than I care to do, especially since I'm swapping gear so often. Until the recent patch v3.2 you were unable to sell dye and it would stack in your inventory. Now it's been fixed. Pets Pets are different in this game than the original DD1. In this game you find eggs and you hatch them by putting them in your amulet slots and let them get exp while you fight. Once it notifies you that the egg is ready to hatch then you go into a forge and inspect the egg. There will be an option to hatch the egg and it will produce for you a random pet. Each pet has it's own passive ability as well as an activated ability, which is hotkeyed to "X". This system allows you to experiment and determine which pet you want for yourself rather than run a map over and over for, I dunno, something like a kobold?Colors While a lot of people complain about the color of the texture and say "it's blurry" etc, I want to let everyone know that the game does say "Please allow for images to stream because they may be blurry in the beginning", which was true. Once I allowed for the game to play for a while, the color system worked pretty well. There is a difference and after going back to DD1 to help a friend, I prefer the new DDE colors. Cons:   Trendy Overlay Menu The game no longer seems to be running through steam systems. When I attempt to go visit "who I've partied with recently" it no longer records them. In addition, the overlay menu that trendy uses is extremely difficult and in what appears to be a beta type version. Nothing is easy or smooth. To access the menu first press F11, completely out of the way and not as easy as Shift-Tab for Steam Overlay menu.  Party System If you want to party with your friends get ready for a challenge. If they are in the same tavern as you, awesome you are in luck! Press Esc and look for their name and "add to party", cool right? Okay what if they aren't one of the 16 players in the tavern? Sh!t.... ok go to Overlay menu F11, go to the second tab from the top, click right twice until you get to friends, click the dropdown on your friends name, click add to party and wait... did he add? Oh he's gotta accept.... ok he finally accepted. F11 to get back outta overlay menu. They could make it much more user friendly if they tried. Survival Maps Survival maps used to be in waves, 1 to 35 for tavern defense in DD1. NO LONGER IS THIS TRUE, this is pretty cool in my book. This does present a problem because now you are confined to 1 character through the entire survival, not cool;  sometimes we want to level our alts. In addition to this issue there is also an issue with mana in the beginning. Each player has their own chest as mentioned before, which would limit you as a single player trying to build for an entire survival because you cannot switch and build the build completely as you would in DD1. For example Endless Spires Survival, if I run it as a single player I get 375 total from all the chests, if I have 3 other players I would get 1500 mana for my build because players can pool mana like in DD1. So at the moment survival sucks because we HAVE to bring in other players in order to build the build we want. Kicking None. They don't have it in the game. If you wanna go in and afk 24/7 to get up to level 60, go for it. The only thing they have to prevent afking is a very long timer that attempts to sense if you are afk after something like 25 minutes of "not moving" which doesn't include being dead. So if someone is afk and keeps dying, well they get to be in the game the entire time. Stage Selection & LFGThe stage selection screen is quite nice, however it's just my personal opinion that the screen is larger than need be and not as concise in the information presented. The biggest drawback looking for a game to play with random people is that you cannot see all of the maps that are in play. If you haven't completed the stage, it won't show for you if others have space. This really limits the number of people who join your game, especially if you are doing end game content and need the help of others.Scanning your lootThere is an issue that causes the game to not hold the comparison window up of an equipped item and an item you are mousing over. This blip of disappearance is on-set by people joining the tavern, and taverns are public so this happens very often. Should I buy it?   The game has it's pro's and con's as you can see above. After being a fan of DD1 and coming to DDE I was originally seething with anger because of what I saw, however, now I can say that I really enjoy DDE more than DD1. You just gotta get in the game and play it a bit. It's worth it in the end and I support it, even with all it's terrors.
