content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												If I had to describe DDE in one word, it would be Disappointment.If my money has gone to make the game better in later updates, awesome, but what it feels like is everything that was good about the first game has been sucked out and replaced by things that might cash in on casual gamers like in-app purchases and novelty items.The interface... seriously poor form. Trendy.. you need to fire your UX and UI designers immediately. Even for a touchscreen interface it sucks, and it should have been ripped out for the PC version entirely. The icons are awful, the layout is clumsy and the overcrowding is just typical of terrible, terrible modern tablet based shovelware.There are definitely positives but gutting the local games in favour of heavily laden DRM based, nickle and diming microtransactions really, really turns me off continuing to play it and hoping it might get better.The worst part is no local co-op, the only reason my wife got into Dungeon Defenders in the first place...... oh but you could buy two copies of the game and play on two screens!?!Yeah, and I could also put a rusty nail through my scrotum too!

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												Failed all expectations. Somehow degraded in quality to the point that the UI is barely functional, the gameplay ramp-up is extraordinarily slow (especially when matchmaking, as team mates frequently sell your structures in favour of their own), a steep drop in framerate (from 80+ -> ~50), and it seems very much like multiplayer is an afterthought (an odd thought considering its multi-platform nature) with no ability to votekick abusive players, and no way to prevent others from sabotaging an otherwise positive multiplayer experience.Incredibly frustrating to play if you have played the first. Save your money, skip this version, and wait for DD2 for a quality experience based on DD1. I don't feel comfortable calling this a complete game in light of these glaring UX issues.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												If this is the way DDII is heading then I'm not optimistic about the future.  Always online and no single player; microtransaction store; horrible texture streaming (so you need to wait five minutes for the graphic fidelity to reach the level of the original game) and no capacity to import existing characters. They've made some tweaks and rebalances to the gameplay, but not to a noticeable extent. Perhaps this will find it's market on mobile devices, but for the PC it's inferior to the original in every way.About the only good thing I can say here is that it made me start playing the original Dungeon Defenders again.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												If your a fan of Dungeon Defenders and liked to play with random people but hated the hackers and cheaters then you will prolly enjoy this game. They have also included a number of new features and a overhauled UIHowever if you like to play solo or with just friends then i wouldnt not recommend this game. there is no offline mode at all. You can host private games and be alone (although i did have someone join my private games somehow) but even so you are at the mercy of their servers. Which at the moment of this review isnt great. Even in the tavern (the ingame lobby) i was getting rubber banding lag effects. Based simply on the fact that i like to play solo, i would not recommand this game to like-minded people.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I barely write reviews but I want to give in my 2 cent opinions since I have played both DD1 and DDE. Most are already listed in the other reviews.Pros : Starting over is pretty fun.New mapsAll characters unlocked.Skins provided.Tavern with other players! Can shout for party invites.Items now show! Stylists would love this feature.More item slots!Coins and consumables! Amulets to help you.Mystery eggs! Hatch them!Cons:Nightmare/Mixmode is not up.Hardcore I heard is permadeath, may be fun for daredevils but I'm already having trouble finding gears.Can't open your own shop or decorate your own tavern.Can only see games opened by people in your tavern.Can't see people selling items.Can't switch characters in survival to level yourself.Playverse gets confusing and seems pointless besides the party system. Should've just used steam to add buddies.Aquanos has a glitchy area where the wyverns or flying eels circle around and not enter map.Summoners now are just "DPS pet" users, something that I feel a hunter should be having. A strong pet.Summoner's archers stay slow and weak, can't even pass easy mode deeper well solo when starting.Not sure how some people are doing 5mil dps already with 3 full level 60's geared up on first week, later to find out it's from Palantir insane boss fight while being lied to about survival.ONE HUGE pet peeve is that, when you d/c from a private game. You can not rejoin it even if you are in the party with all 3.Over all it's fun but I'm hesitating to play because I can't find a nice game to join. Sometimes my tavern doesn't even have any Insane games. Should combine all the game rooms.

No steamlikeness at all. WHY DIDN'T THEY JUST USE THE STEAM OVERLAY, WHY CAN'T I JOIN MY FRIENDS BY JUST ALT+TAB'ing AND PRESSING "JOIN GAME". number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												My first experience almost made me want to rage quit the game. You click play and you're dumped into a tavern with 20 other people. WTF? Then I go look for a way to get my friends in. Eh... nope. Escape-menu? Nothing. After 20 minutes of Googling, I finally found that if either press F11 or go to a menu where you get a mouse cursor, and then click the icon in the top-right that looks like a ball of wool, you'll get a sidebar menu that looks worse than Games for Windows Live. Seriously, it's horrendous. But, this is the thing you have to use to add friends to your friends list (because you can't invite Steam friends straight into a game, like with Dungeon Defenders 1), and then you need to form a party using friends from your friends list. Only then can you start a game with your friends.The gameplay so far has redeemed the poor user experience with the friends list. All classes from DD1 are there, though they have been altered a bit. The summoner no longer has its own unit count, but shares defense points with the rest. You can still equip two pets like before. Pets also grant you a special ability, which you can activate with the X key and which has a short recharge timer. There are a few more gear slots and item sets are now clearly indicated. There are consumables which give you more options while you play, such as regeneration amulets or taunt-totems.Loot is now assigned to each player, like in Diablo III. This is also the case for mana from treasure chests. So everything you see on the ground, you can pick up!They introduced coins as a currency for in the shop and for upgrading items. I suppose this is to make a distinction between the stuff you use to build towers and what you use to enhance your characters. So far it feels right.TL;DR; Social features are messed up. Remember: open a menu (Escape or i) then ball of wool in the top-right corner. Besides that, it's a decent game that looks to be an improvement over DD1.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
Does many things right, does more things wrongI was a big fan of dungeon defenders on 360. I probably put 200+ hours into it, then I moved over onto the steam version for the DLC. Seeing this on the featured tab got me excited. I read some negative review and read some positive and decided to try it out for the $6 price tag.Here are some of the things I thought were cool features Launcher downloading the necessary files to play then downloading the rest while you playMost of the DD1 DLC already included for freeImproved online features, less item/level hackers and suchNeat amulets/consumables. Stuff like a "flash heal" object that would heal everyone around you but had 1 use There are more that I either missed or didn't remember to addNow for the things I really didn't like Always online DRMNo single player, only "Private Matches"Removal of 4 player split screenFrequent network delays. I have an internet package of 50down/15up, yet when playing a private match I frequently noticed lag/delays while playing. Attack that archer to stop his attack? nope. Dodge out of the way of that ogre's swing? nah. There was also common rubberbanding while moving. Not really enjoyable.Shared taverns. Ever wanted to have 14+ players running around in the tavern calling out, placing defenses/auras/etc around, constantly chatting back and forth with that annoying chat noise? No? Too bad. It's there and you can't get a solo tavern(as far as I know)Auto mantle. There is an option to disable it, but it doesn't disable it entirely. Frequently when fighting a mob I would accidentally touch one of my defenses and automatically try to jump over it...in the middle of combat. With the option enabled every little ledge/thing that would normally stop you but is low enough to jump over it, forces you to jump. Very annoying"Streamlined" UI. Maybe I just missed the option, but there's no "UI Scale" slider like there was in DD1. I found a lot of the text/numbers just too small and found myself leaning closer to my monitor just to read if that 3 was an 8 and such. There was also a lot of things that just seemed unnecessary and the UI often seemed cluttered.Removal of mana as currency and adding of gold coins. At first I thought this was a neat idea, but it seemed like I was getting less gc than I would mana originally. Oh well, it's not a huge issueRemoval of gear from the tavern shop? When I got back to the tavern after a game I went to the shop to find out that there wasn't any weapons/armor/pets in there for sale. After every match in DD1 me and my friends would check the shop to see if there was a good sword or pet or piece of armorALWAYS ONLINE DRM. Just to get into my first game I had to wait at the "Searching. Joining tavern" screen for about 5 minutes. About every minute of waiting I had to click the play button again to get the searching prompt pop up again just to have it close after a minute again. Then I got kicked off the game and had to wait...again. It's a really bad systemAll in all. I would say it's pretty neat but not really worth the buy. I'm glad I spent $6 not the full $20. If you were a fan of the original DD1 you will probably be disappointed if you can't get past some of the huge flaws. Who knows, though, maybe they'll fix it and in the future I'll be happy to have it in my collection.For the time being, though, don't waste your money.

Who knows, though, maybe they'll fix it and in the future I'll be happy to have it in my collection.For the time being, though, don't waste your money.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												This game appears to be a simple port from the mobile version of this game, rather than the advertised "remastering" of the original Dungeon Defender's game.  I had looked forward to the original game with additional features and perhaps upgraded performance, graphics, and perhaps additional gameplay modes.  Instead this game is a bonanza of microtransactions, public lobbies, horrific UI, with graphics at the same level, if not lower, than the original game.  This is not an early access, this was marketed and sold as a completed game, and sadly I was taken in with nostalgia for the original game.  I regret spending even the $6 to 'upgrade'.  I have spent a fair amount of money on early access, alpha, beta, and various other stages of games that just didn't pan out, but this purchase is the only one I regret wasting my money, and more importantly my time on.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												Did you like the original Dungeon Defenders game?Do you primarily use a desktop computer to game?If so, then steer clear of this shoddy re-release!Although the development team claims that this is primarily a PC game, the game itself claims otherwise. With shoddier controls, a forced always-online multiplayer tavern, mantdatory waiting period before starting a match (even a private match), and a new 'playverse' interface which feels optimized for touchscreens (likely because it was), this re-release seems to offer very little in the way of enhanced content over the original title.The good:-You can stream the game's levels as you need them-New item types & revamped stats-You can play the game on your iphone & your android & your pc & probably your OUYA tooThe bad:-Touchscreen interface is clunky when using a mouse or gamepad-Character management is horrid-Character skins were converted to items, cluttering your stash with needless junk-Always-online means you need 100% connectivity to play even singleplayer-80% of the options are gone, such as replaying a level without going back to the tavernFinal thoughts:Maybe this game will get better before release, but I doubt it. These issues are part of their cross-platform design experience.2/10, buy the original instead.EDIT: Changed my rating from 4/10 to 2/10 on my discovery that if you lose internet connection for even half a second, your session is terminated. In singleplayer. Yup.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												This game, as it currently stands sucks compaired to the Dungeon Defenders. When i first booted up the game I didnt have a choice of what i would like to do like in the original, it just loaded me into a tavern with like 10 other people. Being very confused as to how to switch to a squire instead of a monk which i spawned with i went to the shop keeper where i discovered one use items like potions and bombs and stuff along with a real money cash shop. In this cash shop you pay a dollar for character emote that only apply to one skin rather then all of them. After that disapointment i went to the vault where I found multiple things that confused me. Instead of having a some buttons that take you to your character info, bank, etc. it loads you to one menu that contains your bank, character info and character select at the bottom which sounds good untill you see that all of your character skins, pets, weapons, and armor are all mixed together in the bank area of the screen with no option to put things in separate folders like in the original, instead they give you two drop down menus that let you select a catagory of item out of the 12+ different types of items. Ex: Amulet, Mask, emotes, helmet, gloves, shield, weapon, shoulder pad, wrist gaurd. Then i went to the crystal to try to start a game and to my unhappyness I had to wait for other players... with no option to play solo or with one other person. There had to be 4 people in a game at all times. If someone left the spot would almost instantly be filled by another player. I did however learn that each player gets their own chests at spawn and you dont need to share but they only contained 20 mana each on the first level meaning you only will get 80 mana at start instead of the possable 160. Over all I think this game is designed for a phone, tablet or other mobile device not for PC or Mac

												Microtransactions have no place in paid games.  The fact that they're there leads me to believe that this game is set to go F2P in the future - after they've made as much as they can off sales.  I refuse to play this game until the cash shop has been removed.I was one of the silly people to buy this game when it was first released, belieiving that it was a finished product instead of the Early Access title that it really is.  When I was told of the microtransaction shop right after i bought it and all the severe game-breaking bugs in it, i was furious.Little or no response was given by the devs other than this being a test bench for Dungeon Defenders 2 (which I've been told it will be a F2P game) - yet all the information I've found on the next Nom Nom/Trendy game to come out has led me to a non-Dungeon Defenders game that looks like it's graphically and engine-wise identical.  It's a game called Monster Madness.I honestly feel I've been scammed.If you too feel this game should have been labeled and had and EARLY ACCESS warning to it, you should write Steam Support and ask for a refund.  If enough people do this, the game will get yanked until they get things fixed or an Early Access put on it and a warning that it has Microtransactions ingame.Look familiar?https://search.yahoo.com/search;_ylt=AuLfd33JnfzCsxph8UEsyimbvZx4

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												I have been a huge fan of Dungeon Defenders for a long time and have very fond memories progressing through the game playing with friends and solo. That being said Dungeon Defenders Eternity has turned my once loved go to game into disappointing waste of time. While Trendy has recently patched the game to include online single player it has clear balance issues when played as such to the point of my avoiding it completely. This has caused my motivation and excitement when I saw the release into a strong aversion and dislike of the game in general. While the original had its own problems in regards the inventory management and loot distribution/progression this game has taken a severe step away from fixing these problems. When using said inventory I feel as if I am trying to smash a square peg into a round hole and leaves me only with a bitter taste in my mouth as this should be one of the simplest tasks considering the clear focus on the new progression and loot system Trendy has recently made.Playing with my group of friends has now become a challenge and lesson in patience with the addition of playverse dedicated servers and the poor interface for inviting and creating a party. This interface should be a seamless and painless procedure but falls far short of the mark. Being forced to return to the shared tavern after every level instead of just continuing the play through of the campaign has me frustrated and confused as it takes away from experience and fun of the main story by a rather large margin. The shared tavern itself seems to be only a cost saving measure and serves only to create chaos as I attempt to manage my characters after a level. I find my screen flooded in spam from players leaving and joining said tavern while my senses are assaulted by other players firing wildly testing their DPS or checking out what some new item does on use. As you attempt to compare current gear with recent loot the tool tips frequently disappear by players joining and dropping from the tavern further adding to my frustration. The gameplay itself has remained largely unchanged aside from a pointless crafting system, texture pop in and balance issues. If you own the original there is little to no point in purchasing this new version and strongly suggest you avoid it until some large changes are made and maybe not even then. Hopefully Dungeon Defenders 2 won’t leave me with such a bitter experience.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												The original Dungeon Defenders is a complete game with tons of content, 4 player split screen co op, full controllers support, mod support that allows for removal of player cap and new levels. I can't help but look at Dungeon Defenders Eternity as a downgrade. I think the right way to look at this game is this. If you really want to play this game online get this version. If you would rather have a more complete game, get the original. There are a lot of upsides to this addition, but it comes at a price. It also does not run as smoothly, so if computer specs are an issue pick up the first one instead. While I would like to imagine they would fix things up and do right by their community, they seem to be charging forward forgetting what got them here in the first place. It is extremely important to improve upon your game without sacrificing what people liked about it.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												This really should have gone through a prerelease beta phase. For some reason, Trendy decided that it would be a great idea to rip out and try to replace the (quite functional and pleasant to use) existing UI from DD1 and replace it with this mess. I had to look up the manual to create a hero, the one thing you have to do before even getting into the tavern! And once you're there, it just gets worse. You're in a tavern with a zillion random people, with no way to get into one with the friends you want to play with.The old crystal customization is gone, and there's no way, as far as I can tell, to change your skin color, only hair and clothing. A few of the old seasonal and challenge missions didn't make it over, either.Overall, I'd recommend the original version, if you can get it on sale. It seems to have slightly better performance, and the features it has, like split-screen, are more interesting to me than what DDE has. If you like to play with randoms, though, DDE might be a better choice.

												I really loved the smarthphone version and the console version of this game. I actually went all the way to have characters level 78 in the console version and managed to get the platinium trophy.Yet this version has been a huge dissapointment, I really felt like I was being ripped off, the added content seems okay in the overall (I have a friend that has this game pc version, and there are many new cool features which are described on their website). Yet this game is SOOOOOOO BUGGGGYYYY. I have the mac version, I mean, I understand since most people are on PC then most of the support should go there... But if you'r going to release your game on a platform make it at least playable on that platform. This game is so laggy I feel I am living some kind of slow motion flashback... And i have a 2000€ mac that runs pretty much all I have ever tried, and a fiber optic internet connection.To resume my grinds with this game are:-Of course BUGs AND LAG for the mac version ( can't imagine the linux version; must be like playing in screenshots). I mean even the downloading tool crashed during download I had to re-run around 8-10 times... Mouse sensitivy cannot be adjusted directly so say good by to any decent fluidity... -Fake "offline mode", so far EVERY SINGLE TIME I have launched this game in "offline mode" the game just crashed systematically. This also happens sometimes normally when you are connected so i tried again and again... never worked...-I knew before buying this but I feel I should point out that half of the new heros are a fraud, they are just the same heroes as before but with different skins, actions skill, and a bit different stats, they are 4 copies of each of the original heroes, they have the same towers! For a tower defense game that was dissapointing The ther ones are different altough really not a revolution IMO.I would just say I did not enjoy playing this game, I rarely post negative reviews because usually my problems are that I don't like features in the game but I had never played a game this buggy. It feels like a game in early acces, and I played more stable early acces games... I really loved DD concept but here I feel I just wasted 20€.I don't recomend this game if you are a not a pc user.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												I loved DD1, I played it for hours and hours... when I heard of Eternity, I wanted to relive the love I had for DD1. However, this "new" game does help. If you have played DD1 before, all Eternity will do is leave a sour taste in your mouth.You don't have your own tavern, you have to click Play a few times before it will get you into the game, and then when you are in, you have to queue up to be able to play a map... they removed King's Game (my favorite map :( ), you can get kicked (Login session expired, srsly?), which can happen when you are on the second to last wave of a map. Party checks that require you wait 30 seconds before starting a game, the list goes on... I'm sure they'll improve it, as it is new as of July 22nd, but my suggestion is to wait.As you can see, I've played five hours, and got kicked twice. I wish I could have played longer, but microtransactions, and being unable to get into the game without being spammed with other players, just makes it painful.TL;DR Downgrade from DD1, do not buy.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Microtransactions have no place in paid games.  The fact that they're there leads me to believe that this game is set to go F2P in the future - after they've made as much as they can off sales.  I refuse to play this game until the cash shop has been removed.I was one of the silly people to buy this game when it was first released, belieiving that it was a finished product instead of the Early Access title that it really is.  When I was told of the microtransaction shop right after i bought it and all the severe game-breaking bugs in it, i was furious.Little or no response was given by the devs other than this being a test bench for Dungeon Defenders 2 (which I've been told it will be a F2P game) - yet all the information I've found on the next Nom Nom/Trendy game to come out has led me to a non-Dungeon Defenders game that looks like it's graphically and engine-wise identical.  It's a game called Monster Madness.I honestly feel I've been scammed.If you too feel this game should have been labeled and had and EARLY ACCESS warning to it, you should write Steam Support and ask for a refund.  If enough people do this, the game will get yanked until they get things fixed or an Early Access put on it and a warning that it has Microtransactions ingame.Look familiar?https://search.yahoo.com/search;_ylt=AuLfd33JnfzCsxph8UEsyimbvZx4

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												Did you like the original Dungeon Defenders game?Do you primarily use a desktop computer to game?If so, then steer clear of this shoddy re-release!Although the development team claims that this is primarily a PC game, the game itself claims otherwise. With shoddier controls, a forced always-online multiplayer tavern, mantdatory waiting period before starting a match (even a private match), and a new 'playverse' interface which feels optimized for touchscreens (likely because it was), this re-release seems to offer very little in the way of enhanced content over the original title.The good:-You can stream the game's levels as you need them-New item types & revamped stats-You can play the game on your iphone & your android & your pc & probably your OUYA tooThe bad:-Touchscreen interface is clunky when using a mouse or gamepad-Character management is horrid-Character skins were converted to items, cluttering your stash with needless junk-Always-online means you need 100% connectivity to play even singleplayer-80% of the options are gone, such as replaying a level without going back to the tavernFinal thoughts:Maybe this game will get better before release, but I doubt it. These issues are part of their cross-platform design experience.2/10, buy the original instead.EDIT: Changed my rating from 4/10 to 2/10 on my discovery that if you lose internet connection for even half a second, your session is terminated. In singleplayer. Yup.

number of helpful: 135 of 271 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												Reading the reviews and forum posts originally made me think "Wow i just wasted 5.99" but after actually giving the game a shot more then 5minutes or  just seeing up to the loading screen; Yes it pretty much is dungeon defenders minus some DLC maps and plus some unlocked costumes. However there are some interesting aspects to it, the pet hatching for one, and if your into cosmetics then of course the whole new armor changing appearence and dye system is a great feature. Other then that it's pretty much what they described, Dungeon Defenders with some tweaks while you wait for DD2.All in all, if your hardcore into dungeon defenders and spent billions of hours playing it, you might instinctively dislike this. But doesn't mean people should nerd rage all over it either just because you spent all that time, it has its merits for those who never really got into the first one for one reason or another, or just got tired of playing the original because of all the overpowered hacked and exploited characters.Final verdict. Not what i was hoping for, but at least I dont feel like i wasted money. If you give it an honest try without pre-judging it, then it's playable and thats all you can expect from the devs so cut them some slack.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												I was a big fan of original Dungeon Defenders. Played it too many hours. So I might say I know what I want from DD game.Let's keep this simple, DDE couldn't be done as an update to original game. There are too many changes. Most of all new online only. Old game was ridded by hackers. Financial side is awful. Mana was worth nothing in trading. Now with DDE, everything starts from beginning. Perhaps keeps hackers out for good.Now pros & cons:Pros-New loot, more sets and cosmetic changes-Full wipe, game really needed it-New maps, haven't yet tried many, still.-Pet hatching-Control over hotkeys. So good system now, you can remap num keys for different characters way you need/like.-New survival system. I have just scratched surface, tried Deeper Well at medium difficulty, survived about 20 minutes with level 14 character.-I don't mind the new inventory. Make folders ;) I personally made folders for armor, weapons, pets etc. Inside armors I made folders Old School and New School where I put old armor and new ones. -Maybe even more stuff I haven't yet tried or discovered :P-Always online, no more hackers.Cons-Always online. One thing that bugs me, we should get personal taverns. As I organise my inventory, almost everytime peep joins or leaves, dragged item drops.. And too much hazzle. Need some privacy :D-Possibility of downtimes on servers.-I'd like to have everything integrated at steam. Another account at Playverse.. Oh well, just have to live with it.I recommend this game upgrade for old and new players. For missing LAN support, what kind of LAN party is it if there's no good internet connection? :)

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												I have only played a small amount of this game compared to the 300+ hours I put into the original game but still easy to compare the two. I would recommend this game to anyone who doesn’t own the first one. The first question I asked when playing this game is it better than the original, I would say no it is not. They made some good improvements to the game but they left out of the things I liked about the old. The graphics are better and the game itself seems to run fairly smooth. I do like the fact that they made changes to the currency which a lot better than the mana crap from the first game. I'm still up in the air about the gear changes, while it’s nice to have my character appearance change with the gear, about 50% of the time gear looks really stupid when you have it all on. I wish they would just let me toggle the gear appearance on or off like other games instead of making buy items to make them invisible. I have never been a fan of having to connect online all the time to play a game. When it works it’s not a problem but I get a lot of random lag spikes in this game even when doing a private session, which I would never see in the first when hosting my own game. The whole time I play this game it makes me just want to go back and play the original, I want to like this game as much as the other one but just not as good. While this game does feel less slapped together as it did when it was released it still missing something, not sure what that is. Even with the problems I have with this game it still can be really fun, if you have never played the original this is a good game to get into the franchise.

												Played it for about four hours, I'd tell you hold off for now.  If you're one of those that purchased the original and are curious to what an alpha version of DD2 is, then you can satisfy your curiosity at a cost of your fast food breakfast.  Even with the rushed out single player, there is still more work to be done.  Trendy was very shady with this release.The game plays very much the same as its predecessor except no way to set up co-op between your friends outside of connecting to a public lobby to do so (as far as I am aware of this posting) which makes creating games that much more difficult.  If it is possible the current layout of the game is confusing and far from intuitive.  People that were used to controller play more than keyboard play will find themselves at a loss and trying to at least remap what they can do with their controller.  There's very little in the way of that support in this iteration which may perhaps be a sign for DD2.Disappointed that this isn't tagged alpha or early access.  This is in no way a finished product.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												If you have the original, steer clear of this one. Always-online DRM (seriously?) with their own overlay (Uh, hello? Steam? You know, that thing you're selling your game through?), no offline/LAN options whatsoever (there's "singleplayer" sure, but that's it), and literally unplayable without a constant internet connection.There are also a few costumes inexplicably missing from the original, which I'm assuming will be patched in later. Too little, too late.It's not even funny how much better the original version was just because of the fact that it did NOT have the always-online DRM/overlay... thing, proper singleplayer/LAN support (clicking "play" and being dropped into a lobby designed for 4 players with 20 other people in it is not my idea of "singleplayer", and if that's all I want to do, I should NEVER have to deal with that OR the online overlay/DRM thing). I can never stress this enough: Always-online DRM is NEVER a good thing. For anyone. The punchline? Pirates crack these games too. Some people even take it as a challenge, this one doesn't even really look particularly hard to crack, and coming from someone with zero programming knowledge that should say a lot.I think my last complaint would have to be that the original version pretty much had full support for everything this has to offer. They just decided to mislead their consumers to get more money on the way to the sequel. Wasn't the whole point of having offline saves and trendynet in the original that one would be secure? Well good job keeping that secure and showing support for it by just completely giving up and making an entirely new thing that might as well be Uplay or Origin. Granted, it's not THAT bad... Yet.There ARE a select few positives I didn't quite explore: Equipment is (allegedly) visible on your character when equipped. There's something like six new maps. The dedicated servers are (allegedly) more secure than the old trendynet (would it have been so hard to let people make a local copy of their trendynet saves and force a restart on that one after implementing actual security measures?), though there's also supposedly some noticeable latency, so all things considered... That's two positives, one iffy and a whole lot of terrible ideas and execution.

												DON'T BUY IT.....YETI will change my review when it is fixed but I am gonna give it a fortnight before i bother ltrying againThe new features are fun and the two new maps I have played so far are cool, but there are some serious design and installation issues;The install resets everytime you reopen the game and 90% of the time it fails to create a game session from the tavern (even a private game session). I have tried reinstalling and deleting my data several times with no luck.But when it does work, these design issues bring the game down; *A lack of a private tavern, which leads to a stuffed tavern where you have to climb over everyone else.*After EVERY game you have to go back to this tavern, and when you play a new match you have to wait 35 seconds for the   lobby countdown, even if you are on your own.*There is no restart button so if you botch a set up its back to the tavern and several minutes of loading.*The new inventory system is VERY confusing, why can't we just have the old one ?*The "Report a Bug" button crashes the game************THIS ISN'T A PROBLEM FOR ME PERSONALLY BUT EVERYONE SHOULD KNOW, YOU CANNOT USE OLD ITEMS OR CHARACTERS, EVERYTHING NEW FROM SCRATCH**********

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												As a big fan of the original run of the game I was curious to try this one out. (Hooray for cheap deals!) I was just utterly floored about this version once I got going with it. Playing solo is all fine and dandy but you only get 20 mana per chest! It forces you to rethink how you build things right out of the gate. The game itself chugs pretty harshly even with things turned way down. Not to mention the gameplay itself feels sluggish and slow. The tavern is such a cluster of stuff going on and generally lags even moreso! The biggest gripe I have is I always enjoyed going from mission to mission but now you have to go back to the tavern after each one.Stick with the original Dungeon Defenders, it's a faaaar superior version than this load. I hope to god Dungeon Defenders 2 isn't modeled after this version because I will not buy it.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												TL;DR: It's a new and overall great perspective on a familiar game many love, with it's issues, but it is an overall welcome addition to the Dungeon Defenders series.Longer review:I absolutely loved Dungeon Defenders 1. They got a lot of things right, and all into one accessible game. Now Dungeon Defenders Eternity came out, keeping in mind a lot of the issues that were in the original Dungeon Defenders.They have largely smashed the hacker issue, due to server-side items. This requires an online connection, and I'm more than happy with that in return for limiting hackers.They have have several notable changes to the class mechanics, some major, and some even controversial. In my view, the way to look at this is... this is not DD1. This is a familiar game, with a new perspective. Are the changes for the best? That's a matter of opinion. Personally, I find the changes refreshing.They added on several new game mechanics, and fixed some annoying issues from DD1. Did they get every change right? Probably not. But overall, this is a new take on DD1 that I find a new great twist to a familiar game, and worth the one-time price tag for a still awesome game that now comes with much of the previous DLC content right along with the base game.In the end, even with issues considered, I would certainly recommend this, what is in my opinion a wonderful game, to others.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												UPSIDES:Take everything good from the original Dungeon Defenders, scrape off the awful barnacles known as 'lag', 'hackers', and 'a totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t endgame', and re-release it for a fraction of the cost with all the DLC pre-added. Now slap on a ton of new gear and cosmetic options, a VASTLY improved economy, a ton of new powers and systems, and a better online play system than TrendyNet ever was. You've got a good idea what's going to come out of DDE then.DOWNSIDES:-- A new (optional) "streaming texture" system makes the game look pretty assy for a while after each patch, but it passes as the assets re-download. You can also just wait to launch the game until the patcher pre-loads all that stuff: Lose time in return for no streaming.-- The user interface is currently quite janky, but it's a work in progress, so give it some time.-- Due to the aforementioned hackers and TrendyNet issues, none of your progress or achievements will transfer from 1 to DDE, or from 1 to 2: Only from DDE to 2.OVERALL:Incredible value if you already have the original, and if not, this is a great time to get in.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												  I've seen way too many bull reviews, so here is a review with the information on BOTH sides. Hopefully this will actually help someone make the choice on if they want to get this or not. This review is admittedly mostly aimed at those that have played dungeon defenders in the past and are thinking about buying this one as well. As you have looked below, I'm sure you see the wall of text; don't worry, I will be putting bullet points at the end.[PROS/CHANGES]  Let me start off by saying I do really enjoy both dungeon defenders, and Dungeon Defenders Eternity. As for all the wonderfull changes that are made, there isn't a single one that I don't enjoy.  We have two stats replacing the skill stats, such as the joust for countess, as Ability Offensive and Ability Defensive. They act just like they sound, with Ability Offensive helping out the offensive skill if you have one, and defensive helping the other. These two stats do play into more, but I'll get to that later. The next new thing is that you no longer only have a helmet, chest plate, pants and gloves. Now you have all those, plus greaves, belts, masks, shields and each one of those items has stats associated with it, as well as actively change the way your character looks. A nice change to actually see your equipment change your character, besides just your weapon. There is also now a crafting system, where you can randomly come across blueprints for items from monsters. From chests you gain crafting materials, and you just take those and go talk to a shroomite on the 2nd floor of the tavern, and if you have the necessary materials you can make said item. The really nice thing about this is that you actually know the stats the items is going to have before it's made, but the bad thing is that I believe once you make it once, you'll have to get another one to make it again.       Another really nice thing that falls near the same catagory, is artifacts. From beating certain bosses and challenges, you obtain artifacts that you can use (you can only use that specific artifact on that specific character once, but are not limited to only one artifact used on that character,) to give a permanent bonus toward stats, such as tower attack. Some do have level requirements as well, such as a demon one requires your character to be level 15 in order to use it on it. There are also boosts you can get that are consumables that can increase the quality, quantity and rarity of items that drop on that stage. At least, until you're done with the stage, then it reverts to normal. That being said, getting a bunch of rare items with really good stats isn't something I can complain about.  The next really big change, is in a completely new catagory called "Active Items." These active items can be potions, bombs, distracting traps, eggs, and ability amulets. Yup, ability amulets, such as "Thunderstorm Amulet," that give you new spells to use. Remember those new stats I spoke of? Well, say your Thunderstorm does 70 damage every .33 seconds base. Not only does your offensive ability buff your Joust, or whatever base class ability you have, but it ALSO buffs the item abilities. So, instead of doing only 70 damage every .33 seconds, now you're doing 100 (70+30). That's just an example, mind you, so no real formula's were used. As for the eggs, it's a new way to gain pets. While your out slaughtering hapless orcs and whatnot, an egg can sometimes drop. All you do is put that egg in the active item slot, and wait until it get's enough xp to hatch. Doesn't seem to be too bad as far as the amount necessary. You already know the stats of the pet before it hatches, but not the type, so you can take an educated guess on if you want to hatch it or not. Speaking of types, pets now have a passive ability as well as active. Take a hawk, for example. It still has it's peck-like attack that does damage that it will regularly do, but it will also have a swoop active ability (On a 15 second cooldown,) that doesn't cost any mana that adds a bleed effect to anything hit by it.  Next up on the list is how things have been rebalanced, and the UI changed. If you place a turret down, say a ballista, you can still cursor over it and check it's stats - such as how much damage it does and fire rate. However, if you open your radial menu and select the tower out of that, then it will actually show you information such as the ballista's base stats, and how much YOUR stats add. It also gives you information on if certain stats, like tower speed, will affect it or not. Kinda neat, and somewhat helpeful! On the topic of rebalancing, I don't have any direct examples, but I can definitely say that after 712 hours or so of Dungeon Defenders this one definitely feels more fluid and even. Another neat thing is the dodge mechanic. You get 4 charges that replenish quite quickly, assuming you don't use them one after the other, and it gives you a horizontal leap in whatever direction your moving in. This is great for avoiding projectiles, jumping ledges, getting around the map faster or dodging that assassin that just jumped over you and is about to eviscerate your head.All in all, lots of really, really nice changes in my opinion.[CONS]   Nothing is perfect, and dungeon defenders eternity is no exception. The game does suffer currently from some nasty bugs, some of which I've noticed particularly with Summoner. I've had orcs moonwalk through walls off the level and dissapear. I've had ogres decide they don't like where they are and relocate to a different spot, or go suicide in pits. I've had the kobold lit fuse running at you about to explode sound looped on my headset until the round was over, even though the last kobold had died a while ago. I have teleported to my cursor's position while selecting something from the radial menu three times, though I have been unable to purposefully recreate it.  There is a ... cash shop... shudder... I place this under cons because it invites the "Pay to win" aspect in games. No better example then the original Diablo 3. Thankfully, as of right now, all it contains is Emotes so hopefully their plan is to only sell cosmetic items through it. If that is the case, then I can remove this off [CONS] and place it in a [MEH] slot. As of right now, the tavernmaster pretty much only sells those emotes for cash, and some dyes, dye removal and respec potions so he's pretty much unnecessary at the moment which makes me kind of sad.     While the thought of  having to start completely over from scratch does not personally annoy me or anything, I understand why it does others. It especially hurts if you played 100% legitimately, but still... It's understandable, to me, due to all the other changes. Once again though, I do miss my stuff and I know that others do as well, so leaving it here under cons.[  -----THIS IS THE BIG HITTER----         You have to be online to play it, since you have to be logged into their trendynet servers. Even if you're playing solo, just like Diablo 3, you have to be connected. Also, the tavern is now a... well... tavern...  You no longer have a private tavern all to yourself, as now it is a hub for all players. The bright side is you get to see lots of people running around doing stuff, but the bad side is that you're constantly being spammed by "SUCH AND SUCH HAS JOINED," and "SUCH AND SUCH AS LEFT." This wouldn't be so bad, except it plays that same noise as when someone would join your tavern in the original every single time, and also removes the tooltip if you're, for example, trying to compare two pieces of loot. When I have tried to figure out if I wanted to equip something, I've had to jump into a game just to keep it straight so I could actually compare them.  [      You CAN still host solo/private games, but have to wait 40 seconds for "players to join." Not too bad, but if you fail the map, there's no retry button so you have to wait again.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												I own the original Dungeon Defenders and saw very little reason to purchase this game.  However, the Linux client for the original Dungeon Defenders is full of bugs and Trendy seems to have no intention of fixing them.  Meanwhile, the Windows version, while exhibiting a bug or two, is far more stable and contains fewer obvious problems.  Since I read that this game was web based and Trendy advertises that it supported Linux right out of the gate, I figured that even if there were problems, all platforms would be on the same footing.  Boy, was I wrong.I can't say that on Linux there are some strange effects, or that this class' towers don't work correctly, or that performance is poor.  I can't say that because the Linux client WON'T START AT ALL!  THE CLIENT JUST CRASHES!  I CAN'T EVEN PLAY THE GAME!I've gone through forum post after forum post, looking for a solution or maybe that  it just doesn't work on my distro (Fedora 20).  But it turns out the problem doesn't not appear to be distro specific.  The client just doesn't work on any Linux distro.  What's worse is that Trendy appears to know this but still lists the game as being available for Linux.Now you might think I'm just a flamer and that if what I've said here is true then there would be far more negative reviews by Linux gamers.  Here's the catch (and I hope you're sitting down for this one):VALVE WILL NOT LET YOU POST A REVIEW UNLESS YOU'VE PLAYED THE GAME FOR AT LEAST 5 MINUTES!!!!!!!!!!!!!Not the easiest thing to do if the game won't run for more than a second.  What I had to do was install Steam on a Windows system, login, install the game on that system, then let it run for 5+ minutes.  All just so I would be allowed to post this review!  I was so disgusted, I didn't even actually play the game on Windows.  I just let the launcher sit there.Now I understand Valve's point of view, trying to slow down trolls as best they can.  However, in this case, they have to know by now that there is a major problem with the Linux client to this game.  Yet they still allow the game to be listed as "Available on Linux".  That makes them partially negligent in allowing this fraud to continue.Since I can't get my money back for this game, I'll give any reader patient enough to read to the end of my rant this advice:  Don't give Trendy a dime of your money for this POS until they get their act together and actually deliver what they promised!************** UPDATE 10/10/2014 *****************It looks like they've made some updates to the Linux client.  You have 4 options to launch now (not sure what they all mean).  The options are "Play Dungeon Defenders Eternity", "Link Steam Libraries", "Unlink Steam Libraries", "Play Offline".  For me they all do the same thing.  The application tries to launch and exits.  I get a flash of a window, but it's disappears so quickly I can't see anything to give me a useful hint as to what's going on.Trendy (or whomever is developing this now), you guys suck!!!

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												Finally Trendy fixes all the issues with the original Dungeon Defenders and adds in cross platform support.  New levels, with all the best levels and campaign missions from the first one, tied together in perfect harmony.  Hackers are gone, kick-abuse is gone, which were the reasons that most people stopped playing the first game.  It's true that this support should have just been added to the original, and I'm not sure the reasons behind why it wasn't, but for the introductory price it was hard to say no.  Playverse isn't the best online platform support but neither was steam when it first came out, and I have faith Trendy will fix it up in no time.  Plus PV makes it super easy for friends to join in your game by prompting them to accept/decline games you're hosting and automatically placing you into the same party system you've used before.  It's like if XBOX live auto added you to party chat with your friends that were online and auto joined their games when you turned on your xbox, it's that easy.  For $6 (introductory price + DD owners discount) these improvements is a definite recommend.  I ended up buying a 2nd copy for the wife's account to play co-op.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												As someone who didnt really play the origional DD much but saw it was cheap, I picked up the game for like £5 on some super special offer. I have enjoyed the game thus far but have mostly played with 2 or more friends from other games. It is very addictive and almost everything but the character emotes are free. Honestly it's a game that if you have friends to play it with and like a more interactive tower defence game then you should definitely play this. I would recommend once you buy it and DL it, load it up and let it download all the maps before you play. This prevents any issues when loading maps and minimizes bugs.It's true, this does seem like their BETA test for a Dungeon Defenders 2, making Eternity more like a 1.5 version that the makers can milk ££ out of...and I am completely fine with that. I would rather buy this game cheap while it's buggy and report the bugs than DD2 which will hopefully be awesome be this precarious. The ingame UI needs a LOT of work, and I mean a lot. I didn't find it user friendly but this is hopefully something being worked on. Notably the UI does allow access to Twitch for easy streaming - like streaming a BETA. Oh, I see what you did there game makers. *wink wink*.A mixed bag from me, but I'm still gonna keep playing. If they release nightmare mode or boost the lvl cap from 60 i'll probably play more. I also like what they've done to survival mode making it a 1:00:00 hour constant defence where you don't have to AFK for 12 hours until good loot starts to drop :D!

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												Played the original for several hours on PC and probably more than that from my time on the Xbox 360 before it.  If you want to play everything you didn't get to in the original or are an old player that found yourself annoyed at players having hacked gear in random lobbies, then this will probably be for you. Sure there has been changes to how the game used to play, but it's more or less the same experience.For anyone new to the game, there's endless fun to be had with all the classes now available immediately and that a good majority of people playing have had time in the original, so you're likely to find veteran help while playing through the game too. If you've got a few friends who might want to play as well, that'll make progressing even better, especially if you intend to go for the higher difficulties and want to gear yourselves out.Also to keep in mind is that as you're playing this again or are just jumping into it, this will get you prepped for Dungeon Defenders 2. Certain things you complete here will supposedly be put toward that game as well, if you liked DD/DDE enough to warrant a purchase of that.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												Spite the terrible reviews this game has so far, they really put some time in with this. The gameplay is the same as the first with most of the bugs from the first fixed. All of the classes feel more balanced than before and the loot and item system has been revamped to feel more powerful right from level 1. Crafting sets is even more rewarding than the first and if you are willing to spend some hours getting good, you can challenge the much improved difficulty levels! I give it 4/5 stars.

												I definetely recommend this game, it started off on rocky foundation and plummeted, and there is no denying that fact; however for anyone not grinding the end game content it is a lot of fun, and honestly at this point there is little dirrection besides up. With the newest patch (3.6) out and adding the ability to sell and change characters during survival matches, it seems Trendy is takinga step in the RIGHT direction, not the wrong direction.Nerfs are kind of commonplace as they are getting the game "Balanced", but I feel they are necessary to prevent the INSANE scaling that came with Nightmare mode last time. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												Complete copy/paste of the original, with very few features added and more taken away. It appears to be an Android port that hardly lives up to the depth and quality of the first game. Several bugs and missing features as of release, to name a few:-No Nightmare mode.-No Hardcore mode.-No Mixed mode.-Miscoded item/item levels that have been retroactively nerfed and players not appropriately compensated-New survival mode, 1 hour of endless waves, no character swapping, extremely poor loot, disappearing items issues worse than DD1.-Desynch/lag issues.-Required Playverse launcher.-No single player/offline mode.-No Private Tavern.-Microtransaction Market added.*-Many players losing characters/loot entirely.If you want the real Dungeon Defenders experience, I strongly recommend trying the original, and avoid trading/using the hacked items that have spread like wildfire (single player would be ideal). This "game" is hardly worth $5.00 and should be marked as an Early Access/Alpha title or pulled from Steam. Falsely advertised and horribly unpolished

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												This is the first time I've ever reviewed a game, but I felt compelled to due to the blatantly false advertising for this one.  Far from the definitive version advertised, this is just a money grab.  A rebalanced endgame?  Endgame difficulty is currently dissabled with no eta on when it might be implemented.  Hardcore mode and Mix mode from DD1?  Disabled with no eta.  Remember running survivals in DD1 and running around at the end to see what gear dropped?  Well in DDE monsters drop 1g coins in addition to loot.  There is a 400 item limit for how many things can be on the ground, and coins take up most of this limit, resulting in most of the loot despawning whithin moments of dropping.  No eta on when this might be fixed.  The developers from Nom Nom Games (thats right, this isn't being produced by the same people that created DD1, it's just being marketed by them) are making all the same mistakes they the Trendy developers made in DD1 and the community is suffering from whiplash while the devs flail around trying to fix their mistakes.  This is essentially a beta to test the playverse archetecture for Dungeon Defenders 2.  If you never played DD1, you might enjoy it.  If you played through nightmare mode in DD1, spend your money elsewhere.

number of helpful: 51 of 104 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												This game is like a Director's Cut or Definitive Edition of the original Dungeon Defenders.  It takes everything that was great about Dungeon Defenders and adds new features such as consumable items, permanent enhancements and reusable amulets.  There are several new maps and challenges, including what appears to be the start of a new campaign.The Tavern has been converted to an open lobby with a personal trophy room at the back.  Survival Mode has been modified from the original 3-5 hour binge to a 1 hour timed single wave survival and the loot curve has been balanced for proper advancement.  Players will also find that all loot and chests are player instanced so you can loot all you want.In the original Dungeon Defenders, mana was used to summon traps/towers and level up weapons.  A few changes to this system make it more friendly.  Mana is now only used to summon traps and towers.  Weapons are leveled using gold coins and pets have their own separate experience pool.I would recommend that you buy this if you enjoyed the original Dungeon Defenders and are still interested in playing. If you have already burnt out of the original Dungeon Defenders this game will not offer much to keep your interest since the innovations added do not offset the lack of new content.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												It seems this bears reiteration upon reiteration:Disregard the majority (though never all) of the negative reviews and sentiments for Dungeon Defenders Eternity. The vast majority are based upon misunderstandings, misconceptions or factual errors, and are therefore inapplicable to the actual product.Dungeon Defenders Eternity is NOT:* A mobile port. It is based completely on Dungeon Defenders, with added code and assets. From whence this idea comes, I know not, as there is NOTHING to suggest mobile roots.* Laden with IAP. The in-game shop ONLY sells cosmetic items, a standard not only of the genre (in as far as DD can be categorized), but a new paradigm for the games industry as a whole. And it is one of the most harmless and fair ways for developers to increase their profits (which is often not about quick cash grabs, but about staying in business and making new games, especially for indie developers).* Visually downgraded. This fallacy is based on the new streaming texture mechanics, where textures are streamed upon first launch, thus allowing players to get into the game faster. That this would make 50+ reviewers believe that there has been a graphical downgrade only shows that customers will jump to conclusions within SECONDS, and never challenge the legitimacy of their own preconceptions, or double check their initial findings. I first launched Eternity on a 1 MBIT/S TETHERED SMARTPHONE CONNECTION, and the textures for the tavern loaded within one minute. * More demanding than the original edition. The two Steam apps put almost the exact same strain on my processor, GPU, etc.Dungeon Defenders Eternity IS:* Significantly improved. The list of new features include manual dodging, a whole crafting system, consumables and spell amulets that provide entirely new powers in battle, pets that can be hatched and trained to fight with their own abilities in battle, visual armor upgrades, and a true hardcore mode.* FINALLY hacker-safe. Hacked characters made the original almost entirely unplayable for anyone hoping for balance and even matches, as so many players had over-levelled or over-equipped hacked characters. (This is one of the primary arguments for always-online requirements for games with multiplayer modes, and proven very succintly in this case.)* Rebalanced.* Endowed with an entirely new loot system, as this was an oft-critizied part of the original.* Equipped for true cross-platform play. Progress is already shared with the Android Tegra version, and iOS will receive the same later this year.* Not designed to siphon money of old players, as all of us who own the original are offered to buy DDE for 5 euros.* Linked to the upcoming sequel, with unlockables that will be available in Dungeon Defenders 2.So, is this a good game? That depends on your sentiments regarding the original. An improvement? Oh, yes, in nearly every single way. The ultimate version of Dungeon Defenders 1? Very, very nearly so.Could Trendy have launched this new version more smoothly and predicted some of this confusion and irritation? Probably (though after looking at the Steam store description and new page for the game, I find it hard to see any room for significant misunderstanding, or most of the misconceptions that surround the launch).A worthy purchase? If you are a fan of the original, definitively. If you’ve never played Dungeon Defenders? Oh, gawds, yes!

number of helpful: 32 of 66 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												I personally like the game, but like others, are a bit jaded on the details of what is new or included. I'll break it down best I can.  The game is basicly a GotY edition of Dungeon Defenders, including the DLCs from the original, but also including changes and new levels.New, but not really listedMatchmaking - You share one tavern.  I assume it has a cap, so there are several taverns.  To those who never played the base game, the tavern is where you prep before going into a game, sell items, and can goof off.You will be paired with like, leveled people.  You still get to choose what level and difficulty you choose to play on.Loot Drops per Character - Your item drops in a game are yours.  You don't have to worry about someone taking an upgrade because of the matchmaking.Streaming Client - Yes the game looks bad when you first load, as many reviews have said.  This is due to the game streaming textures and whatnot the first time you need them.  It only downloads once.  That's why the download for the game through steam is quite small.What might annoyMicrotransaction - Everyones favorite thing to hate.  Currently (June 22, 2014), the game only has emotes as microtransaction items.  A bit overpriced, but they are cosmetic only.No Tutorial - It just dumps you into a lobby, the tavern.  No character creation, no explaination of controls.  Ask in chat and someone will probably gladly point you in the right direction.Playerverse instead of Steamworks - They decided to use their own matchmaking system, with its own friends list, party making and trade system.  The reason probably stems from cross-platform play with phones/tablets.  This can be seen as a good thing if you plan to play on your phone or tablet as well.No private game - This shortcoming is already being fixed tonight; seems like an oversight by them.  I think they were hoping to have a bustling matchmaking system, instead of a bunch of private games.No character transfer - You'll be starting at level 1 again.Things I like so farTweaked Play - Pets now have abilities you can activate.  You'll find pet eggs you can hatch.  And there are items you can use in combat, like health potions and bombs, as well as buffs.  Also they added a dodge ability.Despite my short list of what I liked, I really enjoyed the original, and look forward to leveling up and seeing how the end-game has changed.  For people who haven't played the original, this is the version to get.  If you have the original and are debating getting this one for the discounted price, look at the things I highlighted.  Comment on this review if you have questions or want clarity.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												This review in a nutshell: Singleplayer was added, games now 500x better. Dont believe me?You should. All the negative reviews on this page are before they added singleplayer in.When you first log in, I will admit, its nuts. Have you ever been to a spawn town in a busy MMO, or gone to New York? Thats it. The tavern is a hub that EVERYONE uses. So, sometimes crazyness happens. But don't you worry, little girl, this is the only time your little loner side has to show like a sore thumb. Ignore the people. Go join A PRIVATE GAME. Dont join a public game if you dont want to join muilitplayer. BOOM! Your alone!The gameplay hasn't really changed, other than you now get less mana. Or so it first seems... in singleplayer this doesn't really matter, but in muilitplayer, people used to NOT share chest, and made it so people couldn't even do anything because there was no mana to go around. They changed it so every player can open every chest. So, 3 people can touch the same chest and it wont go away for the forth person. So, every player gets the same amount of mana. Otherwise, in singleplayer, this change sucks, because your getting less mana.The games pretty. Nuff said.They added some new missons to the main campain. It will feel a bit fresh to older players.The GUI, is uh... really, well ugly, acually. Its new. Does it feel rushed? Completely, acually. Its not something you can't get used to, mine you, but its odd.Coustumes are now items, so only 1 person can wear them. Yea, it kinda sucks. You can see your armor though, so who knows what you'll look like in the end anyway.2nd to last, the crafting system. Cool! At the time of this review I couldnt test it out, but I'm sure that i lets you dupe items for crafting ingredents you find on quests.Finally, the shop system. Lots of people don't like the whole spending real money thing, but its only for cosmetics, so its okay. The new system goes like this. Instead of using mana, it uses coins, witch is found the same way mana is. Its a bit more rare, but you wont cry because you only got 5 peices in a run. The money can buy lots of new items that are consumed on use. These items do a varying amount of things, but an example is a mana collector. Place this bad boy down, and collects mana for you? Easy! Nice! Theres also mana potions, health potions, bombs, lots of awesome stuff.So, yea buy this game. If you havn't bought dungeon defenders go buy this. Its worth it. If you have bought dungeon defenders, its up to you. Its a plunge your gonna have to take, but the new changes and others things I didnt take about in this review, You might be happy. Remember that you have a big discount because of you owning the game already.Remember though, I'm a dude on the internet. I like DD a lot. I bought this game (before singleplayer) knowning it was bad. I bought it anyway, because I love DD. I'm not gonna make you use your wallet. (If you have it anymore after the steam summer sales!)Oh, and all DLC carrys over. Nice!If I write anything else, I'll start writing a novel. You get the idea. Check out more reviews, NOT THE ONES BEFORE SINGLEPLAYER, before you spent your money.

number of helpful: 28 of 58 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												There is very little wrong with this game. It looks and feels like the original version, and the control and responsiveness are fine. They will feel clunky because you're going to play with a slow character for the first time in years.The public taverns are utterly painless, and remove the hassle of closing your game every time you want to look at your inventory. Nor will you need to politely decline the companionship of players 5 times your level while they hop around on the bar.Everything else seems pretty much the same to me, though I don't doubt that those of you who've put in hundreds of hours will find changes to the math you'll find pleasing or not so pleasing. The biggest change I see is that you won't need to derp around the game listing, wondering if you belong within the weird level range of the various games that have been running for heaven knows how long. You quite literally press go and get dropped into a game seconds later with people around your level. It's honestly pretty nice.As a side note, the numbers on the negative reviews here paint a picture of an angry little brigade putting in an hour or less before writing the game off on bugaboo grounds. There are serious reasons to find fault with this game - there always have been - but they certainly aren't in play here. These people are upset about specific disagreements they have with the direction the franchise has taken, NOT with the actual quality of the game.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												It's DD1, with a few changes.  I played (according to Steam) 831 hours of DD1.  So I'd say I'm pretty familiar with it.  This is basically the same game with some tweaks.I don't like the lack of offline mode, but I understand the reasoning.  It really is the only way to prevent cheating.I do like the pets-from-eggs (and they seem to be a lot more common) and that pets have quality levels.  I haven't done any crafting, but I'm looking forward to that.  Hardcore/permadeath is an interesting way to add a little spice to existing levels, as well as provide better loot in them.  Being able to play from a browser is nice, for those times when you aren't at your gaming rig.  Cross-platform play is nice, too.  It means I can play on my nVidia Shield or my PC or my fiancee's old Macbook.  (To be fair, I probably could have Steam-streamed it anyhow to those, but not while someone was using the PC.)I'll be looking forward to some UI improvements, though.  Inventory management is a pain.  Especially for comparing equipment.Overall, I like it.  Especially with the discount for owners of the original.

												So there are plenty of negative reviews on how terrible this game is, where about 70% of the reviewers have around half an hour played. The game isn't any where near as bad as everyone says it is, and if you enjoyed the original game, you'll enjoy this one. The cash shop only sells $1 emotes and nothing else (at least as far as I have seen) and the servers were fine for the few hours I played yesterday. The game's a great buy if you loved the original but didn't buy all the DLC as it all comes included in this game, and while it might be a harder sell point for someone who already bought all the DLC, the few new features the game offers, and the promise of no hackers, is a decent reason to pick this version up, and if those don't sound like good enough reasons, then stick to the original.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												The Good:- Visible armor- Active abilities for pets- New abilities (for all classes) through an amulet mechanic- Dodging mechanics- Crafting mechanics (haven't really gotten into this yet; might be♥♥♥♥♥♥- Pretty much the complete package of DD for a lower price than the original complete edition- Balanced item pick ups / general progression- New contentThe Bad:- Always online- Taverns are public (read: you load in to taverns with other players)- A second overlay/service with login needed (I really hate this for Steam games)- The new UI is clunky as all hell- Postprocessing somehow looks worse than the original (everything looks a bit "greasy") (the tavern seems to be the worst looking with actual maps looking slightly better) (easy fix by turning post-processing off, but I really don't understand how anyone looked at the effects and gave it an "OK!")- Seems to be missing a few levels/costume dlcs from the original (I'm afraid they might reintroduce this as microtransactions)- There's really no transparency from the developers of what exactly was added (or will be added in the future).  The Steam page comes off a little dishonest.There's plenty of strange decisions for this release; but for $6, I can easily recommend it if any of the new features interest you.  Otherwise?  Maybe stay away. But, I can't say I really regret my purchase; nothing is completely experience-ruining.  If anything, it's nice to have a "new" experience with Dungeon Defenders after all these years.  The only thing that concerns me is that they might just be testing the waters for ♥♥♥♥ing over the fanbase more at a later time.
