content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Don't care about the bad reviews that people with literally 0.2 hour playtime. I will provide you with a proper review for the game.I have no idea why this game is getting so many negative reviews. In this review I want to go over some of the things that they changed about the game.Before I start, this game is basicly Dungeon Defenders 1, with new content, and a lot of fixes.New Content Cash shop The cash shop is getting a lot of hate by a lot of the reviewers. They are saying that it makes the game developers look greedy, and that they only care about money. This is false. The only thing you can buy in the cash shop, is taunts. You can buy taunts for $1 each, and there is a total of 34 taunts you can buy. It does not give you any benefits in the game, but it does make you very cool looking. The pause menuThey have made a new pause menu for the game, which does not only look amazing, but it is amazing as well. You can now change your options in game, without having to close, and re open the game. You can once again inspect players (look at their gear and stats), you can add randoms to your party without having to add them on steam, and you can report players for different reasons, like cheating, offensive username, language and profile picture. The tavernThey are using the same tavern as in the last game, but you are now sharing  the tavern with other players. This makes it possible for you to just sit in the tavern, and chat, make new friends, trade with randoms etc. It makes a community out of the game. Story mode, challenges, and just maps in general.They are using basicly all (and some new ones) maps form DD1, but they have made it so you have to complete them in order to be able to play them. This makes it so you can no longer but the game, and instantly lvl up to the max lvl. You have to work for your lvl, and you have to work for your gear. This makes it more funt o play with friends. Pets, armor, weapons.You can now see parts of the armor you are wearing, which is really cool. All the armor pieces does not look the same, like it does in the original game, and you no longer get armor with just +1 stats if you play on easy mode. This makes it way more balanced.For the pets, I think they have made a huge improvement. They have made it so all lvl 1 pets comes from eggs that you need to carry around (basicly just have it in your inventory) until they hatch, and you get a new pet. All pets have special abilities that you can use (with cooldowns), plus they will fight for you, like they did in the original game.For the weapons, I have ot noticed anything different yet, apart from the new textures. Coins!You no longer have to be greedy when you are upgrading your friend's towers with your mana, because you no longer use mana as money. They have made it so you get coins instead. This makes a lot more sense to me, as I think of magic, and summoning when I think of mana. I don't think about buying armor with it. You get coins about the same way you get mana. You get them form killing mobs, selling your loot, and completing maps. Small changesI have found a few small changes in the game too, that I think are really cool.When you are near another player, you can see their health and mana bar over their heads. Now you don't have ti pause the game to see if anybody has any mana left!There is a mini-map in the corner of the screen, so you don't have to enable the full-scree map to see where the remaining mana-chests are. You can just look at the mini map! You can of course use the large map too, if you perfer that.When you are building a tower, or repairing one, there is no longer a giant progress bar showing in the middle of the screen. They made a small, but nice looking bar down in the left corner instead.Keybinds for your forge. Now you have keybinds you can use in your forge, instead of having to click first the item, then the unlock button, you can simply click L while hovering your mouse over the item you wish to lock/unlock to do so. There are more keybinds like this.Things I don't like about the game It is a bit confusing the first 20 minutes You kind of have to play DD1 to understand what's going on in this game. I guess you could always google a "Dungeon Defenders Eternity tutorial".The first time you load something, the textures are blurry as they render for the first time. They change a lot of things in the game without warnings. Suddenly they figure they want to remove single player, but after a while they add it again..-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall, this is a very good game, and if you liked the old game, this is a must. I have 500 hours on the old dungeon defenders game, and I wouldn't be suprised if I got up to another 100 hours on this game.I don't know why this game got so many bad reviews (mostly by people that only played it for under 1 hour). I believe it is because it is so different from the first game. It takes some time to get used to the new things. People are getting mad when they see that there is a cash shop, but I don't think they should worry about it, as the cash shop only sells taunts. You can buy everything else for in-game coins! I really have no idea why they are calling this a phone-app though. It is just like DD1 in my opinion.Notice that the game is not a finished project. They game came out yesterday, and they are still working on things like bugs (haven't found any serious bugs yet), new content etc. You have a lot of things to look forward to if you buy this. It also has some sneak peaks on dungeon defenders 2, as they use some of the DD2 things in this game. And yes, they added private games, so you can play alone if you perfer that.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Time to give my 2 cents. I have put hundreds of hours into the orginial Dungeon Defenders and decided to buy this one as well. Bottom line is, I believe it IS WORTH IT. Whether you are new to the game, or already own it. It is worth the money, and they seem to be working on and fixing any problems so far. DON'T LISTEN TO THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS! Most complaints have been fixed at this point and there is still being work done. Overall, the game still plays the same as the original with some fixes and additions that arguably make the game even better! Now... let's get into it.This review is going to written as though you played the original just to point out the reasons for buying this new version.Pros:-More maps-Almost every DLC from the original comes included in this version-Any equiptment is now visible on your character-Pets have alternate abilities that can be activated-Item slots for equiptment that can be activated during battle for various effects (Summon a storm cloud that deals damage, make all your attacks poisonous, heal nearby players, etc)-Players now have there own mana chests as well as drops so no more stealing or fighting over mana/equiptment-You can dye your character AND items-Mana is no longer currency, instead during levels there are gold coins mixed in with the mana as enemies die-Hardcore mode is now scary (if you die...your character is gone for good)-Hitting control allows your character to kind of dash ahead a bit to get around a bit quicker-running into your towers causes you to jump automatically to allow you to get over them with easeCons:-Still HAVE to be online-When completing a level, you always have to return to the tavern prior to starting a new level-The overall userface and inventory system is a bit more clunky then usual, but is manageable-Hardcore mode I feel is also a bit too much some times haha-No split screen-A store that uses REAL money (but is only for cosmetic stuff like emotes and costumes so no biggie)Again, overall the game plays the same. Once you are actually in a match and playing through a level, you won't really notice a difference (other then a few of the new additions). Some things have even made the game better from the original! It's not as bad as those initial reviews made it seem, and although there have been some problems and it isn't perfect...it is getting there. And even as of now, it is still great and feels close to the orinigal DD we know and love. BUY IT!

												I don't usually post reviews, but due to the massive negative feedback this game is getting, I feel it's necessary.Some of the UI is a bit complicated and clunky, but it doesn't necessarily take away from the game. Just a bit of exploring, and it makes much more sense and is easier to navigate.I understand why people are getting angry, but I think that nearly all of these reviews are overreacting. I don't think it's fair to say that you don't recommend a game after an hour or less on record. Granted, recommending it with the same amount of time isn't very convincing either.But, this game does have a lot of added features that spice up the gameplay and make it all-around more enjoyable, in my opinion. The UI for the shop is clunky, yes, but in the actual Dungeon Defense part of the game, the UI is much smaller and easier to navigate than previously. Also, the upgrade system is much easier to understand and use. They've added Pet Eggs to make obtaining pets easier, as well as Consumables. Seriously, so much has been added from the first game, it's ludicrous.My favorite feature is the dodging. Parkour parkour, mutha******.Honestly, I think this game is getting way too much negative feedback considering how good it actually is. Much better than the first game, in my honest opinion. (They've added Single Player now, too, so please shhhhh.)If you can get it for $6 thanks to the first game, do it. If you can get it at all, do it. It's worth your money in my opinion.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Eternity is most certainly different from DD1, and its not all good or bad.From the positives such as better loot filtering and pet abilities, to the not so greats such as needing to be connected at all times and laggy response times on most actions.In a short summary, for anyone who played the DD1 but found it lacking and abandoned the game shortly after, this game is perfect for you, but for the many who played it out through it all, this will feel like a very foreign and strange experience, it will likely be a fairly displeasing experience at first but in time you may grow to like it, i was off put at first but upon finding out about pets having active abilities i came to embrace what differences this game offered, i may not like them all but what i do like is here, so here is were i will stay.Oh and uhm, if you havent played the first Dungeon Defenders game... ignore that one and get this one, this is basicly a remastered edition.

number of helpful: 37 of 77 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												For those who wrote hasty reviews before learnign the essence of what Trendy is doing here I wish you Hadn't. Let me start by saying that this game is by no mean the Origional game completely remade (It will be a different experience even playing through the old campaign!). This is also not Dungeon Defenders 2. However this is a Sincere effort by Trendy to put out a taste of what the new game will look and feel like, and give the thousands of fan of the origional a chance to start seeing some of the hard work they have been putting in. For everyone complaining about a cash shop? That is a feature that will be available likely in DD2 but in no way is Pay To Win its essentially all cosmetics that you can choose to bling out a character with new emotes or taunts. Ive clocked over 1k hours in Dungeon Defenders, have 100% acheivement rate, and can say that I give this game 8.5/10 due to small annoyances like no option to replay a map, and creating a new game taking a minimum 35s in lobby countdown even if playing solo. However the controls seem nicely improved with features like character movement now auto paths over towers and terain easier. And the addition of a much more inviting Pet system are all worth while.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												As someone who played the Original DD quite a bit I was wary of a new version that had to be purchased seperately and  featured much of the same content as  the first title.  Having now levelled a new character into their mid 20's I can say that this version is better than the Original.  Players no longer fight over crystal chests each round; the loot system has been tweaked for a smoother experience and the dlc from the first title has all been included and rebalanced for a better levelling experience. The UI does  have some issues with not being very intuitive on how to manage your inventory but the developers have posted that UI changes are being looked into.  As far as price goes even at its full $19.99 tag, this version is a better deal than purchasing the first title with all the dlc; so its a no brainer for anyone who hasn't already purchased the first game.  With the game servers being handled entirely by the developer, instances of cheating will hopefully be far less prevelant or nonexistent compared to the first DD.  Overall I'd say this title has some rough spots to work out as far as its UI is concerned but overall I would not tell someone to not give it a try and enjoy one of the best action/tower defense games available.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												I own the original and all of it's DLC, I am a fan of the game so I picked this version up.This version is horrible. The launcher is unnecessary and unattractive. The first time I tried to launch the game from it it crashed. You are now required to make an account with a servivce I have never heard of (you have to log into the account in the launcher before you can start the game). I understand that the service is providing servers to host games, which prevents hackers, but I absolutely hate how this was gone about. I'm sure another solution could have been found, or more time could have been put into implementing something such as VAC to not require another account just to launch the game. You are also immediately dropped into a multiplayer lobby with lots of people when selecting play, there isn't even a character select. This is also unnecessary and not something I think adds value to the game. I prefer starting a game and being present a menu, or at least some kind of character select, not being dropped into a game with a group of people I don't know. Oh yeah, and there are microtransactions... they went F2P without going free. My first impression upon launching this game (when I loved the original) is to stay far away. I highly recommend you don't spend money on this. Wait until the original version is on sale and pick that up- or just wait for the second one (which they hopefully haven't done the same to).This version of the game cripples a great game with a multitude of poor and unnecessary decisions. I am upset that I spent any money on this (even if it was only $6). I normally don't write reviews, but I want to help people avoid this. It's simply sad that such a great game was put into such a miserable state like this.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												First I gotta say - feels really good to get back into a good grinding TD experience again!And it really is just that .. A hardcore grinding game - Perfect to take away your many leftover hours.Sweet new spell slots they made for more personal charecter options (also able to put in eggs to increase tower stats instead)Spells like  hero healing, tower healing, and extra field damage all found as both single target and area of effect or even personal player damage boosts for those who want to make the action themselves!And about the eggs - Feels awesome you need to first find the egg and then hatch them into pets later and not only does it make more sence but only increase the grinding you need to do further.They also added crafting which is a nice touch to a grinding game.The new survival mode they made makes it interresting in a whole new way because you cant just switch your chars and make the best defence by yourself .. now you actually need team members to get the job done proberly for the whole hour!Ofcourse for some that is also a downside, but fear not. Going beserk alone is very posible with the right spell setup!Now that was all the good stuff ..Dont know when any of this will be fixed but here is how it is as of now..Just when you log in it loads just as any other time.. But nothing happens .. Cant join tavern - AwesomeAnother bad thing they need to fix is the party option - and for a multiplayer game it should be crucial..?When you are in a party and try to start a map the "ready" button people need to press bugs out and you get stuck.When a map is over and you are in a party ( if you managed to get this far ) it sometime bugs the party and the trouble starts once again..This might not sound as much.. But when you got someone to play with and you might be able to play 1 map and then get stuck in bugs for more then 30 mins before just entering the tavern again to get stuck once more?It makes it bad.. Really bad .. Almost like the bugs got bugs :oBut even with the current bugs solo maps seem to work fine most of the time. And what you get to play is as awesome as ever!So besides the bugs in this game I fully recommend it! Maybe waiting abit to buy it is a smart move so they got some time to fix the bugs.. But not that it matter really when the game is this awesome!Hopefully this gave you some answers you were looking for. Hope to see you inside Defenders!

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Listen up!! Here is the real review! Beware of people that are downvoting this game because of bugs. Look at the date of their review and then look to see if a patch just came out. The game acts really BAD when you click play at 25% downloaded instead of waiting for 100% and the first 3 days after a patch it acts really laggy, BUT after 3 days and 100% downloaded this game works perfectly. Now onto the review, this is a similar game to DD1 but they remade it for transitioning into DD2. This remake allowed rebalancing to all the items and classes. There are extremely few hackers, I have only seen 2 people with hacked items in all my hours on the game. Patches are plenty and they have added new levels and minions to keep it interesting. Downsides to DD1 players are that the reduced the size and weapon effects so you can't get rediculously huge items anymore :( . It took like 4 months to finally see nightmare survival mode and mix mode still isnt out, but we will have all the blanks filled in soon I hope. Still a great game just not as addicting as DD1. If what they say is true about item transfers to DD2 then I recommend playing DDE over DD1. There are a lot of minor UI and mechanics theyve added that really make the game more enjoyable. Still wish the game was more flashy and outrageous though.

												I'm a Dungeon Defender Veteran as you can check on my Steam Profile. This game  is a optimized and improved version of the first one with all the DLC included. I do recommend this game to fellow defenders,  most of the negative reviews and feedback are because there is no offline play, no local COOP features remover from this iteration of the game to promote a safe environment with out the presence of hackers that populate the previous game. It is worth the 6$ asking price given that it includes new content, and also additional loot fro the upcoming DD2. The included cash shop is completly for optional  visual features that dont affect gameplay in any form. I loved the first one and I also loved this game, I do recommend the game to new people who wants to try the blend of rpg/tower defense, and fellow dd veterans.

												If Trendy had released this game in a different way then I dont think there would be so many unhappy people.  I was a bit unsure at 1st as I felt I was paying for a game I already had but once I finnally got in the game I realised its just Dungeon Defenders 1.5. Its really buggy joining the tavern and can takes loads of atempts before you get in.  I dont like the shared hub tavern, I much preferred having my own tavern and I miss all my trophies ;PThe PlayVerse joining issues need to be fixed desperatly as it takes more time to join a game than it does to play but I'm hoping this will get fixed soon (this seems to be fixed now, had no issues joining since 29/07/14)Hardcore mode - loose all xp/gear if you fail (this is a terrible change)

												In some ways, this is a very pollished version of Dungeon Defenders. Lots of stuff has been fixed and streamlined. I really like the character customization options (although it is weird that we cannot choose the color of our character's hair, clothes and skin like we used to).However, the GUI is awkward and completely different: it will take a little while to adapt. It took me a good, long while to find some basic functions. I also hate the public tavern system: some players fill the place with so many traps that it gets real laggy. Wholly unnecessary!! I'd rather just have a party-only tavern.But once we figure out this new GUI, and the developers fix a few things, this will really rock. I'm glad that I'm giving it a chance.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												In its current state I 'can't' recommend this game, but do recommend "Dungeon Defenders" as a game, that would include DDE if it becomes as fully functional as I hope. This version is altogether broken and filled with so many poor choices it makes it hard to enjoy. This is sad because DDE is a fun game with creative elements but...1. Mandatory online in order to play, whether solo or local. This is terrible for so many reasons. One reason is everyone starts in this small tavern hub and it's cluttered with people spawning and throwing spells around...its a mess. Shopping is difficult as you have to maneuver around to click the right spot not occupied by someone. The biggest problem of all is...I havent been able to play for an hour now as it won't connect. It keeps telling me matchmaking has problems...I DONT CARE, I DONT WANT TO PLAY WITH PEOPLE (outside my party and even then sometimes not at all). I paid to play a game not watch loading screens. mandatory online without ability to filter out people is just so strange and gives creedance ot those saying things like "mobile port", especially when in context of always online.2. inventory and shopping is one of the other great detractors from fun. I played one match today and spent 45 minutes going through every piece of poorly indicated (stats) junk to find one or two better items. Multiple clicks to manage, lock/unlock items, then finding what is part of a specific set (from what I hear equipping everything of a set is a bonus), then guessing what each little icon indicates for stats/perks. If that wasn't a pain enough, to compare an item to an equipped you hover over it, everytime something happens (someone logs in, changes chars, chats...) the stats dissappear and you have to continue to hover....and only then do you get to compare it to one of the two weapons as it never shows stats for both. The loot drop system makes this even more of a problem because you collect sooo many items in one match, give us a few appropriate or decent items to choose from, we don't need 50 pieces of junk not worth much money or even useable by our characters every match.New players be warned nothing is clear, not exhaggerating I literally mean nothing. It will not explain what anything means outside of the obvious, just make sure you play with someone who is in the know or good luck.I kept the thumbs up in hopes this will be fixed, because the core of Dungeon Defenders no matter the version is fun and worth a play.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												DDE is what I would call the "game of the year" version of Dungeon Defenders. It constantly finds new ways to impress me as I play it, making the original DD seem obsolete in comparison. All the characters are unlocked from the get go, so you don't have to buy them seperately. Mana, chests, and all items are seperate to each player, so you don't have to fight over them. New item slots have been added like trinkets to use during combat such as Flash heal, Instant tower repair, and even a holy hand grenade to deal with pesky skeletons. A new currency has been added called coins, which is used to upgrade your items instead of mana. There are orb like items which grant you increased exp, loot drops, and loot rarity which apply for the entire map and for everybody, further encouraging team play. Towers now have stat numbers available, so you can see exactly how your skills affect them. There have been some downsides however, such as now your armor appears on your character at all times, which makes you look gaudy if your armor selection clashes. I would like the ability to turn this off. The summoner no longer has minion points but uses defense points like everyone else, however has been buffed to compensate. The tavern is a public hub, which lags everytime someone joins for a split second, making inventory management a bit irritating. Overall though, I would recommend this version over the original any day of the week. If you've already bought the dlc for the first one, maybe only get this for 5$ or if the new features really appeal to you. There is one last thing to mention, and that is the playverse overlay. I mention it last because it's barely worth mentioning as it doesn't really add anything to the game, and account creation takes a few seconds at best. Don't let it dissuade you from this awesome version of a good game.EDIT: The mana that drops from enemies is not shared and is able to be picked up by anyone. I'm sorry for misleading you on that fact. Chests and items still remain as being unique to you and you alone

GET OUT !"But then, i played a couple hours, and the goal remains the same, you have to build towers and kill monsters. Of course the launcher is totally different, but it's because of the non-stop hackers who ruined the game with their impossible high score. But still, why made this one not free or for really cheap ? I already got my DD game, i don't want to pay for quite the same think...It's not really expensive if you already have the game, but come on, 6€ until the 29th July, maybe 15€ after it's not nothing...A good point IMO, is that they listen to their customers, they made patch almost everyday in order to improve the gameplay and their game. So for all the people who trash-talk every time against Nom nom games and Trendy, be patient and stop insulting a game without even playing it. Do constructive criticism and be respectful to the work they did.Have fun !

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												As a player who has put in over 450 hours of game play for DD1, I was excited to hear about this "definitive" version. I knew from the start that yes it was the same game just with new features, no I won't have any of my old DLC since this is a new/separate game, and was excited about the visual gear (because I'm a firm believer in personal customization). So lets jump into the game.We start by making a profile which is fine. We did this in the old game, then we hit the “Play” button. I'm expecting to see a choose or create a character screen, but instead I'm in the tavern as a random cavern with a few dozen other people. In my confusion I just have to ask how do I make a character because nothing explains how. No brief tutorial, no inn keeper popping up on the side of my screen saying “hey, welcome, lets start by showing you around”. I actually restart the game a few times thinking this was a bug. Once I find out how to change my character, I decide to start how I started in the old game. Playing solo and leveling three different characters: Mage, Series EV, and the Summoner.Hours into the game, I find a few things very pleasing:Coin System: New currency system.Eggs: Pets in the old game were super rare.Pet abilities: Being able to have certain pets that do certain things helps with customization.4 new player abilities: These can be either eggs, consumables, or new skills. Trading through Play-verse: I can trade gear with friends even when they are offline.Visual gear & Dye: Again, I'm am all for customization.New Survival system: Rather then just more waves, you start and are pressured to build as the waves progress. More skill intensive.However I also find other things displeasing:Having to use play-verse to create groups with friends. Now I have no problem with games using their own system. Especially when multi-platform games. But the system its self is just super slow. Nothing shows you how to use it. Like having to create a party first, THEN add your friends rather then adding a friend and a party automatically being created.The Tavern: I know this is supposed to act like a main player hub. I nick-named it “Stormwind” from World of War craft. A place where all players go to when not doing quest's or missions. However the Tavern was originally built for a single player. Being able to show case mission rewards and host there own shops to earn mana. A system no longer in the game.The timer before a match starts: Maybe its just be being used to the old game where the match would immediately begin. I'm guessing it's like your League of Legends before play screen where it waits for everyone to load the data so the game play it's self can be smoother. But this is still the case for solo play.Make one character: Unlike the old game, you do no have split-screen capabilities that allow you to level up multiple characters, or invite friends to play on your account. This is more of a “if you want to play it, you must buy it on your own system.” which is in a total different direction then the first. But $$$ is $$$.Character swapping not as relevent. In the old game, to be a good solo player, you had to swap between characters during build phases. Build your towers, build your a.o.e bubbles, build your summoner minions, kill with your warrior. Now it's still possible to do this, but it's so hard to level a new character since you cannot run it yourself. Maybe running your own alts wasn't a normal intention even in the first game. What it needs:Some way to help players better understand what it is they are doing. What to do, and what everything means.If it is so hard to level up multiple classes, show a preview or have a detailed list on what a character does. Like e.g. Barbarian. “Since he cannot build defense, he uses two weapons and stances to destroy waves of enemies” before players embark on the journey and waste their time. Overall: If you own the first DD, if your looking for new new, this isn’t it. However this is a good refresher.I will stick in a few more hours because I just like the overall feel that DD gives and I know that this is still early and it's a preview for whats to come in DD2. Using DD as a trial and error system.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												  ATTENTION! THIS REVIEW IS ONLY A RESPONSE TO THIS BUNCH OF NEGATIVE REVIEWS AND A COMPARISON TO THE FIRST TITLE , IF YOU DON'T KNOW WHAT THE FIRST DUNGEON DEFENDERS IS LIKE, OR DON'T CARE ABOUT WHAT THE STEAM REVIEWS ARE TALKING, READING THIS WILL BE A LITTLE USELESS, BUT YOU CAN DO IT ANYWAY, I AM JUST A GUY WITH CAPS LOCK. You know... this really surprised me. After i saw hundreds of negative reviews for this game i though that the game would be a disgrace to the humanity, and i will start by saying: Yes, it have its flaws, but it is not as much as Steam reviews are trying to convince there is.    The game uses the same gameplay style as the first one, and it is like you had all the DLC.   "BUT HEY! THE GAME IS TRYING TO SELL SKINS WITH REAL MONEY""    No, it is not, you have a whole pack of skins in your inventory, what they ARE selling is Emotes, that are basically animations that prove nothing. It is not only not required, but also, no one that buy them will be superior to you in any aspect, you probably won't even see anyone using these things.    "BUT THEY SHOULDN'T BE ADDING MICROTRANSACTIONS TO A PC GAME!"     Yes, that is true, but the same goes to the first game. Look at the DD1, look at the DLC quantity. There is a lot of them, and they are important things, like characters or missions. This one gives you all the previous game DLC included, comparing to that, selling emotes is almost a joke.     Anyway, continuing the review... The gear thing is awesome, you can have the most riddiculous equip possible, your character will still look amasing, the feeling of gearing up is incredible.      And about the new item types, there...     "THEY WERE TOTALLY CRAZY DOING IT! IT IS NOTHING LIKE DUNGEON DEFENDERS!"     Calm down... let me finish: Yes, the weapons ARE completely.. hm... peculiar. You still have the weapon types of the first game, but in this one, you have more. I already found a machine gun, a granade launcher and even a freakin' Flamethrower. Yeah. Completely not what you would search in a Dungeon Defenders game, but that is not necessarely a bad thing, i found it really awesome actually, these weapons are given a little "medieval" style, so it doesn't break immersion that much, and i found myself pretty badass while burning enemies.      Besides that, they indeed solved that hackers problem DD1 had.(even if they did in a strange way), they tried to add Playverse in-game, so they can have some feedback before DD2. Also they solved their first week probl...     "YOU COULDN'T PLAY SINGLEPLAYER OR OPEN A PRIVATE MATCH!"      Yes, yes... Stop interrupting. Even though they got that wrong, they solved really fast.      "HOW ABOUT THE WHOLE LOAD OF OTHER PROBLEMS WE TALKED?!"       Well. You can found online a chart the devs made showing the most talked problems with the game, and how were they handling it: First one was microtransactions, and they already pronnounced that every future mission will be free, and they will NOT sell level-increases or armor/items. The second and third were "no singleplayer" and "live texture streaming" things they already fixed.  Fourth was the confusing HUD and inventory system, what they said that it is a known issue and will fix it soon. Next on the list was that the game was a "portable device version of the original", and they already said that it is not (I didn't quite understanded this part, i have the DD second wave on my ipad and it is nothing like this game, and if they are referring to the way this game is presented, it obviously have something to do with mobile versions, considering it will launch to mobiles soon, with cross-plataform). And lastly on the list was the "must be online to play", what they are already fixing.        If there is something i do have to complain is the bugs, there are a lot of them, something small enemies glitches their ways into my defenses and stuff like that. Nothing game-breaking, but a little annoying.        Now the pros and Cons:         Pros:         +Classic DD1 experience.        +Gear showing up.        +Awesome new weapons and armor.        +Balancing fixes.        +Graphical Improvements.        +Devs are listenning to the feedback and trying to fix their mistakes.        Cons:        -Loads of bugs.              (may or may not be fixed)        -Confusing HUD.            (will be fixed soon)        -Must be online to play. (will be fixed soon)        -No private taverns.       (will be fixed soon i guess)        CONCLUSION: Even by screwing up a bit, the Devs are giving attention to the feedback and improving the game. The game have all the features DD1 Had. It adds all the DLC content the first game had for free. It did rebalanced the game, fixed the hacker problem, added some cool new content. If you don't have DD1, i recommend you buy this game, if you have DD1, i recommend buying this game, but if you have DD1 with all the DLCs maybe it is not worth the full price, since it doesn't add much, you could wait some discount.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Why is there so much hate? I have no clue. Let me start off with Singleplayer. It's nearly the same as the first Dungeon Defenders, only with enhanced graphics, cooler weapons and awesome armor. But Multiplayer is where it gets fun. You first start off by choosing your class. No DLC characters, you have access to everybody. Once you choose your class, you get a TF2 pet equipped and press E on the eternia crystal. Then you click GO. It pairs you up with people close to your level, you will never play with anyone that is more than 5 levels above you. So you play for 10 minutes. Then 30. Then an hour. Then 4 hours. And next thing you know, it's 2 in the morning. I missed Dungeon Defenders.

												There are some kinks that they are working out, but it is a good value for the price. Plenty of characters to be, and plenty of maps to play along with varying modes that are standard to Tower Defense games, e.g. survival, boss waves. content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Dungeon Defenders Eternity is everything original Dungeon Defender lovers wanted. I first want to get the "always online" thing out of the way. They have their reasons for it and that's that. Do I like it? No. But I also paid $6 for this game (which mind you includes ALL DLC from the previous Dungeon Defenders, maps and all).Private/ single player sessions are no longer an issue, as they included it in a patch. With that said, disregard all prior terrible reviews made by kids with .4 hours on record. If you loved the first Dungeon Defenders then I promise, you'll love this one. It's the same thing as the first, but updated features, textures, and maps. One of my favorite new features is visible armor upgrades. Before only your weapon would change it's look. Now they've done it with all of the armor so you can actually look different and feel badass.

												All in all I would not recommend purchasing this game. It's a rehash of their original and I don't believe it provides the merit required for buying it again. Further they big sell on it is that you can't cheat anymore because it is online. What it didn't fix is the ability to ban or kick players from your game. You can pretty much gaurantee that 50% of your games will end like this:You star the map, you play, somewhere between half way and close to the end someone will jump into the game, sell everything give you the perverbial middle finger and then leave.The game is a bit buggy, but Trendy has worked hard on fixing the bugs so there is that benefit. Though all in all I'd wait for DD2, or just write the game off entirely. I know personally I probably wont be looking too hard at DD2.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												People will not give this game enough credit considering the amount of content Trendy has added/ will be adding all because they used not the ~best term to describe this final iteration of DD. (Definitive).Many nice cosmetic features have been added/ revamped, small things like:- Personal loot- Personal mana chests- Being able to see your equipment on your HeroAnd even some bigger ideas seen through:- Five new maps, each of which fit in nicely with the original story, plus the last one which is its own map entirely.- Long-term balancing of each class - we will eventually have a balanced DDE (this is why Definitive was a bad word)- All DLC from DD already comes with this game, they could have made us re-buy it again, especially for those that never owned DD/ bought the DLC in the first place. No, they're not greedy people.- A way to both make this original game as good as it can be, plus some slight insight into DD2, plus we're essentially testing out features - this will avoid DD2 issues that were presented in DDE. Be happy, stop nagging to your every need.- You shouldn't be expecting Nightmare mode because it wasn't stated that NM was available in this game. They are most likely working on making it as balanced as possible, most likely in parallel with what it might be like in DD2. Who knows.The negatives would be:- Playverse: Not very intuitive, so there's much to be desired.- The game should probably have been left untouched (original content-wise) *if at all possible*. And then just amended when necessary with patches.- Other little things here and there which are being addressed on the forums. If you're curious, check the forums out, it'll do you some good.All in all there have been more positive changes/ additions to the game than any negative bugs, etc that could weigh the game down. Already putting a decent amount of hours into this game once again!

content:

												Having played the original dungeon defenders and owning the entire DLC, I have to say this new version is pretty horrible. content:

												I will defend this game to the end of time. That's not to say its good but its definitely better if you actually know the game. Whenever I played it on launch almost everything was changed and was lacking a tutorial or any proper functions and bad queue times. The game improved and added more content and steam workshop content was added. Trendy avoided this game later on and gave away collections of DD1 ( Which is arugably better ) and didn't update it. Onto the actual review. The game plays really well for veterans of the series, not so much for newbies. They introduce new items which I honestly didn't use and regret that. The game looks well and has a more cartoony vibe this time with a little more cell shading of sorts. All characters are available for free, which was a problem of the first game but not really if you wait for a good sale on it making the collection about 7 or 10 bucks. Really I would go more indepth but this game isn't worth buying but if you do buy it, it's still a good experience. TOO BAD NOBODYS PLAYING IT. 3/5 Would only recommend to Veterans like myself.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I've seen a lot of negative reviews about this game, but please read this before you read those negatives ones.This game, although not advertised as early access, certainly feels early access. First of all:-The download "client" (I say it with quotation marks, because it's very poorly made), looks terrible and for me the download percentage bar, went down, but the number went up. The amount of bytes in the negatives.. Which I found amusing. :)Anyway, into the game.The game starts off with a good looking menu. You press Play. Instantly transported to the tavern, where literally everyone and their mothers are hanging out. You don't get to choose your class straight away, unless you look into the defenders forge deep enough, to find at the bottom of the character list, that you can choose between the four main classes. The tavern shop, is incredibly messy. I didn't know what was what, and where to go for whatever item I wanted to purchase. This game IS TOTALLY MULTIPLAYER CURRENTLY. No singleplayer. Frustrating to say the least. But you can host a private game however. The mana graphics have changed so they all look exactly the same... (makes it worse really). The chests are buggy to open, take a lot longer than the original DD. Standard weapons do a lot more damage too. Other than, not much difference.This game has MASSIVE potential, it just needs to be refined a lot more. It's extremely messy and all over the place. I do love the loot you can get now, you can get jewellery and temporary boosts and potions and whatnot. Also, I do love the fact armour shows up on your character now. PLUS!!Other than that, it's a bit of state at the minute. If you wish to purchase and experience it... be my guest. :) But I wouldn't recommend it, EVEN though this is a positive review. This is positive because of the sheer potential this game could have if done properly and is refined more.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Haters are gunna hate! While not perfect, this is a nice take on getting rid of the rampent hacking of the weapons and stats of the first game.  Time will tell if the online aspect will prove to stop the hacking from the first game.  That being said its good ole DD.  Few new surprises, but otherwise same game just more streamlined and simpilified.  There's a lot of gaming to be had for the entry price.  If you're like me and was a big fan of the first one, but stopped playing because of all the overpowered (and hacked) people that would ruin the games online then this will make you happy.It has been so long since I've played DD I've been enjoying relearning the different techniques needed for the dfferent maps and making new friends along the way.  As for the people complaining about microtransactions they are only there to change the appearance of your characters, they in no way shape or form alter your characters power, stats, or abilites.  Its just for looks!  They also have been really good about addressing bugs and have been adding constant patches and updates to the game.  (in addition to adding single player options as well). Basically if you loved the first one and want to get your Dungeon Defenders fix in again then this is a great way to do it.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												I love Dungeon Defenders, it's an amazing RPG/Tower Defence game that I would reccomend to any person who enjoys strategy games. I was extremely excited when I heard about Eternity coming out, but when I got it, I felt slightly disappointed. The reason for this is that this game didn't really have much to offer. Of course, I do enjoy the new items and mechanics, extra maps, and having every character availible without having to buy DLC is always nice. But I feel like this game should have been just downloadable content, rather than a game on its own. One thing I don't really like is how you join maps. I would much rather select a group to join from a list then wait in a queue. That's one reason that I feel this game should just be DLC. The option of a queue would be nice to have, but I wouldn't want to have to be in a queue every time. I would prefer to just have the option, along with being able to join games like the original Dungeon Defenders. But the biggest complaint I have, is that this game has absolutely no tutorial whatsoever. Playing the game for the first time, I had no idea how any of the new mechanics worked, and I hadn't played the original in so long, I needed to refreshe my memory. Eternity lacks that though. I consider myself a veteran Dungeon Defenders player, and even I was confused at first. I would hate to have somebody completely new to this game be totally lost, as it doesn't even explain the mechanics of the game that were in the original Dungeon Defenders. I understand this this is meant to be an expansion, but it needs to explain how the new things added to the game works. Despite these flaws though, Dungeon Defenders Eternity is a great game for those who have already played Dungeon Defenders and want a little bit more, or newcomers willing to do a bit of research about the game. Any strategy lover should play this game.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												     Okay so the best way to think about this game is by seeing it as a Dungeon Defenders: Game of the Year Addition. So when you purchase this game it comes with all of the dlc that was with the first, plus a few new missions. That is the most important change. There are some differences which others have repeated many times the best of which is that loot (item drops, mana, etc.) is seperate for each person. So there are no more drop hogs that pick everything up whether it belongs to their class or not, and no one picking up all the mana for themself. Also your character now wears the armour that you equip.     So if you already own this game on pc, yeah it might not be completly worth it to buy right now, I myself would wait for a good sale. However if you are like me and have only owned the console version of the game, with 1 piece of dlc, it is worth the buy. Especially because the console edition never recieved the additional characters the pc version had. Or if you have not purchased or played Dungeon Defenders at all I would reccomend going for this game over the original as it comes with the dlc.     It is good to mention that this still in fact a "new" game that still has bugs, and incompleted things/ideas that they are working on. The major thing that I myself am waiting on is full controller support. It was in the original DD so it should be able to transfer to this game no problem. Yes I prefer controller for this style of gaming, you can go ahead and make fun of me, I am just very clumsy with a mouse and keyboard. Once that is available I will give this game a full 5/5 rating.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Love it! Better balanced, better UI, better loot system, and NO MORE HACKING -- in theory. This is what DD should've been from the get-go. Contrary to what some of the early reviews said, this is NOT just a mobile port. And there IS both single player and private party play (though you still have to be online -- that's how they prevent hackers, as everything is hosted on their servers this time).Big changes:===========================* Online only play. No more hacked characters and items, hopefully. Matchmaking (presumably hosted on Trendy's servers) instead of peer to peer hosting. Hopefully no more hacked hosts.* No split screen, level xp revamped. You don't jump from 0 to 70 with three split screen characters in Tavern Defense anymore. You actually have to earn your levels with each character.* Towers rebalanced. Summoners now use DU like everyone else. Most towers cost less DU. EV buff beam nerfed so it's not the end-all-be-all must-have tower anymore. (Opinion: I think this is a change for the better, because now you have to think about which towers and heroes to use. It's no longer just poons + buff beams + minions. Will have to wait for higher level play to see how this turns out... but so far it seems promising.)* Loot system redone. Everybody gets their own private loot and don't have to compete with others anymore. Much more loot variety: weapons, sets, quality levels (tiers), etc. all much better. Loot's actually useful now.* Mana system redone: Every player gets their own mana chests (total chest mana is divided by number of players). They see their own crystals when they kill a monster. You can still drop mana for other players.* Microtransactions were only for the new emotes. All heroes, maps, and non-legendary/super-legendary costumes are included for free. (Not sure if this is because I already own them for DD1)* Visible armor sets and accessories for all characters. It's fun to see the Jester wear hats on her knees and belts on her hat :)* Pets now drop as eggs that need to be incubated and then hatched. All this means is that you carry them in an inventory slot for a wave or two and then double click on them to see which pet you got. Then they level up as before. But now every pet has both their old passive ability and a new active one. For example, the genie can summon a mana aura that increases mana drops in a radius for a while. The helicopter cat can add additional damage to your next attack (almost like hawk stance). The faerie does a large AoE heal. Etc.* A few new maps* It uses their own Playverse service for matchmaking/chatting instead of Steam. It really sucks, is buggy as hell, and completely unnecessary. Wish they stuck with Steam.* You can carry up to 4 activatable inventory items. There are Amulets that add skills like regeneration auras, poison DoTs, flash heals, etc. There are also bog-standard potions (healing, for example) and some one-time-use bombs, decoys, etc.* True hardcore mode: With this on, your character permanently dies (loses all levels and equipment) if s/he falls. The best loot is found in this mode -- for those willing to risk it.Minor changes:===========================* Revamped UI, with item sorting, filtering, etc. Better item comparisons. Better item and tower stats. Other quality-of-life UI enhancements: You can now filter out all lower tier weapons, for example, and then unlock them all and sell them all at once!* Armor & weapon dyes* Every character can hold two weapons and switch between them, like the Jester and EV could before.* Most DLC costumes available from the get-go, without needing requirements or additional payments. Legendary and Super Legendary costumes still need to be earned, if they're in the game at all (not sure yet).* Consumable items (health potions and whatnot)* In-game currency is now gold coins instead of mana. Most chests, monsters, etc. drop coins. You can also sell items for coin. Coinage is abundant at least in the early game.* Currently, the real-world money shop only sells emotes for your costumes. Not sure if they'll add more things later.* You can make a short forward dash several times before needing to recharge it (basically a sprint)* Finally, rebindable keys (or Xbox 360 buttons -- including readying and dropping mana!)* Borderless full screen mode* Minor graphical updates* You can now type full sentences in chat! No longer limited to the previous 70 or so characters.Conclusion==========================Definitely worth it for $6. I've switched to this for the online play alone, to be free from hackers, and probably won't go back to DD.

number of helpful: 11 of 25 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												((Review reworked 24/7/14 - yes, this could be considered 'in constant development'.))Playing Games with Bad Reviews so you, my friends, won't have to if it's a bad buy! ...is my personal motto for this review, because I've heard a lot of bad things about this. Like, a lot of bad things. Like, seriously, this game had severely negative reviews when it first launched and I can't blame them. It is supposed to be the definitive Dungeon Defenders experience, and while it may be shaping up to be one, I can't help but feel... well... annoyed, and somewhat disappointed.Upsides/What is newNow, first things first, this game is basicaly DD1 with a new engine, there's no two ways about that, the game has been rebalanced and tweaked and looks better in some ways, looks worse in others. It still plays pretty much the same: Build towers, kill monsters, collect loot. The upside to this is that DDE has all the heroes and their costumes unlocked for you right out the gate, well, whatever was in DD1, anyway, who knows if they'll offer costumes as a microtransaction.The game plays just as well as the original, with a few QoL tweaks like client-side mana and equipment (thank goodness), the fact that the currency is replaced with gold coins so that you no longer feel the need to leave mana out on the field, the ability to AUTOMATICALLY JUMP OVER SMALL OBSTACLES (10/10! GotY!) and the fact that there's more equipment slots plus the ability to weapon swap in the middle of a wave even if you're not Series EV (which is her gimmick back in DD1, although it seems useless now because her towers are pretty good for support.).The UI is decent enough to fuss about with, it's not terrible, but it sometimes feels a bit clunky like the item box interface. No idea how crafting works, and my hotkeys get reset everytime I go back to tavern. There's not much of a tutorial to figure anything out if you're a newcomer, although some veterans reportedly had some trouble with it as well.Taverns are now public... that's something I'm not too sure about, sure, it's nice to see other people in the tavern but some people don't like to see strangers running around, spamming attacks, towers, and so on. I tend to ignore such things, preferring much to get out of there as soon as I can.Downsides/ProblemsWhen this game first released, and this is going to be an understatement, there was a terrible fuss over how the game was missing some of its advertised features. Single-player and private lobbies? Patched in after the fact. Cards and Workshop? I dunno when that came in, but they're there now. Third-party accounts? Not advertised at launch, but there now. Always-online DRM? Not what most people were expecting. Cash shop? Bluh.However! The company seems to be putting a small effort into fixing a few things if what they've been doing didn't tip anyone off, so at least they're trying to make things work.So, acknowledgements of missing things at Day 1 and general fussery aside, what's the problem here?The servers breaking in the first few days of launch doesn't really come as a surprise to me, these days. It's probably just me, but I just don't really expect any company to handle their launches very well, but perhaps I've been jaded by seeing so many online games releasing and then buckling under the pressure of people coming onto the server and breaking them. When I first played this, they were fine, although it was after the initial surge, I believe, or I was playing at a quieter time.The cash shop in a paid game kind of rubs me the wrong way, although they're selling cosmetics right now, so that kind of mitigates it, it's still a cause for concern. Right now, I don't feel too strongly about it, but I would feel wary about it, just in case.OverallAll in all, this is not a bad game, but it's been sullied by how it was handled right out of the gate, and that doesn't put a lot of trust in their customers. The price for this is questionable, but having a hefty discount for owning the game plus the initial release sale at this time of writing brings it down to a price I can somewhat agree with. Sure, I'd prefer it to be more or less free or be a patch for DD1, but if they insist on it having a price, then so be it, but the initial asking price right now for a small upgrade doesn't fit the bill, perhaps when it is more fleshed out then the price would have more worth to it.Anyway, it is up to you as to whether or not you should buy it. If you don't particularly care much for Trendy's antics and want to play Dungeon Defenders, this could be a good pickup for what it's worth since it has the Eternia Shards levels packed in with it. However, if registering a separate account on Playverse and having a game that requires you to always be online irks you, but you still want this game, I suggest you go pick up DD1 over this.Side note: I honestly wish there was an undecided option for reviews on Steam whenever the reviwer is unsure on whether to recommend it or not, like in my case. Honestly, what happens in the future can tip my view on this game in whatever side's favour.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												Like many of the people complaining, I also sank a LOT of money on the original DD. With that being said though, that game and community were completely dead for me. The fact that people could get anything they wanted just by running a program in the background killed it for me in every sense of the word. This game has been given new life with this release making it a LOT harder for people to just hack and get what they want. One cool/weird thing they did with this game though is you don't download anything until you need it. That means when you first start the game, EVERYTHING is going to be super blurry. Just give this some time and it will pass as you download the required files. So far this game has been wonderful and fun to play again and really helped revive a game that just wasn't fun to play anymore.--UPDATE--After playing this game for almost 60 hours now after its first release I can honestly say that the game is better than its previous counterpart. While the game is still going through some growing pain as far as the servers adjusting to the player load, the staff seems to be really helpful and quick to fix any issues that come up. The staff also takes a lot of what people are saying in the forums and fix what needs to be fixed. -- Conclusion --If your reading all these posts saying stuff like "THE SERVER IS DOWN, WE CANT PLAY" or, "This game sucks, there is no single player" then your just reading peoples first impression. Even WOW couldn't keep their servers playable for the first couple days and DD is doing a way better job than they did. The single player is now enabled due to popular demand. They are fixing every issues as they come up including server down time. When it does go down its for like 5 to 10 minutes tops and this only effects you if your not already in a game, it wont kick you out of one you already have going. Ignore these trolls who didn't give the game a fair shot or are just upset that their hacked max item set can't be transfered from the old hackers resort version of the game.GET THIS GAME

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												Being a big fan of the 1st game along with a really good sale of this one i decided to get it, and dont regret it.i'm not going to go through a whole list of positive things about the game as their are so many, though i'm going to have a little moan about things they got right in the first game and so wrong in this 1.Private Taverns: i dont want to be lumbered with no escape from a bunch of other players spam attacking dummys and skills in the tavern, me and my mate play mainly at night till early hours in the morning due to being busy during the day, and to have a private tavern to talk about the items picked up and the next fight and tactics and stuff was perfect, now we're dumped in a zoo of 20-30 other people going mental.User Inteface: The UI in this game feels rushed, trading is useless unless you wish to spend an hour looking for the item you said your mate could have when you picked it up, as the icons are so small in the trade box and you cant tell the difference between a staff and a sword.An added filter for class would be great, their are a few filter choices to help you look for specific items in your inventory, but their is no filter that allows you to look for specific class items, if you have a few characters that you would like to progessively level and gear up, this would be a huge bonus.Their are a few other issues with the UI but you get the idea.Loading times: The loading times are starting to annoy me a little. Because i'm so used to the game loading instantly in DD once a level is picked and now this whole countdown waiting for player stuff has been implemented it needs to be tweaked slightly. Add a check box that allows players that are ready to tick, and if all players have loaded and ticked, they can begin instead of waiting for the whole countdown, me and my mate have monstrous gaming pc's, 95% of the loading time is us waiting about.Trading: i know the game has its reasons for having our own client side loot, and it is great i enjoy not fighting over loot anymore, but it would be nice if i could just right click an item in my inventory and click drop and it becomes server side, when playing with more than 2 friends its time consuming clicking trade on each person when if a "drop" feature was implemented everyone in the game could mouse over the items i dropped to see if they are better and take them, if not ill scoop them all back up, i miss that.These are just a few of the problems in this game in comparison to the first, it bugs me when developers seem to lose a lot of good aspects to a game that were in previous versions, this should be every good thing from the last and much more, which in most cases it is, just these little things let it down.I'm a massive DD fanboy and i do love this game, i could spend all day pointing out the amazing points of the game which is why i chose to just dig at the negatives a little hoping it would get some feedback out there and hopefully eventually sorted.highly recommended game guys, if you loved the first you will love this one more!

number of helpful: 23 of 50 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												This is Dungeon Defenders 1: Complete Edition.  Without hacking, with some extra content.  As such it gets my full endorsement.  As someone who came to the party late, there was no point in playing public multiplayer due to the hacking.  This game finally allows me to play the original as it was meant to be played.Despite early reviews, this is not:1) A mobile port (this is a complete misunderstanding of the cross platform service launching later)2) Full of microtransactions. The only thing you can (currently) buy are useless Emotes for $1 - all skins and dyes are earned as usual, as are all weapons, armor, etc.3) Dumbed down or DLC deficient - the gameplay is identical, and the UI is largey the same or slightly streamlined4) Lacking single player or private matches (both were added with a day 2 patch)They did add a uPlay-like launcher to the game that might annoy some, but I found it to be seamless.  They need the overlay to offer cross playform play later on, which steam cannot do.Drawbacks:- You cannot import your characters.  This is to prevent item hacks from exploiting this game also.- They added too much bloom.  Hopefully a patch will allow you to turn it off.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												I will be making comparisons to the original Dungeon Defenders, so I apologize to those who have not played it as this review will be difficult to understand. Do note that this review is solely based on how the game is in its current state (as of July 25, 2014). There will be changes made as the developers iron out the bugs.This is essentially Dungeon Defenders 1.5, so if you enjoyed the original, you will enjoy this even more (assuming you can get over the fact that you have to start over). However there will be certain exceptions. Although there have been some MAJOR improvements when it comes to the loot, leveling, stats and gameplay in general, it comes at a cost. This game REQUIRES you to be online, at all times. Not only this, but you must also have a decent connection in order to be able to play without monsters lag-warping all over the place. While this issue does not really affect the tower-defending portion of the game, it will hinder some players from being able to properly fight mobs up close. This game also contains its fair share of bugs, and requires you to sign up for a Playverse account (relatively painless however).While many people will say that it contains every DLC from the past game, there are a few noteable exceptions. In the game, the maps are divided between Campaign, Lost Shards Campaign, the new Campaign (only one map in it so far), bonus maps (Glitterhelm, Palantir and such), challenge maps (Raining Goblins, etc.) and another grayed-out tab that has crossed swords as an image. I found that most of the combat-oriented maps are missing, the Presidential PvP map, the two-team tower defense, the Assault maps and other similar maps. However I speculate that the grayed-out tab has something to do with that.While most of this that I mentioned in my review here is already mentioned on the store page, I feel that it helps to repeat these as they are important factors when it comes to deciding whether or not you wish to purchase the game.I enjoyed this new remake of the old Dungeon Defenders, however I was one of the lucky who were able to get the game to work from the start, and have no issues with connectivity so far. I've also been lucky enough not to suffer from the hardcore glitch (they have disabled hardcore mode until they fix it) which causes you to suffer the consequences of hardcore even if you haven't died. I know not everyone will be so lucky, so you could take this as a warning.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Only played the first level and messed around with items, store, forge etc. But so far I can't really see what people are complaining about too much. Will update this once I played more this weekend.>edit Okay so after playing for a bit longer tonight, the only real complaint I have is that of the new tavern system. Anyone familiar with DD will have spent a lot of time in their OWN tavern, but now you have to be in a public tavern, and connection issues galore a lot of the time you can't even connect to one. This leads me with the issue of sitting at the end of a game for 10 minutes trying to leave so I can start a new one, but unable to go to my own tavern, it's really frustrating, I spend more time waiting than I do playing...Another annoyance is that you can't make your own public game. So if you want to play public, you have to play with people you don't know. Yes, you can create a private game, but what if I want to level up a DPS character and can't solo some of the larger maps (for example), and can't be bothered to use my builder? This means that you can either play with randoms, some of which are bad... not blaming them, some people might not have played DD to my extent, but I don't want to play with new people at the moment, I want to experience the "new and improved" end game. And sometimes it can even take 5-10 (sometimes longer) to even FIND a game for your level/difficulty/map... So the only other option is a private game.Other than that I'm enjoying my time, I think I'll wait until the connection issues are fixed and I can actually host a public game and/or tavern to remove the complaints I talked about above.If you're a veteran DD player and you have the $$$ to spare, pick it up and see what you think, it's really not as bad as some people on here have made it out to be, the connection is♥♥♥♥♥♥and the way you actually get into games is also♥♥♥♥♥♥ but the gameplay itself is as good as the original we all loved, maybe even better with the new pet "active" abilities and trinket type items.If you've not played the previous DD, I wouldn't bother spending the amount of money they ask for on this UNTIL they fix what I mentioned, after those are fixed I have no issues with this game so far._______ ONE MORE THING_______"Eternity was created to give you, our fans, an opportunity to revisit Etheria while allowing us at Trendy to test an alpha version of playverse, the server technology that will host Dungeon Defenders II. This project has already undergone rigorous testing and feedback from a group of dedicated Defenders, and we can’t wait to continue improving and refining with the help of our entire community." - DD2 Blog - Please stop complaining about how this is the same as the original DD.

I'm seriously starting to think that this was a moblie verson that you just gave a fancy name and slapped it onto steam. Another thing, I spent years training my hero and you expect me to throw away all of that? If you want it because you want all the DLC like me, your going to be serverly dissapionted. If your the type of person mentioned above, dont even bother. If your someone new to the series and wants all the things mentioned above and doesnt mined all of the flawes i have mentioned, go right ahead. But from me, I would like to say if you put some notes saying that it isnt compatible with your old saves and that, then it would be fine. Don't disguise somthing as somthing it isnt is the moral of the story. If for the original you put a complete DLC pack for about £10-20 then you would have so many happy people buying it. in my opinion, don't bother, but those are my two cents and hey, i'm not gonna stop you if you want this.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Original review right after trying the game: "This game is what should have een a anti-hack patch on the original but instead turned out to be a copy of the original one in streaming version. The original game is fantastic. This one is a insult to every Dungeon Defenders fans out there. Trendy Entertainment lost me with this. There is nothing that is actually new. You may gain four maps, but you loose more. And now you have to pay with microtransaction stuff that you already bought with the original game. That's a big Up yours from Trendy."Review few months later with more objectivity (Still subjective): Pros: - Good game concept (reference of the Original Dungeon Defenders here) - Fun and active gameplay - Different classes that you can play - Has loot - Has leveling - Has character statistics  - You can see your gear on your character (difference from the original game)Cons:  - It's a game made of streaming - It's a pale copy of the original - Missing good elements or the original - Has microtransaction (For a copy that you have to pay for of a game you probably already have paid for it's ridiculous to not even have access to all the old content without paying again and again) - It is called the "Definitive Edition" even though it's a downsized version of an amazing game - Every map you play for the first time takes longer to load since the game is being streamed.  - It is sold like it has more content that the complete version of the original even though it has less. - You can only play online - You don't have your own tavern anymore so the one that is used as a lobby is always full of people, making it harder to browse your stuff, manage your inventory and test your DPS on the dummies - The "new arranged stuffs" from that game to make the game work proprely and prevent hacking and cheating should have been an update to their original game, not a copy - There is more negative stuffs on this game that left my mind at the moment, I will add more if the tought of the game ever cross my mind againConclusion :If you really want to play that game I strongly reccomend to wait for the orignal complete package to come back on sale. It worth the 12$ or so. The original game alone is still fun, but this particular version is frankly a rip off. Of course, everything stated in here is a personal opinion. (Excuse the english mistakes, it is not my main language)

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Before I mention what's good or bad about the game I think the reason this game was made should be stated.The main reason this game was made is to hype up Dungeon Defenders 2 and to also test their playverse system.So with that fact lets move to the pros, cons and they idk.pros:complete player reset, some wont find to this be a pro but this allows for new players to have a better multiplayer experience.gear rework, they've managed to even out the gear progession so that becoming level 74 or higher doesn't make you a god in dungeon defenders with mythical etc.New maps, who can complain about a few more maps and bosses.visible armour, It's a small pro but its makes every character look unique which is always goodopen tavern, Now this is a con if you prefer to be on your own but if you're like me a prefer to socialise it's a big plus.loot rework, They've made it so the loot that someone sees is invisible to everyone else meaning that some of the more greedy players can no longer go around spamming e.The ability to charge, I'm an extremely slow tower squire right now so the fact that I can charge helps alot for moving around the map it also allows you to leap backwards to dodge an enemy attack helping in close range combat.You can also play at 4% allowing thos who can't wait for it to fully download to jump right in and play though you will experience slow loading times as 96% percent of the content hasn't even been downloaded.(Those of you who say It's 25% are wrong as the download to 25% is 51mb but the whole download is 1.61gb meaning It's 4%.)Cons:The enemy pathing is terrible I've noticed that enemies will not walk in the right path and will instead walk in circles at times.The loot you find isn't always for your class, many times I've found a awesome sword to only realise it's a small monk weapon.This may be a personal con but I hate the fact that the tavern keeper no longer sells weapons or armour.buffs, agian this might be a personal thing but the fact that you can buy bombs etc makes it feel like the tower strategy has been made slightly easier.For thos who have never bought Dungeon defenders have to pay 20 while I should be 15 euro out of sale(I'm from Ireland so I only have the Irish price.)If you want to play a private game they make you wait through a 33 second timer.They made the gui aimed towards phones making it akward to use. once you learn the shortcut keys it is slightly easier to useThe idk:The fact that people can't host games is both a good and bad thing as It helps players find other players who want to play the same map but it also makes it very hard to setup a party of players who can work together properly e.g my first public game was throne room but  when I join my party was me and 3 barbarians luckily I could carry the team with my towers but if I had never joined that team was doomed from the start.There is microtransactions but they are emotes and in all my time playing Dungeon Defenders I don't think I ever used an emote so I can't say they're a good or bad thing.Conclusion:This game is in a grey zone as you can't call it a cash grab from dungeon defender fans as It's 6 euro right nowbut you also can't call it a new game as even though it has new things It's still the same game at its core.If your a fan of dungeon defenders you'll probably buy it anyway but if your a new comer think it through before you buy it as I think the 20 euro price tag is too high for a game that was released 3 years ago.
