number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Dungeon Defenders Eternity is a bit of a surprise to most. A game that changes up the multiplayer aspect of the original Dungeon Defenders game to better protect itself from cheating (which was apparently a huge concern for the original game) is now caught in ethical crossfire as to whether or not it should be a free update or what-have-you regarding those who owned it.In the end it doesn't matter. A game stands at $19.99 for a redeveloped online-only release of Dungeon Defenders using the same back-end that Dungeon Defenders 2 will use. Is it fun? Very much so. Just like the original game I've found myself addicted to the game and found it even cutting into sleep these past few days.Build Towers, defend crystal, level up, get stats, fight again with a harder map or difficulty. DDE supposedly improves this aspect by making a rebalance pass on items, making it a little more fair when it comes to upgrades. While I didn't have trouble in the first game, it is nice to know things were looked at a second time.As far as items go, you now have them actually displayed on your character. Get a helmet for your summoner? Shows in game. All these items can also be dyed, which in turn gives a much more personal touch on the game as you play through.  Pets also have a new mechanic that allows you to find eggs and hatch them. While so far it feels like an extra step to the process of obtaining gear, I have a strong suspicion that there is more to it than first appears.Some new content has also been added. Challenges and maps that are supposed to be a bridge from Dungeon Defenders and it's sequel while allowing you to earn gear for when Dungeon Defenders 2 comes out. This is interesting as I personally can't wait to see what challenges there will be.Since the game is online-only, there are some issues with performance. Server latency can impact the game as can disconnects in the newly tuned Hardcore mode.  This also means those with poorer quality connections may have trouble with this version of the game, however this was done with the intent of keeping all user data server-side to prevent tampering. For those that were frustrated about the cheating going on in the first game, this may be the solution (though admittedly it may cause a bit of grinding teeth since it isn't a patch.)If you haven't played Dungeon Defenders before, now is a great time to get into it. $19.99 and you get almost all the content that was released in the first game, plus a little more in a secure environment. For those who owned the first game and its DLC, it becomes a much more difficult decision. Did you want a safe environment to play, or did you stick to solo or private matches in the first place? Where you frustrated with balance issues in later game modes?At $10.99 it's hard to recommend to existing players if they truly didn't have issues with the first game. However, at a lower price (like at the time of this review) it's much easier to make a compromise and move up for $5.99 instead.I like the game and while some of this business leaves a bad taste in my mouth, it's hard to not enjoy what time I have with it.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												A good game ? Yes. Better than the original ? No.DD-E is basically the same game with a variety of details changed, some for the better, some for the worse - And probably which is which is based on taste. My love for DD has always been its tower defense part and the long progression system, while running around and shooting stuff for hours was never my thing.Anyways, to the good and the bad based on my taste:Good: Every map and mode needs to be unlocked - I love this mechanic, it gives you a feeling of accomplisment as you unlock stuff that yesterday were too hard for you.Balanced better than the original - I can only speak for how far I am at this point.True hardcore mode - Perma death, although I wouldnt dare it till I have backup armor sets and a character to take over.Crafting - nice addition although I have seen nothing I would like to actually craft yet.No longer shared loot - no need to fear others picking up your Ultimates.Re-learning tactics, classes and everything - Just pretty fun process especially in a game that is still the best TD/Defense/FP cross genre game to date.All classes, most maps, even a few new maps - All for a fair price.Bad:No pure strategy - My favorite mode.Based too much on co-op - I do love co-op, but I the mindless shooting monsters for hours is boring, and with so many maps requiring those 3+ players doing just that to finish them.. Unfortunately this is the direction DD2 is also taking but owell its their game.Clunky UI - Or rather some stuff took me long to find out how to work, for example bulk selling, hatching and then click info and hatch again to make the pet useable.Too many consumables and combat things I will never use.Coins - Unnessesary. I preferred the mana system, one currency for all.Still way too many drops, and it still dissapear pretty fast if you don't pick it up.. One of the things I think they should have improved while at it.Having to download 1.5Gb every time you start (after a reboot) the game - This is utterly stupid, period.Details:Mobs getting stuck (for example in City in Cliffs) don't always time out and making that particular map mostly unplayable.Tower placement areas have changed, some towers require less space, but all in all good because it forced me to re-think tower placement tactics.Summoners now use DU.. I am not sure if this is good or bad but it removes the need to always have a summoner.Better anti-cheat, moot point. In DD playing trendy net I didn't experience it as beeing a problem, infact in my 800 hours played I have never seen a duped item for sale.Although the original DD is a better game, this is better prices and lets face it, with this release the original will die, so move along and embrace the future, good and bad.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Eternity is a remake/remaster of the original Dungeon Defenders. While it's got some changes (some of which I'd prefer to have remained unchanged), the core gameplay is the same. The game is rebalanced, equipment generation has been rewritten, and a lot of complaints have been addressed. Only a few maps were taken out, and new maps have replaced those ones, and there's a new campaign to be discovered. I don't like how the tavern is shared now, and I wish you could still customize character color, but other than that, complaints are few and far between. It's effectively the Game of the Year edition for Dungeon Defenders, and those who loved the first game may not even mind starting all over from scratch. Especially since the new servers and the Playverse are all Trendy. So right now, in the beginning, is most likely the worst they'll ever be.Edit:As the game is being updated, I feel I should update the review. The game continues to be a fun and exciting experience, obviously better with friends. Apart from the occasional hiccup in server activity and a few glitches here and there, everything is running smoothly, and I'm very happy with the game. It's getting better, and I still recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Dungeon Defenders Eternity is a revamped version of the original Dungeon Defenders. Owners of the original Dungeon Defenders can purchase this game for a discount, giving all the more reason to purchase this game. Upon hearing of it's release, I bought it immediately, despite the criticism it had gained over the first few hours of it's launch. I can certainly say that some of the complaints were justified, but most of the main problems have been patched out of the game, along with balance tweaks and more. Micro-transactions are contained within the game, but are only tied to cosemtic taunts in game, that do nothing to benefit the player, other than look cool. Dungeon Defenders Eternity also comes with most of the DLC from the original game, including all the characters, the Lost Eternia Shards DLC, and the start of a new campaign. It also contains the ability to transfer items to the upcoming game Duneon Defenders II. This game gets a solid 8/10, and is recommended to purchase over the original Dungeon Defenders, both to DD veterans, and beginners alike.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												What this game really is:This is Dungeon Defenders with all the DLC unlocked, but now requires you to be online to play.  If you check out Trendy's website you will see that they did this as a re-release to test the overlay system (accessed by f11) for the upcoming DD2.  I see a lot of people complaining about the $6 price.  $6 is a bargain for the amount of hours you will play this!  I've gifted 2 copies already!This version adds a real cash store:  Currently the only things you can buy are emotes for your characters. Currently NOT pay to win.  The cash store is not a big deal.  I fail to see what all the complaints are about.If you loved the first but got burnt out because of all the hacks/mods then you'll want to try this.  It's starting fresh all over again.  Is it a new game? I'd say no, but definitely worth the $6 to start fresh and play unmodded with ALL DLC unlocked.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												At first look it seemed like a un-needed mobile-esque update to the original HOWEVER, and there is a however, after approximately 2 hours of playing my Series-EV char 'Clanketta' I realised that I was far more interested than I had originally thought, despite the odd UI in the item box and hero inventory the game is still capturing some of the original DD flare with new additions that are a huge plus to the experience.The first thing that really caught my attention was the eggs, I love being able to fight through the horde to find, and loot a pet egg, look at its stats and try to guess what it will be. Having to incubate an egg by fighting with it equipt and waiting (im)patiently for it to be ready to hatch was a lot of fun, I have a seperate folder in my Item box for eggs and pets, I currently have a Shoddy Shroomite with 22 upgrade levels, which is great as you dont invest coin to upgrade them, but fight alongside them to get XP for them.Secondly was the addition of visable armour, nothing surprised me more than noticing I had not only the witch kings great helm on, but a tiny little crown sitting atop it, not the most ferocious looking but still novel and fun, adding dyes to armours and skins was a interesting edition as I can finally get back into the customization of my character and I actually have to work towards it.The game has enough new features to outweigh the current teething problems on the serverside with the occasional drops and inability to join games (sorted by hosting private and publicizing it). With responsive and active dev teams working on the community highlighted issues (such as the odd UI) I feel that given time DDE will be the true 'definitive' version we were promised.Many negative reviews are given from the perspective of those who like DD and refuse to accept any variance from their accepted view of what is "right" for the series, however after logging several hours in both games I have found that most of the faults they find are all without any real impact other than the server problems which is common across nearly all new releases.In conclusion, given time, this should prove to be more of a gem than people are giving it credit for.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Not sure why this is getting such bad reviews. This is everything Dungeon Defenders 1 was, and more! Player instanced loot and chests are an amazing addition, saving the grief from ninja looters in public games. Plus, currency is Gold instead of Mana, meaning you can spam your Mana in-game without having to worry about the cost. Blueprints are available as drops for crafting which is aother great feature. The micro-transactions in-game are strictly for cosmetic items, but that's to be expected in this day of Microtransactions. A lot of complaints were also targetted at the fact that you apparently can't create Private games, which isn't true. It may be a recent addition, but since I bought the game there is an option to create a private game just for you and your friends - You're not forced to play with random players. For £4.50 for Dungeon Defenders 1 owners, it's well worth it. It's just a fresh take on the game with some great additions, balance and bug fixes.The negatives are the fact that the game features it's own Always-Online DRM, meaning you're relying on their servers for a good connection - I'm used to this having played Diablo III for a long time. Plus, the UI is a clunky and could do with some work here and there, but it's nothing game-breaking. Don't let all of the overracting negative reviews put you off, I'm sure glad I didn't. The game has been out for 5 days, there are still some fixes they have to make and they're working fast. I have faith!This game will definitely whet my appetite until Dungeon Defenders 2 comes out, and I'm pretty sure they have a few more features still to come!

												I was skeptical of this at first, with 600 hours in DD1, hating the RNG/end-game MASSIVE grind. but so far I'm super pleased with this.Pros:- All DLC is included (Although holiday dlc maps seem to not be in it), which means all that we no longer get the classic "Oh damn, I haven't bought that map/character"- New equipment slots like a shield slot for everyone, two weapon slots allowing a backup elemented weapon (Like Series EV/Jester in Vanilla)4 new maps (And probably more coming)- So far the item RNG seems to be better (Can't tell because I haven't reached end-game yet)- Equipment actually shows on your character (I think you can turn this option off)- Mana is no longer the out of combat currency, enemies (and chests, and sold loot) now gives Gold Coins!- New slots for Consumables and Amulets that give you up to 4 new skills to use in battle, ranging from a simple health potion(Consumed on use!) to an amulet that lets you summon a thunder storm (With a cooldown of 60s)- Each pet now comes with it's own activated ability. i.e. Engineer lets you do a blast repair in an area, or the Heavy lets you buff you and surrounding allies' Hero damage for a period of time!- Summoner's Minions now use Defense Unit(DU) instead of having their own Unit pool. I think this is a plus because I felt we were being forced to use Minions as they effectively doubled (Or even triple since you don't need to use up half their points as walls) your defense strength / amount of placeable towers for damage.- All loot is instanced! No more loot ninjas! All Chests are instanced to you (and whatever come sout of them), I think dropped mana from enemies is NOT instanced though! So be fair for that, but all other loot, go nuts!- New Dash feature that lets you do some quick jumps ala UT/Quake style! (Although you have a stamina bar and right now you can only do it via the ctrl key, so no double tapping a direction for now)Cons:- It costs extra (But overall it's cheaper for new players, and 70% off for owners of DD1 now, which I feel is fair as the dev's have obviously put in a bunch of effort.- Always online (I think this is ALSO a plus, stops hackers, allows you to play while the big/highrez textures stream in (First time only, so expect some blurry textures at first but trust me they do get better)- In-App Purchases (But these are purely costmetic, right now they're just $1 emotes)- Public Tavern (Which is actually really good for some people but for me it causes big lag)- Slow internet means you will get lag, no matter your settings in game, but I think it's bareable. (Like mine, damn having bad internet in Australia)- Having to start from scratch even though you might have already spent hundreds of hours in DD1- Splitscreen/Local Co-Op has been removed. (I'm hoping for it to return though, as this is a huge con for me)- Survival Mode is forced "Continuous" which means (at the moment) No switching characters, and no chance to either stop, go pee/sammich/greet loved ones or, for the slow ones out there like me, loot/upgrade/repair without worrying of a DEW stabbing you in the♥♥♥♥♥♥- Textures start off super low res (But this is so you can get in the game faster) and download overtime as you play (As do maps), this can cause extra lag and make the game look very bad graphically, but just give it time and those sweet sweet graphics we've come to know and love will come rushing in! (It's a first time thing for everything, but after that first time everything will already be downloaded and therefore not a blurry low-res mess.All in all, I'm glad I bought it and will continue to play (hoping end-game RNG is fixed so we don't get max level gear with -50 stats)EDIT: I will be updating this as I experience new/more parts of the game!

												The extra modes and maps more than justify the price, even if you already own the previous dungeon defenders title, as someone who personally commented and aided in one of the first official reviews of the first game, i can say without a doubt that this game is one of the best indie games on sale today in the tower defence genre.Even when youve beaten the game in all its modes and difficulties, there is nothing to stop you from doing so with the other classes you can choose, if you are a completionist, or strives for the most awesome loot for a particular character, and being able to do it with friends, comparitively with games such as torchlight, diablo, titan quest, but put it into the form of a third person tower defence game, then this game will scratch that itch for you, with its charm, light humour, and mindless destruction of all the foes you may face!

												I've played Dungeon Defenders before, and although it's a fun game, once you get past The Summit, it's no longer fun. In the first game, I found it wierd that the equipped armor doesn't show up on your character, but they finally included that. Over it's a great game.(9/10 Stars)

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												Now that the early problems have gone here is an update for people who have already played DD.Imagine the original formula of DD revampedHere is what to expec1) Currency is now Coins instead of mana2) Crafting system is done with blue prints and items that you find within game3) Chests are now for individual players, instead of people fighting over chests to build stuff every person sees there own instance of chests.4) Items are now only visible to a player, each player will only see items that have specifically dropped for them5) You can get eggs which do hatch into pets, doesnt take that long to hatch them either.6) Coins can be gained quite easily.7) The monetisation shop isn't as agressive as people are making it out to be, they are only for emotes so far. If they sell costumes from the DLC that we bought in DD1 then be very vocal about it.8) Gear is now visible.The current problem so far is server stability, it feels like a train wreck lag is more prone then before and it all feels rushed. The GUI needs some work, the side bar stuff is fine but the party notifications and what not is just a simple ugly white popup screen that might as well have comic sans on it.The cross platform stuff is going to possibly get on a lot of peoples nerves, firstly they implemented the download system soley to cater to mobile/cell/tablet users and secondly I can forsee dropouts occuring left right and centre. What I do like is the ability to play in the browser just incase you have one of those off days where steam is having a tantrum. just to note: you also have to buy the android/ipad? versions . I dont know why they just didn't make it free and use the login system to verify if they have a valid license. Original Early ImpressionEarly Impression: This is by no means a final representation of the final product. Just an initial reaction.1) Logged in2) Downloaded Playverse3) Checked the options (All was semi decent here, not great but there was sliders with no numerical value but that doesn't bother me)4) Added a friend to playverse5) Eventually got into the same tavern6) Tavern was in very low textures, I've seen better minecraft texture packs (Yes you are warned about this when loading into the tavern) Had to wait a while for the textures to download.7) Not all the textures downloaded and now stuck attempting to download some "Movie: The New Generation" infinity back to 0% random loop that never exceeds 10%8) Started up a game, Waiting in queue9) Started singing in chat "99 bottles of beer on the wall" With a fellow welcoming random player10) someone interupted the song.11) 45 mins later decided to jump out of the game as I refused wait any longer.Im giving this a thumbs up due to knowing that the core game is already solid.I have a few issues on if I'll be asked to purchase DLC that I've already purchsed and wether this stupid download system will at least be optional. I get it, some people are impatient, They are also the same kind of people who will give negative feedback due to its obvious side effects (Low res textures)Will update this as time progresses. I bought this game on the soul purpose to help fund DD2, that's how I am treating this.Edit 1: Playverse 2.0 Update: I am now downloading the files, from the start, again. Wasn't this issue resolved with binary updates in DD1? (Can't remeber the exact terminology used)

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Tavern is partly black and can only see some heroes and lights. Maps can appear teal and or things look transparent.A1: Make sure you are running the latest Nvidia drivers and not any beta drivers.A2: Change your NVIDIA control panel so that no settings are forced onto the game. Instructions on how to do that below:1. Open the NVIDIA Control panel.2. Under 3D settings select "Manage 3D settings".3. With the Global Settings tab selected4. Look through the list until you see "Antialiasing- Mode".5. Change this to "Application-control".6. Apply and then start up DDE again.

number of helpful: 11 of 26 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Hello, After seeing all of the reviews I wanted to write up my own little intake on the game thus far!To clarify. Micro transactions are to purchase EMOTES, not entire skins (thus far). When i launched the game i had all previous skins from the last game and some extras i had never purchased. alongside that all classes are able to be played with no additional purchase.There is 4 -5 new maps in the game currently, in addition to all the previous maps from the last game. On the website it states "And more to come" meaning there will be new maps made for this game in addition to what is avalible.The new UI is not terrible in my opinion, it takes time to adjust to and find out how it works, however once you figure out how it works it is fine. There is more armor slots in this game, with loot being purely for you. For example, the loot sysytem is similar to diablo where it only drops for you, only you can pick it up. this also applies to the chests before a map begins!To begin with the private server / SP option was disabled, but as the news update mentions, it has been re enabled and shall remain enabled. Trendy wanted to lower costs due to the fact the servers are hosted elsewhere to prevent hacking / cheating. However they realise this is a big mistake and have thusly rectified it.The gameplay is smooth, connection is also quite smooth. Here is a key bit of information - The game is mostly streamed, however I do not believe it streams the map EVERY TIME you want to play it. I believe it streams it the first time you load it and then you keep the file downloaded - This is most likely done to prevent an overload of downloads occuring and thus stressing the servers. It really isn't a hugely bad feature, it staggers people but not in a way that harms them playing the game or having access to it.All in all, yes DD2 may be close, however this is essential DD1, With all the old classes and skins, New maps, A better loot system, Visible armors (my personal favorite as i love to customise), New pets with abilities, Dyes to change the look of items,  New abilities that can be picked up and used in game (that scale off of two new stats, Hero Defensive Abillity and Heroes Offensive abillity)I would reccomend this game simply for the fact the new systems are interesting, it has been rebalanced to allow all classes to be viable for either DPS or for tower building, its not hugely expensive for what it is and micro transactions relaly has no influence on this game what so ever!

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												   While the game did have a bit of a rocky launch (no single player/ private games, blurry texture problems, etc.), much of these problems have already patched out within the first day. While I'm not 100% sure I could reccomend this game to those who have countless hours on DD classic I can say that I would reccomend this to either new players or those who just want a good reason to get back into played DD. The good: pets and accessories are more common, all classes are available, re-balanced gameplay, amulets and consumable items for quick skills, DLC campaigns and mission are included, new campaign and missions, new textures and looks for characters, enemies, and items.The bad: Game doesn't download everything at once and will instead download files as you play and get to new levels, overly crowded tavern as your hub, game could better explain controls.The meh: micro-transactions for emotes (this would be in the bad if they weren't pretty usless micro-transactions).

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												For all this hate this game is getting I thought that when I bought it I made a horrible mistake but I am glad I bought this. To clear things right away this isn't a pay to win game there are microtransactions but they for emotes for costumes, costumes are not bought with real money. I bought this for 6 dollars since I already have the first one and its a bit better than the first one. The game has some bugs but its only been out for a bit and they seem to be getting fixed, Also there is single player now but no offline which is fine for me because as much as I want to believe that I would play this offline I probably would not since I usually have an internet connection and I still have the first one. For those that havent bought the game I feel that is a great deal since it comes with all the characters and dlc with the exception of a few maps but it does come up with extra maps. I haven't gotten to far into this game so I am not sure how the game was balanced but overall I am glad I bought this game and the changes are very welcome. Also another thing I really have to note is I have to thank the developers for being so involved with the community and addressing all the problems. Apparently the issue with textures and constantly downloading are fixed and local single player will be added soon so the developers are listening and trying to fix many of the issues players like myself are having.

number of helpful: 8 of 20 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												All the initial backlash to this game was blown way out of proportion.The online DRM is there but it actually works incredibly well. The UI seems kind of pasted on to the game but I've been matchmaking with 1-3 other friends and parties work fine and I've had no connection issues with about 5 hours of playing. The login is painless, doesn't require an email confirmation or really much of anything to get it to work. Steam remembers the information and you don't have to input it everytime you want to play. I saw a comparison of it to GFWL and almost laughed. It works great and even has Twitch integration (which I'll never use, but it's there).Singleplayer is present and works fine. This was not the case at launch but was fixed the day of release, mainly due to people being upset about its absence. As far as complaints of it being a ported mobile game I don't see this at all. I admittedly haven't played the original DD in about 2 years but the graphics fidelity is perfectly fine and doesn't seem any worse or better than before. I haven't done a side by side comparison, but it looks really good.My biggest complaint is the convultued inventory and character screens. Their messy and confusing and use icons for stats rather than just saying what it does. Locking and unlocking items is bizarre and crafting seems promising but I don't really understand it too well yet. Once a wiki comes out I'm sure it'll be easier to get it all down. As for the gameplay itself, it's a tweaked and polished DD. It's fun, it's intense, it's colorful, and it just works. I don't know what DLC is or isn't included, but I didn't own much in the original and there's definitely plenty of content for 6 bucks (what I paid) or the 15 or 20 it's going to be for new players. Definitely worth it.Get it.

number of helpful: 8 of 20 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												After playing for a few hours, and being someone who's put well ovber 1000 hours into the last game, I must recommend it for new and returning defenders.Everything has been completely rebalanced! You move through all the levels with ease, I don't really feel any need to farm (Currently) as the dropped gear during the campaign so far has been enough for me. I also enjoy that you cannot skip difficulties with ease, you should probably play from normal to hard to insane in that order.The new survival mode is fantastic! It's a big improvement over the monogrinding done in the first game where you'd AFK. The new survival will keep you on your toes, and provide amazing loot!With the new amulets and spells, you can change up your character and playstyle, giving you the feeling of breaking that samey-same feeling of doing map after map. And pets now have an active ability, giving you even more to do!The game didn't come without it's flaws. I don't think I need to point out the initial issue, that's a dead horse. IT would have been nice to have a list of changes, as there's been a ton of unnanounced ones, such as changes to the monk auras. The UI was very confusing and intimidating initially as well.A lot of people complain that it should be free. I do agree, it should have been free for previous owners, but at the same time I support Trendy, and don't mind paying a miniscule fee for this amazing game. I do expect there to be further discounts for owning both previous games when I buy DD2. Seriously, there's no choice there, there must be a discount, because I'm not made of money!

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												*Seriously do not waste your money on this game*I bought this based soley on my experience with the original Dungeon Defenders. I tried very hard to view this subjectively. After I restarted the game multiple times due to playverse time-outs (server overloaded?) I finally got into a MMO style "tavern" surrounded by other players jumping on my head, shooting at me and swinging whatever various weapons they had in my general direction.  At least I think they were other players, couldn't tell with all the blurry low res textures.  This game looks like somebody replaced my eyes with petroleum jelly.  But ok no problem, private tavern time... Wait no private tavern? No private game? What? What?!This seems to be a poorly retooled PC port of a mobile version of Dungeon Defenders aimed towards complete cross platform compatibility, based on the lowest common denominator (e.g. smartphones).  In and of itself this is not a terrible prospect.  However when you are on the other side of the spectrum it feels insulting.  The gameplay needs a little work, currently clunky, bug ridden and the LAG, I haven't experienced lag this bad since I played Counter Strike on a 28.8k dial up with AOL.  The textures stream in and are very low resolution anyway, so I'm not sure why they bother streaming anything at all.  At first I thought it was my video settings, then I realized that it was not my video settings and the devs intended the game to look this bad.  (note to devs; blur, bloom, fuzzy glow lighting, does not make bad textures look better, it's like putting make-up on a hippo...) What did I just waste my money on?As far as this being the definitive Dungeon Defenders experience I was promised? No. Just no. God no...  This is an embarassment, to put it simply this is a mobile orientated microtransaction cashgrab.  The exact kind of shenanigans I'd expect from a company like EA.  Needless to say with a pile of garbage like this, I will be looking at the upcoming Dungeon Defenders 2 under a microscope and I guarantee if it looks anything like this pile of trash, I will not be wasting my money.Buy the original Dungeon Defenders (and dlc).  Bury this. (looks like♥♥♥♥♥ plays like♥♥♥♥♥ in-game money transactions) Boo!

number of helpful: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												There's a lot of hate concerning this game. It goes pretty deep, and it can be very depressing, as many people reading, viewing.. or doing anything, may just find the community is just upset. Not quite thinking, everyone has their own perspective- even I. I'm not correct.But, Dungeon Defenders Eternity, is a gem. It is.. A polished perhaps enhanced version of the original. It is not a port from a mobile game. I've played considerable amount of hours now, and the game just plays wonderfully well. It's rather spectacular too.It does have initial launch day bugs. July 22, was a big of a mess, with all the screams for 'lack of single player'. But to be fair, there are numerous reasons. The claimed one was monetary- not many people would outright talk about money as a developer- or publisher. Not to your playerbase.That's a taboo in it's self, but it did cause damage, as you expected. Many people took that to heart, but there is.. another reason. An always-online game. Does have it's faults, and every game that we've ever seen 'always-on' had issues with servers. So far, the servers have been great.Trendy has been very good with the servers, and perhaps can- and will be doing some expansion to it all. But the growth of the game is dependant on us, the consumer. The game it's self is.. What you would expect. Dungeon Defenders.There are some 'holiday' and 'seasonal' DLC content missing, here and there. Some of the costumes are still around, but some of that content was incredibly buggy-  at least to the point.. That some balanced will still be needed.  But for $20 or $6, or whichever your regional equilvalent is. The price is right.Dungeon Defenders Eternity, is NOT a port. It is clearly designed on PC, for PC. And it functions well, runs smooth, and is very enjoyable. There are some tweaks as of writing, the game needs to grow, and to grow. We need to think constructively. What is fair is,  If you're new to the game.. $20 is worth the $100+ worth of DLC+ base game value of the original.It's a good way to get in the gate, if you like Action RPG's and Tower defense all in one, the game is an addicting mindless onslaught. But, the game is just that. A game, an experience that is worthwhile, and entertaining. It features who things from the original, it is not just some super-awesome bugfix, it contains a plethora of features that makes it unique and definitive of it's own, it balances things in ways that were broken. Perhaps for the best. The game is still changing, and growing.But There's a light to be found, if one can look at it, constructively, It is a wholelly enjoyable experience. Playverse may be seen as  "Always On" DRM, but so is Steam.  There seems to be implications an offline mode is being worked on- for seperate files. Much like the old DD which had it's 'non ranked' and 'ranked' mode. Where the latter provided you with  achievements and server side characters- and all that.The game is very enjoyable, infact I've already sunk quite a bit of time into it, and will be putting even more.  It's rekindled a flame of the game I've long since lost, and really.  It has problems, but. Constructively voice the problems, find a way to explain it, and attempt a solution. If you play the game for the first time, this game COULD very well redefine a moment in your life of enjoyment, but perhaps not. The game's grind is much more forgiving, and everything seems just about right. So, if you read these words.  Know that It is a good game. It is worth it's price, assets vs price. Maybe bundled into a new image.Performance wise, it runs smoother, better and absolutely just great.  Here's to helping the game grow, and perhaps a different perspective to be adopted when evaluating things. Enjoy the moment. And be a bit more aware of whats going on around you,  the answer is much clearer.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												TL;DR - Everything Dungeon defenders orignal had + All DLC for the original + new DLC & game restructure, combined for a tiny fraction of the price. #worthFirstly, for those who don't know, This game includes everything from Dungeon Defenders Original + all their DLC released for that game. That totals to a value of £40 (~$67). This game also adds new maps (at least 4) and with the promise of more to come. They also have many new features that run throughout the game. They are only selling it for £15 (~$25) full price, with the game being on sale at the moment + the added discount for anyone who bought the Original game it is currently 70% off so it only costs £4.50.. what an absolute bargain.At first glance you might think, "How can they sell this as a new game? Is it not the same as the original?". In short, No.Here's why, the main reason this game is sold as a seperate game, is because they are trialing their new secure server system for DDII. The reason behind the servers is to intercept cheaters trying to modify any loot or equipment that they get. This was and still is a huge problem in the Original Dungeon Defenders game. The problem got so bad there that cheated items were being sold everywhere, mana could be generated and had no value, people were trading with items only obtainable from end game challenge maps. The cheaters essentially ruined the economy of the game as well as cheating and ruining the fun.There are also several new features that run throughout the core of Dungeon Defenders Eternity (DDE). There is a new currency, "gold coins" they drop in game, from minions and from selling loot to the shop (or letting drops auto sell after waves). Many ignorant reviews of this game popped up as soon as it came out saying this was a pay to win item mall. It is not. The only items in the shop that appear to be sold for real life money are Emotions / Actions, which are costume specific animations a character can do ingame.Another new feature that runs through out this game, is the visual update to every piece of equipment your character is wearing and the new models for them. With this comes a selection of Dyes to recolour the equipment (bought with Gold coins not real money).The game feels so fresh and crisp, the characters have been rethought about and rebalanced so they scale appropriately. Text isnt continuously spammed in the center of your screen when certain minions arrive (a noise prompt is still there for those that relied on that). The minions have been rebalanced and they now have levels for easier understanding of their strength. There is a new pet system, involving eggs and hatching them, with the new pets comes pet abilities! Also characters have slots for amulets that also give you abilities to use to help defend. Consumables are sold in the in game shop (for gold coins not real money) and they can be used in game to help you defend on the tougher maps. The same consumables and Dyes etc also have a chance of dropping in game, during waves from minions. Nothing about this game is pay to win.Trendy is a very intereactive developer and will listen to the community and respond, this game is evidence of that. On the first day of release people were upset there was no Private lobby (unsure as to why, probably and oversight) and on the same day as they released the game they patched it adding Private lobbies and refining the match making system. They continue to strive to make their games the best experience possible for the user.There's alot more I could go into about how much I enjoy this game over the original, but if you havent been persuaded by what has been said already then I guess there's no point going on. I would suggest ignoring any bad review with a play time length under 1-2 hours. As I am posting this review I have played 15hours+ and I have enjoyed every minute.TL;DR - Everything Dungeon defenders orignal had + All DLC for the original + new DLC & game restructure, combined for a tiny fraction of the price. #worth

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Lovely game, obviously similar to the original Dungeon Defenders. Although the gameplay is pretty much the same, they switched out mana for gold when buying items, a new thing where you equip and hatch eggs you find into pets, as well as the interesting (although sometimes hilariously hideous) cosmetic changes with equipment. The option to dye the skins is a lot of fun to fool around with, although I miss the good ole days of being able to make the actual skincolor of the character's skin pink and black and all those random colors. The inventory system is a bit more complex, not to mention a little cluttered, from having to always see every single piece you have equipped on the main screen. Overall, a fun, updated experience. If you think $6 for an updated game you most likely enjoyed before (hence why you're looking at this game) is too much, pass it on by. It's similar, but for the price, it's as though you bought a cool updated DLC. I know I spent more on DLC for the past DD than this game itself.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												There has been a lot of negative reviews for this game, mostly by people who are uninformed and have played for .5 hours. Expectations have been met for me, they have combatted the hacking issue from DD1 which was my biggest reason why I stopped playing DD1. I orginally played DD on Ps3 2012, then I transitioned to the PC version with my friend and now with Eternia I am happy with how far this game has come. I actually like the Playverse system and how the game is online based. Hacking/Modding gear/weapons in DD1 really killed the game for me and most others. They have added some cool new features that we didn't see in DD1 (see above in game description). Granted there are some bugs and server issues, but what game has had a 100% launch without issues? There may be a handful of them but its annoying how people throw this game under the bus when they fail to realize that the Devs have worked diligently and have fixed issues VERY quickly since launch. I have high hopes for this game and for anyone concidering to buy it, you should. For the cost of a slice of pizza how could you go wrong? If you enjoyd DD1, DD:E is a lot of fun so far and it has great potential. To all those who are throwing out their negative opinions and rants, I can understand some of your frustrations but get over it and move on to the next game on your steam list. Cheers~J

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Frankly, I love DD Eternity. I put a decent amount of time (173 hours) into the first Dungeon Defenders and loved it, but eventually stopped playing it. The fact that this game offers all the DLC together with the base game as a single package is just a bonus on top of the awesome gameplay.A lot of the reviews around ♥♥♥♥♥ about being unable to play solo or the multiplayer taverns. Solo and private sessions have been promised, with the private sessions already having been delivered. And solo is fine too, all you have to do is start a private session without anybody in your Playverse party.My only real gripe with the game is the new Playverse system. It has another overlay entirely on the game, which is rather clunky. I mean, in order to play with my friend, I have to make a party, invite him, and he has to make a party too before he can join? What? Also, the game is a bit confusing at first. Tooltips and a tutorial, perhaps, would be great for newbies. I could barely figure out how to change my character's name when I first started the game up, since there were no tooltips.Overall, while the clunky new overlay and lack of clear tips hinder new players and veterans alike, they don't particularly reduce the fun you can have with this game. I give it an 8.5 / 10, and damn is it fun.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												I have mixed feeling about DDE. For $5.99 you are getting a good deal if you still like the game. First of all the game has QOL changes like you can move around when in top view tower build mode; you can switch from upgrade tower to repair without leaving the top view mode; and separate mana chest for every character so u don't have to worry about trolls looting all your mana and quit the game; barbarian can now share his mana from mana chest to teammates now, he is less useless in building phase; tool tips in hero abilities to show what they actually does instead of blind guessing, etc.  These are some examples of the good changes.The bad changes are nerfing buff beam... now a maxed tier buff beam only provide a minger 6% damage boost( lv 27 tower EV) and no longer provide tower speed boost;  Spike trap now does electric damage; start up summoner can't even solo deeper wall normal.  repairing towers take forever and tons of mana, espectially on deeper wall.. Just feels like the game is a patch of DD1 that tries to fix some of the problems, but still ignoring the core weakness of most useless tower. Example being Slice N Dice, still being restricted range and damage interval, which just translate to useless endgame.  Also survival mode is extremely pointless as you have to survive a single 1 hr wave.. Hard Core mode is now Diablo Hard core mode, you die and will lose all equipped items and character, which basically creates disincentive for most players.  The most annoying thing is the 31 sec waiting period before you starts the game, it is a good thing to give time other players to stream the contents, but after everyone is done, the game should just starts.. this new 31 sec waiting time is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.BUT, if you own DD1, and with the special deal they have $5.99 is a pretty good deal because you basically get all the dlc except the holiday ones.  If you have to pay $19.99? You will be better to just look the other way, OR wait till DDE goes to humble bundle.==========================New edit... All character can use 2 weapons now, but only the active weapon add stats to your hero, suck big time

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Ah, Dungeon Defenders Eternity! We have a love hate relationship. I love the game, but I hate how addicted I become during my hardcore sessions!This is a tower defense and RPG hybrid that could almost be called a reverse MOBA.There are many lanes, crazy map layouts and plenty of heroes to choose from, but the goal is the same no matter what: Protect the crystals. If a single one is destroyed, it's game over.The general idea is to build tower defenses like any other tower defense game and defend the crystals, but the formula has never been done like this outside of Trendy's Dungeon Defenders series.The entire game is played from a third person perspective, and during combat, you can run around and fight enemies much like a hack and slash RPG, all while gaining experience points to level up, find awesome loot and become one of the few elite heroes that can destroy anything without any trouble.If you like tower defense games and you want to try a new spin on the genre with many new layers, give this game a shot! You likely wont regret it!

												You know, sometimes you just have to get past your first impression of someone without labeling them.  People got a bit overly histaric and are leading people to believe this is an awful game in a shell of its former self.  Initially I thought so, we had issues connect to games, the social UI is not a seamless part of the experience, and there was no hope of single player. The core game itself is still here and there are some neat new features.  The talk of the a cash shop is a bit overblown, the only thing you can buy is an emote for $1... but they've eliminated all of the cost for DLC in the meantime mind you.  All that aside, it's a game I paid $6 for.  Of course I recommend this, it's great fun despite a bit of clunkyness on it's new connection platform.  PS Trendy.  Everygame other game that has helmets and other visuals allows it to be optional to show.  Most of the masks and helmets look out of place and ruin the art direction of the great character models.  I don't want every character to look like Scorpion from Mortal Kombat.  Pls.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												After many, many hours in the first game, many of the improvements of it in Eternity shine through. In public matches I used to run into hackers a lot, as well as having a hard time getting over the hump of level 75. This game fixes all of this, and that alone makes the $6 worth it in my eyes. I have to guess that the reason it's a standalone game is because the engine and coding for the first was badly optimized, or they couldn't do much about people who already hacked the game, which I understand. With a fresh start, the game feels much more balanced and the introduction of consumables is neat.So, after playing for a while I noticed that boosters started to drop from enemies, for completely free. Experience, loot quality, loot quantity and what not. I thought that was really cool seeing how they aren't sold via micro-transactions. In fact, when I checked I was surprised that it's only taunts which are being sold, and the possibility of skins and heroes, which I find are fine seeing how that's what they did with the first game, nothing wrong with that. I also noticed that they are expanding the trading feature over Steam, which sounds great.Leveling does not seem to slow down at any rate as long as you're playing at correct levels for your character, it's been smooth leveling for me and my Initiate, who is level 46 currently. I used to have trouble leveling up in the first game as it forced you into Insane mode at around this point, but now I can ease in instead of having to deal with tough enemies. It also feels like I have less pressure of being a complete DPS or complete Tower hero with the new array of stats to level up. Although since I am an old player, I tend to stay towards just leveling up in towers since that is what I am used to.The UI can get a bit confusing but I get caught up to it after using it for a while. Some buttons are in weird places, and it seems to be a bit messy. I also had trouble loading in sometimes due to the streaming way of downloading the game, and textures sometimes bugged up for me. As far as I know though, both of this issues have been addressed and/or fixed, so that is good to hear at least.If I had any complaint of the game, it would be these: I would love an option to individually hide the armor pieces from your character. I hate seeing my Initiate having a pink peice of armor that looks like a brain on top of her general cap. (I used the sky captain skin.) It looks rather silly, but the rest of the armor seems to be okay to me at least. Maybe even add an option that Terraria does, having a vanity slot so you can place over weapons/armor and have the gear you like in terms of look. Another problem I have is the matchmaking. Not so much the DRM, but I'd love to find which matches would need a DPS hero or a Tower hero. This way I know I am needed in the mission and I am not pushed aside or unneeded for the task at hand. It annoys me to find another aura monk already building, so I have to either be sorta useless in terms of damage or leave the match.Aside from the problems, I find this game to be great. It is a nice change from the original, and for cheap, too. I suggest if you are a hardcore veteran of the first game like I am, to pick it up. Or if you haven't, enjoy it while you can before Dungeon Defenders 2 comes out! Overall I'd give this game an 8/10.

number of helpful: 9 of 23 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												An early review of the game so a long ways down the road, if absolutely none of this makes sense it is due to post changes since release. Also, this review is not for people who will not go tl:dr.This game is under some understandable criticism and a few disappointing facts that I had not known about before buying this game. The few that spring immediately to mind are the willingness to add microtransactions to the game for emotes and what I can only assume are future skins, weapons, and pets. I'm not a fan of microtransactions, but if it's strictly for cosmetic purposes, I have no quarrels with it. The next problem is the current mass of users in a local tavern. While I'm not all users playing the game are in a single localized tavern, I do miss having privacy and inviting friends from my own friendslist and screwing around before starting the missions we plan on doing. Being in the same people with 20+ local strangers gives me the feeling of being in a tavern in an MMO where I read non-stop messages about stuff I do not care to read. The adjustment in the tavern was probably the result of using playerverse dedicated servers (To which you will need to create an account to play this game). The playerverse server is a split issue with me because it requires two overlays and a new account for a game service I rarely plan on keeping up to date with, but the developers chose it as a more secure dedicated system it seems so I cannot complain... too much anyways.The positive side? This game has all the maps and challenges in it, minus the holiday themed maps(for now). It also has all the playable characters from the original, including the Jester, EV and Barbarian. I personally play as the summoner because of mobile forces and the closest thing to top down RTS feel as possible. Although it might be from not creating a new character in a while, the rebalances seemed to have made the enemies on level 1(Deeper Wells) on normal considerably harder. It took me 3~4 tries while my crystal was destroy to gather mana, gear and points before I could summon enough forces to fend off my crystal. I'm chalking that up to my own fault, but I'll probably play to unlock all levels on easy for the time being. Still, nothing like a challenge, eh? There are a couple of new maps and features I'd like to look into as well. Some pets are hatched from eggs, a step I don't necessarily thing was absolutely needed, but if a sense of some sort of accomplishment is needed, why not? There are also new maps that are to be included in Dungeon Defenders II that I'd like to see as well.A personally messages that will probably provoke people who read this review: This game came out litterally a day ago and it seems like 94% of the people who have already reviewed it have already condemned it due to the game not standing up to expectations. All I ask as a critic is that you give developers the chance to fix bugs in the game. Very few games are released glitch free. This doesn't mean the developer is entirely fault free and I'm still looking at post on the net, seeing if there was any information before this game was released, such as open or closed beta testing. Maybe this game should have been early access on steam rather then full out released? Apparently single player and private sessions were added on the day of the release, but few people can find it. I did not seem to have a problem finding private session, but maybe an entirely single player mode could be added.This review is only recommending the game because I wish the developer will take this seriously and will put a little effort into listening to the players for help and advice and that the players will be patient and bear with the developers while issues are sorted out.

Posted: July 23, 2014
												First impressions of this.. remake?.. were not good.I was greeted by a launcher. Then I was required to create a new account, email and all. Then once I jumped into game I experenced latecy issues, related to walking. I appeared in a tavern full of people, which I kept bumping into and they blocked the tavernkeeper. I would have to navigate past them. Textures were being downloaded as I was playing. They were extremely low quality textures that continue to happen when I enter a new area.I found that the summoner no longer has her own units. This made me give up on summoner in this version, and It was my favorite champion in the base game. Everyone has access to the dlc characters, which felt like a slap to the face for those of us who bought all dlc. When you put your mouse of an icon it takes 1 second or more for text to appear.- this should really be instant. It's a pain to discover what each icon means.Now to the good stuff.I like the new coin system a lot. I love the dye system. I really enjoy the new equipment and how you use coins to upgrade pets/equipment instead of mana. Now when you equip items they actually appear on your summoner. I like how there's now anti-hack, which was a huge problem in the base game. I like the new maps and content, I actually have to parcicipate, instead of leaving my pets to do all the dirty work. Did I mention you now find pet eggs? Gaining one level is a challenge in this game. Which means you should pick your characters wisely.While I feel the bad stuff should be worked on, especially that summoner problem, I have to admit the good stuff makes the game worth it.

number of helpful: 5 of 15 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												After playing Dungeon Defenders Eternity for a bit, I can see what other reviewers have been concerned about. While I echo some of these concerns, others I do not.First and foremost, many have said that the game should not be purchased due to lack of single player mode. That has been rectified, and I have played through the first level on a couple of different difficulties by myself with a couple of characters, and can confirm that this mode is working fine. Trendy had thought that their server costs might be too high if they immediately allowed single player, and quickly backed off due to the backlash over not having the mode. While it should have shipped with the mode enabled, I was pleased that they quickly rectified the situation. I will note, however, that all play is online and requires you to establish a separate account. This is both good and bad, as, while it does require you to always have an internet connection, it also allows you to continue your characters across devices. More devices, such as androids and iPads, should be coming in the near future, and I'm quite excited about that feature, especially assuming I can keep my characters.The second point, I think, is the primary cause for concern, and that is micropayments. Currently a number of specialized emotes can be purchased for $1 each in the store, amounting to a total of $30ish. This would bring the cost of the game to over $50 if one were to purchase all of them, but I sincerely doubt one would. Of course, being emotes, these are hardly necessary to beat the game mercilessly. However, it does open the door for other microtransactions. The store is far from fully stocked, and I expect that we will see more items that require real money soon. That said, Trendy has stated that DD2 will not be pay to win, and I expect that this game won't be either.Those are the main concerns I've seen from people, Now on to the features. So far I really like the rebalance, and I LOVE the visible armor, consumables, and general polish that the game seems to have. It feels like a nice update to the original Dungeon Defenders. There weren't any features I felt were missing, and progression so far has felt very smooth. I was most pleased, I think, that I found a few of the items that were harder to find in the original DD, such as pets and belts, immediately. I haven't felt like I wasn't getting the gear I needed, and I think Trendy has made sure that the loot progression feels a little more fluid than it did in DD, where I admittedly got stuck in the 70s. I can only hope that this trend continues.Overall, I would say that DDE is a nice update to DD that doesn't entirely deserve the criticism currently being levied at it. Time will tell if the game will continue to live up to my high regard for Trendy after the beauty that was the original Dungeon Defenders, but I'm confident that they have it in them to do what's right here.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Well looking at it as someone who owned the original with the DLCs, I got a lot of things I like, but a bunch I don't as well.My biggest problems are the public tavrens and the changes to my main, The SummonerThe Summoner took a big hit in this change, while his units still hit as well as always as far as I can tell, he now works on the same defense units as everyone else instead of his own. This makes having the same setups that made him great before nearly impossible to do and makes you have to rethink your way of playing him. I guess its nice for balancing sake, but as someone who's main character was the Summoner, it is rather disappointing.The Public Taverns just personally annoy me. I go into the game to just play with my friends and we all get pulled into a tavern with like 10 other people, some of whom are firing weapons or testing defenses on the dummies. I it rather annoying and they even made a room that you can go to that blocks out the sounds from the Tavern, but that room has no forge so you have to go back in to use it.Now that said, I love the new pet hatching system, the dyes and the custom armour that actually appears on the characters. I think if you don't own the original  and want the DLCs without speanding the extra money ot buy them with the original, then pick this up. For those who do own the original, well for owning the orginal I got it for 6 bucks when it first came out and i think there is enough here to make it worth picking up, though i would wait for a sale instead of paying the full 20 for basiclly the same game with new features

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												There is always the one corky game that people like, and for me this is one of them, although it's not epic. it's a fun little time waster, and i think that is what they were attempting to archive with this game. I love the cartoon look to the game, it's very well done, and feels as if i was playing LOL on an art level, not on game play level though. The game is very easy to learn, you literally just join a dungeon and slay the enemies, get loot, upgrade your armor and skills and move on to the next level of dungeon. There are a few things you can buy at the Ingame store if you're the type of person that likes buying Ingame content, but most of it you can do without, i've seen some people crying about this because they cant get it for free. ignore them they are out their minds.I've personally never played this on phone, I 'v seen a lot of rather negative reviews, but i would not generally listen to those, most of those people are generally mad at life rather then the actual game they just take it out on reviews. I find that people thrive on making people fail these days, that how i see the reviews most people leave here as well.  Overall i would give this game a 8/10 simply because is fun, easy and well made.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												I have to rewrite my review, since they fixed matchmaking.From what I can tell, having played the PC, mobile, and Xbox 360 versions, this is a port of the Mobile version.It includes every class released in the original, plus a bunch of the costumes (I'm wondering if some aren't unlockable/purchasable later.) It also includes every map from the original, DLC included, plus several new ones.The loot is fixed and balanced, from what I can tell.The characters are fixed and balanced.Summoners, while nerfed (They don't use MU anymore) got a decent buff (Mages cost less, Orcs are viable).Trendy HAS announced that they're putting in Private Rooms (effectively creating a single player mode) but will keep the Playverse up (so as to prevent hacking, I suppose.)As of right now, there's a nasty bug where, if you die with your last hero in Hardcore, you won't be able to play anymore. They've said they have it fixed, and are working on sending out the patch. Bought a copy for my girlfriend and she only had one character. We didn't die, but were removed from our game (couldn't go back to the tavern because of some Party glitch), which caused my Ranger and her Countness to be considered "dead." So, basically, if you're going to play with friends and create parties, disband the party once the map is done with, and just remake it. (You get booted to the main menu either way, since the Taverns have trouble finding slots for more than one person, apparently.)

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												There are some pretty amazing differences from the first.  Individual chests, individual loot, currency separate from building mana, gear info stored on their servers to help prevent hacking.  I let it download all the way and it worked fine.  Summoners now have separate units.  There are pro's and con's I think it needs work too, but I remember DD1 not being a sparkling miracle the first day it came out either.There is a clunky UI. Ability activation isn't as smooth. The latency issues are not too bad, this being their attempt at a diablo type system.  Lots of new stuff to mess around with.  This is not an IOS port for people who have heard rumors.  I like starting fresh.  If you would rather have modded weapons though, the original version is still there.  I think that there will be people that like the original also, they have spent a long time there with many high level characters.  Those people are not forgotten.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												So far I am really enjoying this game, however, there are still some issues that need to be ironed out in my own opinion. Essentially it is a reboot of the same game, with a few additional maps, better scaling and quite interesting graphic and unlockable options, however, as it is early days there are some things that the developers need to address quite fast:1 - Time waiting for a private game. Mostly, I prefer to play my own games, especially at low level just to get a feel for my own playstyle and have a bit of fun without some rather nasty folks getting in my way. Yet even with a private game option, there is still a long countdown to the game start...no need to wait for other players if you're not expecting (or wanting) any.2 - The tavern needs some serious revamping. I can see where they were going with creating a community hub, but what they have really created is a lagfest extravaganza, not to mention, a headache. I would love to be able to comment on the purchaseable items and the changes in pet levelling, but I simply can't because I lose my mind after more than 4 minutes of looking in my itembox because Monk 56 wants to mess about with Aura's all over my bloody screen and the squire has created a dozen harpoon turrets that have rapid attack speed.3 - The timeout at the end of each level needs to be discontinued, or at least replaced with a 'Select another level' screen. Also, where on earth did the retry button go? You have to zone back in to the headache zone in order to try another level. And you don't get 'dwelling' time where you can inspect the drop items at the end of the game, you have a limited time to look at them and get out. Forcing you in the larger maps especially, to collect 10 tonnes of crap in your item box.4 - This is the big one. Why do I have to sit in an ever changing queue to play the game at all? So far I've spent a few hours playing the game, and more than double that waiting in a queue for a 'session' from the server. And the queueing system is pitiful, with me so far being 4th, 12th, 18th and 1st in the queue, but still not actually getting past the menu. More annoyingly, is that this doesn't seem to be a global issue. Only a few forum posts exist about it, and none of the guides or publicised material by Trendy make any reference to this. It is annoyingly bizarre. Overally, the bits that I have seen so far have been really grand, its just these very strange features that I can't seem to understand why they were created in the first place.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Long time Dungeon Defender players may raise an eyebrow or two at Dungeon Defenders Eternity. At best it seems like a light DLC at the current discounted price for previous owners ($6 USD). It includes a few new maps, a new consumable system, rebalance of classes (summoner being one of the bigger changes), and a new patching system which requires an online connection to play single player. Players can also play crossplatform with this version. There's also a built in cash shop in the game and for the time being, it only contains cosmetic things for $1 USD for a costume. The developers have said they intend to keep it cosmetic only and not pay to win. Currency is also changed from mana to in game coins creating a slower climb to currency becoming trivial. DDE includes all of the original's DLC minus some of the holiday maps (for now).As of this writing, there are many bugs that plague this new version from summoner pets jumping off cliffs to hotkeys being unbound with every map. The bright side of this is the new patching system is far better than before. Like Guild Wars, they can patch small things with minimal downtime server-side.The UI is far more suitable for mouse and keyboard in this iteration, albeit a bit clunky at the moment. It's still more customizable than the original DD. Controller support on the other hand is clunkier on this version. Hopefully these quality of life things will get ironed out with time.So for those who own the original and enjoyed it DDE really only offers a chance at a fresh start with less hackers, a few new maps and a promise of easier distribution of content with the new software for the future. For $6 USD, it could pass for DLC-lite for prior owners. For those who haven't tried the original DD or don't own most of the DLC for the original, even the normal price of $20 USD is a worthwhile investment. However, for normal price, prior owners who own all the DLC might want to hold off picking this up until there's more meat on the bone.I really wish there was a way to just post a review without a recommendation. For DDE, it's less black and white and more 'depends'. There's potential in DDE as something to hold out until DD2, but for now it's only for those looking for a fresh start or those who haven't tried DD, a fantastic tower defense game. The tech behind the patching system is a very solid foundation for future content, hopefully TrendyNet will support DDE with more content before the inevitable DD2 hits the market.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												I like the game, I really do. New features and all that. It's like the reverse Borderlands effect. If you have no idea what that is, grab an umbrella, because I'm about to drop some knowledgeBorderlands was a good game, but its sequal only changed its map and the characters. The game mechanics essentially stayed the same.In Dungeon Defenders Eternity, the characters and maps from the first game are there (minus the DLC stuff, I might add) and the game mechanics really changed. Pets can use abilities, you can pick up amulets for more abilities, and the whole darn thing got balanced!Now, as you'd expect with some newer releases, it does have some bugs. The biggest one I think anyone who's played it is the matchmaking, which they even send notifications about if it's that bad. You'll sometimes be unable to find a game or even leave the Tavern.Overall, I really enjoy the game, and if they can fix that there matchmaking it'd be a really fantastic addition to the family of Dungeon Defenders.

number of helpful: 0 of 6 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												Edit: I have put more time into this game and it has been updated. First, you can now play alone or just with friends. Thank you devs for listening. Second, I didn't realize you could wait until the game fully loads, then it won't stream to you, you'll be playing natively. Makes things look and play quite a bit better. You still need to have a constant internet connection, which can be a pain with a laptop, but if you are playing on a desktop, then you'll have that anyway. I still say that if you want to play locally, or just with friends, the original is packed with content. But if you are new to the series, and don't have problems when you play games online, this is a pretty good value. I still don't like the microtransactions for costumes, but to be honest, that's what the DLC for the first game was anyway. I wish they would keep it to costumes though, and ditch paying for more in game coins. They really do listen to their fans, and I like that about the developer. Controller support is still really bad though. So grab a mouse and keyboard and enjoy. for the small price of $20 or $6 if you have the old dungeon defenders, it's not bad. Lastly, this doesn't effect the old version. you can have both versions installed and seperate. I don't like the always online, but I guess if it means better balance then I'll try to deal with it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Dont listen to all the hate about this game, most of all the errors are fixed and the game is still being updated. i will do my original Pro's & Cons BabiPros:Runs on a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ computer: My specs are♥♥♥♥♥♥ the best i know is i have a 1.GHZ yes, it is so♥♥♥♥♥♥ but i run this game 60 - 120 fps, so if you got my computer this will run perfectly fine (on low graphics of course) so no worrys about thatShowing Armor = When you put on armor you can actually see it on your body, there was a bug with armor inside of costumes but it is fixed.All DLC is free from the first game = Really this game is just a test for their new engine, Playverse. But dont get me wrong. If you didnt have the dlc or even had any dlc at all from the first game this is really something that is amazing, this includes all costumes, dlc heroes and maps. and yes, i said dlc heroes, Dyes And Crafting = oh my, you can actually craft♥♥♥♥♥♥ And dye your gear like never before. Lets start with the dyes. Im not sure or i havent tried it. ill edit if so, but im Pretty sure you can dye Weapons, Armor, And your default attire ♥♥♥♥ING RED AND PURPLE BLUE WEAPON OF DEATH?!?! AM I RIGHT? Lets get to crafting, Its hard, but worth it. You find blueprints apon lootdrops, (chests, enemies ect) and you can use those blueprints to craft. I havent done much with it. but its still cool.New tavern = Do i even have to explain this?Boosters: Oh yes, you can use XP boosters (doubles xp for the current wave can use more for future waves) and theres other boosters, like Loot boosters, Loot quality Boosters And moreNow with the CONS (I might of not put much of pros becuase i couldent think of♥♥♥♥♥♥to put)Cons:Playverse = This is the most hated peice of sh** in the game, The game comes with its own ♥♥♥♥ing launcher, With its ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 7 gig download, (you can play when the game is at 25% doe) And the ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ friending system. jesus.Summoner = Not the charater itself is bad, well now the charater is more♥♥♥♥♥♥ Beucase In the first game the summoner had its own defence units (How many towers you can place untill you have no defence units, example i have 80 defence units, a harpoon turrent takes 5 units once im out of units i cannot place anymore towers) so it was easier to do builds and such, But nooooooo This game had to take away that great feature, the summoner now uses default defense units.Public Tavern: what the ♥♥♥♥. Everyone that joins the game has to go into a public tavern to play online, which means its laggy asf you can use a private tavern (FINNALLY) but you will still get a tiny bit of lag here and there.Level Cap: The first game the highest level you can aquire is 100, this game is 60, like what the ♥♥♥♥ again.....Even though i dont have many hours into the game, I have played the console versions for over 4 years (on game release really) And yes i recommend this game, ♥♥♥♥ing play it. Its worth it i swear.
